text:
Great Sauce.  I breaded the chicken rolls in a mixture of seasoned bread crumbs and flour.  After browning, I transferred to baking dish and cooked at 350 for about 35 mins. At 30 minutes I spooned some sauce over and baked the last 5 minutes.  I also brined the chicken breasts for a day because brined chicken is more flavorful and moist.  I used Prociutto and swiss cheese.  This sauce is heaven.  Make extra because its that good.  You have to use wine because it is what makes this sauce. No substitutions , i suggest chardonnay.  Spoon the sauce over the chicken and over rice.  10 stars.

text:
I made this recipe for my family of four.  My husband is a big eater and I'm no slouch.  I could only get halfway through one breast and he barely cleaned his plate.  Not because the chicken wasn't good (it was *sinfully* good) but very filling.  Pan frying was essential; it's the drippings that make the sauce, and the sauce that makes the meal.  I went the whole route, with heavy whipped cream and butter.  Of course, we added noodles to the meal and they helped fill us up :)  The richness of the sauce was beyond belief; I couldn't stop nibbling the chicken even after I was so full I couldn't have eaten another bite of anything else.  I did take a number of suggestions; the Panko crumbs and garlic, and bits of swiss cheese added to sauce.  I used knitting yarn to wrap them up - remember to remove yarn *before* pouring on the sauce :)  My husband wants me to make it again - first time that ever happened!

text:
First time making this dish an wow! I always read most helpful reviews an then go from there. this is how I prepared it:  used thick chx breast an cut slits in side. took ham slices an wrapped it around cheeze(so it wouldnt leak out) an stuffed in chx. I used cooking string instead of toothpicks to seal. I used an egg wash instead of butter then rolled chx in a mixture of Panko, Paprika, Italian bread crumbs, & just a dash of garlic powder. Baked at 350 for 45mins. My mother-in-law can only have a gluten free diet so this dish was perfect! i made her chx in a seperate dish (had to use gluten free bread crumbs) put a small thin cube of butter on top of each chx when placed in oven. Right before the chx was ready I prepared the sauce, (I used a sauvignon blanc) then spooned it on ready chicken. It was out of this world! my sides were simple, broccoli an mashed potatoes with the sauce on top. YUM! DEFinitly puttin this one in rotation!!!!

Super yummy!! I've made this twice once exactly as written and it turned out good. Next time I used smoked gouda instead of swiss because it's what I had on hand. Gouda tends to be less runny so it doesn't leak out while cooking and tastes amazing!! I also brushed each breast with egg and rolled in bread crumbs instead of flour. Definately tie the ends instead of using toothpicks, much easier. My family agrees that the Gouda makes an awesome dish even BETTER!!!

text:
I made this last night for some friends, it was wonderful.  I followed the other suggestions, and brushed with egg and used bread crumbs instead of flour.  Rolled cheese in the ham before putting in chicken and it did help to keep the cheese from oozing out while baking.  Baked for about 30 min in a 350 oven; came out perfect!  For the sauce, I didn't have whipping cream, so I used a can of cream of chicken soup added one can of water and 1 Cup of Pinot Grigio; salt and pepper and then let it simmer on the stove while the chicken was in the oven and it was delicious and very easy.   Served with angel hair pasta and asparagus wrapped in prosciutto (recipe from this website).  Great dinner, thanks!  Will definitely serve again.

text:
AWESOME. Made it for my boyfriend's birthday last night, and now I can do no wrong! As other reviewers have written, I made these modifications to the base recipe: added a thin layer of baby spinach leaves when stuffing, coated in breadcrumbs instead of flour, sauteed in a mixture of butter AND olive oil, and when beautifully browned, I transferred them and placed in a 350 degree oven (covered with aluminum foil) while I prepared the sauce. This keeps the crispness on the breasts. To serve, I sliced the breasts (they looked sooo pretty) and drizzled the sauce on top. Also topped with a little chopped parsley (which gave it that "finished look" we all seek). I used high-end ingredients (cheese, ham, and wine), and feel they may have contributed to the overall success of this dish. OUTSTANDING.

text:
Made this almost exactly as recipe stated, except substituted half-n-half for heavy cream.  To die for!!  The sauce was heavenly.  I actually kept the chicken on Low in saute pan (used just chicken stock to simmer) after browning while I waited for hubby to get home with the wine, so some of the cheese melted into the sauce.  I think this helped add a nice flavor to the sauce.  Removed chickens, added wine, brought to a boil for a few minutes to reduce sauce, then added cream mixture.  UNBELIEVABLE sauce!!  This is one of the best recipes I've ever made from allrecipes, and I've made a lot!  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Amazing results!  I couldn't resist the temptation of panko from previous reviews so I did change the recipe quite a bit. I brushed inside of chicken with dijon mustard before layering ham/cheese.  I brushed chicken with beaten egg, then rolled in panko.  I browned in butter/oil combo in saute pan then transferred to oven to finish cooking. I cooked sauce seperately by warming 1 cup wine and 3 Tbls butter.  In seperate bowl, combined 2 cups half and half with 2 Tbls cornstarch, then whisked into wine sauce, brought to a simmer until thickened. Drizzled sauce over chicken and used extra on roasted potatoes.

Display Name:
Maria2007

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/43919.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the "most helpful" reviews, I decided to prepare the chicken with an egg wash and bread crumb mixture.  I added paprika, Garlic Powder and a little Garlic salt to the bread crumbs. I tied my chicken up using cooking ties (rope) rather then the tooth picks.  I Pan fried in 3 tbs. of butter on all sides and then stuck the pan in a 350 degree oven for 25 mins. When the chicken was done baking, I transferred it to a plate and used the same pan that I browned and baked the chicken in to prepare the wine sauce.  I doubled the sauce I warmed 1 cup wine, 3 tbls. butter and 2 tsp. bullion in the pan. Mixed 2 tbls. Cornstarch and 1 cup heavy cream  cup 2% milk in a separate bowl and added to the wine mixture, stirred with a whisk until it came to a boil and thickened. Sliced the cooked chicken into 1 inch rounds and placed it atop a bed of wide egg noodles.  I then topped with the creamy wine sauce and dried parsley. Served with steamed veggies w/ garlic butter. I swear this site never ceases to amaze me.  My husband thanks you.

text:
The sauce made this extraordinary!!  I made several modifications though.  I halved the chicken and pounded 1/2inch thick (sprinkled both sides with salt, pepper, and oregano), placed the ham and swiss on top and then rolled it up, dipped the roll into a mixture of: 1 clove minced garlic, 1 egg, and chicken broth; then covered the dipped roll in 1 cup panko bread crumbs mixed with `1 tsp paprika, then FINALLY, baked at 350 for 30 minutes.  I made the sauce seperate, and drizzled it over chopped and baked poatoes seasoned with paprika, cayenne, salt, and garlic.  The chicken was moist and fork tender, and the sauce made it amazing.  My whole family went nuts for it.  My husband told me I can make it anytime :-)

Yummy!!  The sauce that goes on top is to die for.  One thing I was confused about while making the recipe was whether I should empty out the juices from the chicken in the pan before I added the cream and cornstarch.  The answer is you shouldn't!  I didn't, and it was delicious!  Also, I had trouble getting my chickens rolled up perfectly with the cheese and ham inside (the ham and cheese were kind of bursting out the sides) but this is OK!  They definitely kept their shape after they were cooked and the toothpicks were removed.  This meal took a bit too long for me for a weeknight after work, but I will DEFINITELY make it again on a weekend!

text:
OHHHH YES!!  This was GREAT!  I cooked it for my future inlaws and everyone loved it!  A few things.. per others recommendations, I rolled the cheese and ham together first, then rolled chicken around them.  The trick to keeping everything in the chicken is refrigerating the breasts after you roll them (no toothpicks or twine needed) for an hour or so and THEN rolling in flour and cooking.  Also, I put a little garlic powder in the flour mix.  I browned on the stovetop for about 5-7 minutes on each side, then baked in the oven at 350 for about 35 minutes.  I cooked the sauce seperately in a saucepan and served on the side.  The sauce was AMAZING.  I was worried that it would taste too "wine-ey," but it was perfect.  Great all-around, and will definitely be making again!

Very good. I wrapped my Swiss cheese with the ham "Burrito" style before putting it inside the pounded chicken breast. I think this helped to keep more of the cheese inside the chicken apposed to leaking out into the sauce. I also tied the chicken with roast-string once around the middle. This made handling the chicken very easy and I didn't have to worry about the toothpicks getting in the way during the browning stage. Served with white rice and steamed broccoli. Great dinner. Thanks for the recipe.

userID:

Display Name:
BERDISA
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1673271.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my gosh, this was fantastic!  I found my chicken was very easy to roll since I pounded them well.  Even if you mistakenly make a hole in the breast the ham seals it so your cheese doesn't leak out.  What I did find difficult was to remove the toothpicks after the rolls were cooked.  I coated my rolls with a combo of flour, breadcrumbs & seasoning.  After browninging in butter/olive oil I removed the rolls and added wine, bullion and 2% milk to the skillet.  I returned the rolls to the pan and simmered for 30 minutes covered, turning frequently.  I also doubled the liquid ingredients.    After simmering, I removed the rolls and thickened the sauce with a cornstarch slurry; served the sauce on the side.  I will certainly make this again.  Note: Careful of how much salt you add, the ham may be salty enough.  I didnt need any between the ham and bullion granules.

text:
obviously this recipe is awesome as most of these reviews are a testiment... and is definitely a winner in my house but i have one tip as a few people have said there is an "oozing" effect (even tho the cheese adds a nice flavor to the sauce) you can tie the chicken and everything up with some simple thread and snip and unwind it at the end of cooking and end up with a nice happy bundle!

text:
I served this wonderful recipe last night for a small dinner party. Everybody loved it!!! I read some of the reviews before I made this and took some advice.  I breaded my chicken instead of floured and I used 1/2 butter & 1/2 olive oil for browning.  I then baked the chicken for 30 minutes. Ask for thin sliced ham & cheese at the deli counter and pound chicken breasts a little thinner for a roll that won't require picks or string. YUMMY!  I will serve this again & again.

text:
Great recipe!  I baked mine and heres what I did.
I did wrap my cheese with the ham.  I made a slit in the fattest part of the chicken and made a pocket for the cheese/ham to fit the length of the chicken.  I then toothpicked the end, salt and peppered the chicken breast. Took a casserole dish, Pam sprayed it and added the chicken breast. Added about 1/4 cup of water. Baked covered at 350' for 50 mins. I did not use the flour and paprika step being I did not fry mine.   I then made the sauce using the butter, wine, bouillon, half & half and cornstrach all as stated in the recipe. Brought to a boil and then simmered low until chicken was ready. I served mine with buttered noodles but also mixed in some sauce to the noodles. All came out heavenly!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/59450.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for dinner last night, and it turned out very well. I don't even like chicken in the first place, but this dish certainly turned me on to it. I couldn't find halved chicken breasts, so I used boneless, skinless, trimmed chicken breast tenders, and they were a breeze to fill & cook! Rolling the tenders around the filling was a cinch, and I did not experience any cheese leakage during cooking. Also, instead of simmering them in the skillet for 30 minutes, I was able to reduce cooking time by half (since the tenders were so thin). The wine seemed to cook off quickly, even on low heat, so I added about 1/2 a cup more than the recipe called for. My only problem was the sauce. I think it would have been better with half & half (or even whole milk), because when I combined the heavy whipping cream and the cornstarch to the wine mixture, it quickly formed a gelatinous lump. It still tasted alright, but it wasn't a pretty sight. I will definitely be making this recipe again (with all my aforementioned tweaks, of course!)

text:
This has to be one of the best discoveries yet on this site!  Dinner's been over for a while now but my boyfriend is still emoting about how much he liked this!  My presentation needs improvement, but the taste was absolutely divine.  I used a pinoir grigio for the white wine, used a whole stick of butter, followed another review's lead in spreading a little dijon mustard on the chicken before adding the cheese and ham, and added a little pepper to the flour mixture.  This recipe is company worthy, but it's so good I'm going to make up special occasions just so we may have it often at home!  Thanks for the submission!

text:
This was very very good but i too  made some changes. First i pounded the chicken then added some garlic powder to the chicken before placing the ham in cheese in the middle then dipped in a beaten egg and bread crumbs cooked it in a little olive oil and butter till lightly browed on each side then place it in oven for 20 minutes 10 on each side sprinkled the chicken a bit of white wine while cooking. Mixed the rest if the ingredients in a bowl and added it to chicken and let it simmer for another 10 minutes.  DELICIOUS!!!! and well worth the effort!!

text:
I noticed someone had said they needed help removing the toothpicks.  I use the metal turkey stays that come in the little trussing packages at the store - they look like giant needles w/big eyes.  They are SO easy to remove and are longer than toothpicks so they secure the meat better too.

text:
Its true.  This really is as good as everyone says and not that difficult to make.  Ours were so fat there was no way toothpicks were going to hold so we tied them up with string and that worked perfectly.  Next time I'll use a really good dry white wine instead of the cheap stuff.  Its worth it.  Also, on one of them I inadvertently rolled it up with the inner, rough side of the chicken on the outside.  That one was the best one because it held the most coating.

text:
So much grease!  It didn't dawn on me until the very end of experience that a "gravy" not grease sauce was the intent.  Loads of red grease. I will try this recipe again, but will compensate by skimming out grease before doing the heavy cream/cornstarch deal.  The red grease probably came from too much butter & cheese fat, red came from paprika.  This recipe would probably come out much better if baked (and separate sauce prepared with some of the drippings (not a pan full of greasy muck). But my grocery stores on strike ...

userID:
15281494
Display Name:
Winston's Mom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read a lot of both the negative and the positive reviews of this recipe prior to making this and I find that most of the complaints are due to poor execution and not due to any fault in this recipe, that being said this is not a recipe for beginners and requires a bit of finesse to get right.
    Everything turned out lovely. The chicken MUST be pounded out (Recommend approx 1/2 inch thickness) Useful trick... sandwich the chicken breasts one at a time between 2 layers of saran wrap on top of a cutting board (you can reuse the saran wrap for about 2-3 breasts)before you tenderize the meat as this will keep the mess/clean up to a minimum. For the ham and Swiss cheese inside I chose smoked varieties of both and had them sliced on the medium/thick side. In addition to the base recipe I used 2 chicken bouillon cubes instead of the granules (it was what I had on hand), about 1 cup pinot grigio, 1 1/2 cups heavy whipping cream and 1 1/2 tablespoons of corn starch. Sauce thickened up nicely and had plenty of flavor. We like a lot of sauce.
    To quote my brother "I could eat this every day!" 

P.s. Fresh steamed broccoli goes great on the side and the sauce tastes amazing on it!!!

Display Name:
Suzanne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a new family favorite! The only thing I do differently is that after rolling the ham and cheese into the chicken, I try to make sure the cheese is the last layer touching chicken-to-chicken when I'm done rolling.  Then I wrap it in aluminum foil and bake at 400 for about 30-40 minutes depending on the size of the breast. The cheese acting as a glue, together with the baking process, virtually removes the need to toothpick the chicken and work around the toothpicks in the dredging & frying process. After baking, unwrap, carefully "towel off" the chicken, dredge and fry until golden -  for about 10-15 minutes.  The chicken comes out moist and super delicious. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I follow the ingredients EXACTLY. I pound the chicken flat but instead of rolling them, I stack a flat piece of chicken with the cheese and ham and just pile another flat piece of chicken on top. Toothpick them together and fry it like a sandwhich. Much easier than rolling them. After frying them, bake it for 30 minutes, make the sauce separately and pour on right at the end. Cut the chicken in half and each person gets the equivalent of one whole piece.

country:
None
text:
Made it like the recipe the first time, came out really good. The second time, however, I cut the chicken breasts in half lengthwise. Put the ham slices down on the chicken breasts after cutting, topped with swiss cheese, and folded the ham slices on the sides and ends inward to help keep the cheese from melting out. Then folded the chicken sides and ends inward over the ham, then rolled up and secured. Keeps the cheese in much better. I did double the wine and whipping cream, the sauce was too good not to! The second time around was a little more work but came out much better. This is now one of my "go to" or "fall back" recipes when invaded by my kids teenage friends, or cooking for horse show meetings/after show parties.

text:
Today I cooked the cordon bleu and it was just delicious. Instead of just flour I also dipped it in an egg-milk mix and afterwards in bread crumbs. 
As a side I made veggies (mini potatoes, zucchini and carrots) and rice.
Totally recommendable. Fry it in the pan until gold brown and afterwards you can put it in the 350' oven for about 15 min. And then it is ready to be served. 
Just to let you know: if you wrap the cheese into the ham, then it won't melt away and it will stay inside the cordon bleu. :)

With over 3500 reviews, this recipe doesn't need one more, but here it is anyways.   I made this recipe as written with the exception that I substituted chicken broth for the white wine.    With the ham and the chicken bouillon and the chicken broth, it does come out little on the salty side but it is sooooooooo worth it.   The sauce is wonderful with no other seasonings or spices needed.   I wondered how a recipe with almost no seasonings could be tasty, but it is.   It's very simple to make.   I will make again, and again, and again.

Best Recipe EVER! I have been making this recipe over and over for about a year now and I still love it. I have made it for every person I know and they all love it. My husband loves when I use bacon instead of ham. I love the sauce. Sometimes I will make the sauce to put over noodles as a side dish. Make sure to put plastic wrap over chicken before pounding it thiner or else it will fall apart. Love this and you will to.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/897860.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is so good and super easy!  My local grocery store sells thinly sliced chicken breasts, as opposed to the thick ones that you usually see so that's what I got for this dish.  I took one users advice and cut the breasts into 1" strips and I'm quite sure it worked out better, since it makes the dish a lot less bulky.  Also, I'm always afraid of chicken (thinking that I will under cook it) but because this was so thin, there was no question about whether or not it was done.  It's so picturesque too!  It looks like a real chef's plate.

This was just a trial run for me - I wanted to cook my mom something nice for Mother's Day and decided I would test this out.  I didn't have any chicken bouillon so I used beef...usually not a good idea but the recipe didn't suffer at all.  I didn't make any other changes and it turned out really well.  I made it with an herb rice (my own recipe) and broccoli.  It was great!

I made this tonight for dinner.  It was so good. My family loved it.  I did as other suggested and browned the chicken, then put in the oven at 350 for 25 min. I closed up the chicken as much as I could by using dry fettuccine noodles(instead of toothpicks) so that the cheese would not melt out on the ends. doing this I only had a little bit of cheese melt out of the chicken.

text:
Very Savory.  No real changes other than simmering the chicken, being I had the time, for an hour and half on low in the already prepared wine sauce which was made in pan after chicken seared.  All simmering together which made the dish easier as far as pan and prep. Used more white wine, less butter, no cornstarch but added some of the flour mixture that the chicken was coated in.  Cant really go wrong with this because any way you decide to change it it will be just fine.

text:
We had this today for Christmas dinner, and it did not disappoint!  After reading other reviews, I decided to brown the chicken in the pan, then I finished it in a 400F oven for 20 minutes--the same time and temp needed for my roasted asparagus.  I doubled the amount of sauce because I'd rather have too much sauce, rather than not enough.  Again... Delicious!  The sauce was looking pretty thick with the heavy cream, so I used half-and-half to substitute for half of the cream.  I will definitely make this again.

country:
None
text:
I only made a couple of changes.  I coat the chicken in Italian Bread Crumbs in lieu of the flour/paprika mixture.  I brown that in the butter, add a dash of cooking sherry, cover and cook in the oven.  I use the cooking sherry, bouillon, cream and either tarragon or basil (depending on the mood) in the sauce.  I don't mess with the cornstarch. It ends up thick enough after cooking slowly.  So delicious!

text:
Wow!  I've been wanting to make a Chicken Cordon Bleu dish for a while, not knowing how my family would like it.  I found this recipe and they LOVED it!!  My son, and husband can be extremely picky with anything that has a white sauce, and my son was begging for more!  My husband is still raving about this.  I follwed the recipe exactly as it is; however I used Low Sodium Deli Ham.  The portions were a tad small given to a growing boy and my husband, so next time I will "stuff" the chicken instead of rolling it up and see if that helps. Using the recipe as it was given and it turned out perfect!  Thanks so much!!  I will be using this as another weeknight meal again for sure!

text:
Kid and parent friendly (3 of 4 picky kids liked it, and 1 ate it despite complaints - that's a big win around here).  Made exactly as directed except that I subbed half and half for the whipping cream and didn't need to cook it 30 minutes (more like 20-22, I think, because I pounded it to just a little over 1/2 inch).  Served with steamed broccoli and with linguine noodles.  Not all the kids wanted the sauce, but they liked it fine without.  I subtracted one star because the pounding of the chicken took me forever, probably only because the pieces I started with were enormous and still slightly frozen...hopefully that will work out easier and less messy next time)!

text:
Great recipe, the only change I made was that I doubled the sauce and used half whipping cream, half 1% milk.  It was still delicious and plenty thick.  I browned the chicken on the stovetop and finished them off in the oven, as others suggested.  Made my sauce in the pan I browned the chicken in.  Used the wine to deglaze the browned bits from the chicken and added cream, etc.  I also recommend using string to tie up the chicken.  My family loved this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a wounderful dish.  I made a few changes to the recipe, starting with I baked the chicken at 375* F for 40 min covered.  I also cut the butter to 4 tbls.  Melt the butter in a small pan, add chicken bullion and wine, mix so everything is incorrperated.  Pour over the floured chicken rolls and cover put in oven and bake.  When the chicken is done move to a plate and cover.  Take the dripings in the baking pan and add to the pot heat on low.  Add the premixed cream and cornstartch to the pan with the drippings stirring until thickened about 7min.  Poor sauce over chicken and serve.  We had this with asparagus, rice, and salad a great meal!

text:
This was very yummy!!! I did make a few simple changes! I brushed the chicken w/ egg, then rolled it in bread crumbs instead of the flour, I cooked the chicken in frying pan as directed.  In a separate sauce pan, (I used chicken stock instead of white wine.) I whisked the Chicken stock, cornstarch, bouillon granules and whipping cream together and simmered for about 10-15 min.! I served the sauce on the side, not knowing if my kids (5 & 3) would like it, but they both loved it!!!

dateLastModified:
2011-01-07T16:31:46.53
helpfulCount:

userID:
2884745
Display Name:
Sarah
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
325
favoritesCount:
61
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/148478.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sooo good! I had a big hunk of turkey ham here, so I sliced a couple pieces as thin as I could and it worked great! I'm not so partial to swiss and I had fresh mozzarella on hand, so I sliced that thin as well. For just me and my husband, I took one large chicken breast and cut it in half (butterfly style) and then pounded the pieces thin. Before I rolled it all up I put a little salt and pepper inside. I assembled the chicken a few hours in advance and let them set in the fridge after securing them with toothpicks. Instead of flour, I rolled the chicken in egg and then Italian bread crumbs. I then sprinkled a little paprika on top and browned them up with butter and olive oil. When I was ready to make the sauce, I put the chicken in the oven for 10 minutes at 350 and despite making much less chicken, I made almost the full amount of sauce (just a little less heavy cream, and added a bit of chicken broth) and it was perfect! It's kind of freaky gelatinous, but super good. I needed a little flavor boost, so I added a second bouillon cube. I will definitely make this again.

text:
I have been cooking for my girlfriend, a (now) 5 year old, and myself for about 3 years. I love to cook, and with no prior experience have basically used recipes off of this site, usually making it more than once to tweak it and attempt to make something better. I constantly read reviews to get an idea for the recipes, and I have never written one. I have to write one for this. I may cook for the two most pickiest girls in the world who never want to try anything that they have never had, until this.  They asked for it again the next night and have many more times.  It's easy to make, and absolutely delicious.  I was nervous using Riesling wine because I thought it may be too sweet, but I usually have it on hand... And it was terrific.  Thank you for the recipe.

text:
I did this recipe, and it was amazing! Easy to do and tasty. I did some changes to the recipe because I have different ingredients, I used Gouda Cheese or Queso Holands, Sauvignon Blanc wine, Low Fat Jam, Low fat whipping cream and butter, I also mix the butter with Olive oil. In addition, I made some changes to the cooking process, I passed the chicken rolls thru egg first then thru the paprika and flour, I cooked the chicken until browned in the butter/Oil and passed to the oven for 20 minutes, also, to the cream or dressing I added basil too Really Good

text:
Easy and delicious! I butterflied the chicken to make it easier to wrap around the ham & cheese. I think next time I'm going to freeze the swiss and wrap the ham around it so it doesn't melt out as much. I lightened it up a little with a combination of half & half and skim milk (cause I didn't have any heavy cream) and it turned out great. Definitely double the sauce because it would be great on potatoes, rice, or veggies.

text:
Loved it! Thanks for the recipe. I followed it exactly and used Kenwood's Sauvignon Blanc for the wine sauce. The sauce was so very yummy! It wasn't an overpowering winey taste-it was just right! Even my daughter used it for dipping her bread in! We have so much sauce leftover we were trying to figure out how to use it for our next meal! I did actually have one variation to the recipe. I went to get my cornstarch out and I didn't have any, so I used flour instead and it was fine. I have to add I have never made Chicken Cordon Bleu in a skillet before, but after this it is the only way I will be making it from now on! It was very easy and everyone loved it! A Keeper!

text:
This chicken was fantastic! I made a few slight changes such as replacing the flour with panko bread crumbs and doubling the sauce.  I also seasoned the bread crumbs with italian seasoning, basil, garlic powder, black pepper and crushed red pepper flakes (in addition to the paprika).  My boyfriend asked me to make it every night!  And he's the cook out of the two of us!  I also found (in a pinch) that using uncooked linguine will work to hold the chicken together while cooking. Just break the ends off and they cook with the chicken.  The bf and I didn't even notice they were there!

text:
I LOVED this recipe! I, however, did do a few things differently, not because I didn't like the recipe as it was, but because of my own personal taste and likes. First, instead of beating the meat, I simply cut it in half the long way. I also seasoned my chicken breast lightly with complete seasoning and black pepper before I placed the ham and cheese ontop and folding edges. Also I added the heavy cream along with the wine and boullion and let it simmer like that for 30 minutes, then used that sauce to pour over the chicken. I like the consistency of my sauce once it was finished so I felt no need to add cornstarch. Thanks for a terrific recipe. Hubby, and 6 year old twins loved it!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/371835.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It can be tough to find a recipe that Everyone in the house likes...but this did it! :) I made a couple changes in my efforts to assure this...after pounding the breasts thin and rolling them with the ham and cheese, I coated them in Panko bread crumbs that I'd seasoned as directed. Browned them on all sides, then put them in a 350 oven for 20 minutes. I made the sauce separate, as directed, except that I added some garlic and Parmesan cheese. The breading of the chicken and keeping the sauce separate was done to keep the kids happy. They did put a little sauce on the side. Served with with rice pilaf and steamed broccoli. Was a big hit and I'll definitely make it again! :)

text:
The first time I made this we thought the chicken was better than the sauce. I doubled the sauce and froze it and I wasn't sure when I would use it or what I would use it for. This morning before work, I browned pork chops and put them in the crock pot with some potatoes and onions and poured the thawed sauce over all. (I normally add cream of mushroom soup.) I had about 2 cups of the leftover sauce and then I added about 1/2 to 1 cup of milk and cooked on low for about 9 hours. It turned out AMAZING! The sauce was WAY better the second time around! Now I am so excited to make the sauce again! Definitely double the sauce and try this! Next time it will be made for company!

Display Name:
lostlittlefairy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/75970.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this dish! Inexpensive but looks like you went all out! I followed the recipe to exactly the first time around but the second time I made it I did decrease the amount of butter used since it made the sauce look a little greasy at the end. As for the chicken, I dipped it in several layers of egg and the flour mixture. I omitted the whipping cream since it gave the sauce a funky look and used plain ole whole milk. The cornstarch is what really thickens the sauce anyhow. Also, when I set the chicken aside, I put it in a pyrex dish and poured the sauce over it and then topped with more swiss cheese before popping it in the oven for about ten minutes or until the cheese was nice and bubbly. One of my favorite dishes to make now!

text:
Thanks for the great recipe! I changed a few things: browned the chicken in the pan, then transferred to the oven to finish off for 25minutes while I made the sauce in the same pan that the chicken was browned in (by adding 4tbs butter and 2tbs flour to make a paste, then 2 cups chicken broth and 1/2 cup wine, allowing to reduce and thicken for 20minutes, then adding the cream and seasoning with garlic powder, salt, and pepper) Will make again! :)

This was excellent! It was the first time I've ever made Cordon Bleu and I was very impressed with how it turned out.  The chicken was very tender and moist. The sauce had a wonderful flavor and was a great compliment to the chicken. The only change that I made (as someone suggested) was that I used a mixture of 3 TBSP of Extra Virgin Olive Oil along with 3 TBSP of butter rather than just 6 TBSP of butter to brown the chicken. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly as stated. Thanks for the great recipe!

None
text:
This recipe was great. The sauce was terrific. I made some modifications due to a wine allergy and to use what I had on hand. I used shake-n-bake garlic flavored for the coating on the chicken and I also cooked it as most other people on this page by browning both sides then baking @ 350 for 20 minutes. I made the sauce seperate. I used chicken stock in place of the wine and still used the boullion cube and added fresh parsley. My fiancee said it was his favorite sauce and even put it on his mashed potatoes. It was soooo good. I will be using the recipe often and passing it aong to friends. FYI----- dont use colored tooth picks to secure the chicken. It colored the surounding chicken when I removed them. I thought it would help me find them easier but ended up being just as hard.

text:
My french boyfriend saw me coating the chicken with flour, and asked me why I wasnt using bread crumbs. He explained to me that here in France, cordon bleu is considered a meal for children, frozen and pre-prepared that they serve for school lunches. I realized I have never seen this dish offered in a restaurant here! but how can that be, because it turned out so good... my boyfriend said his friends would never believe a cordon bleu could be served as a great homecooked meal. I also baked in the oven after browning in butter and olive oil for 20 minutes at 180celcius, its much cleaner and better appearing that way, and you can be sure it turns out cooked through. The toothpicks held in pretty good after all. I made the sauce separately.

text:
This a really good recipe.  I took one reviewer's advice by browning the chicken, then baking @ 350 until no longer pink.  I think doing that kept the chicken nice and moist.  Because I baked the chicken, I made the sauce separately.  I melted about a tsp of butter then whisked in the remaining ingredients & simmered.  I bought a package of 4 chicken breasts, so my husband and I each had leftovers for lunch.  The sauce tasted even better the next day!! Delicious!

text:
This dish was awesome. I have made other Cordon Bleu's before that were okay but this is by far the best. I did make a few changes though. I spread dijon mustard on the chicken with the swiss cheese and I used prosciutto instead of regular ham. I also sprinkled parsley and black pepper in with the flour and paprika. I sauteed it on the stove top in olive oil and baked it for the last 20 minutes. When the chicken was done baking, I put the chicken on a plate and made the gravy in the pan on the stove top. Absolutely delicious!

text:
I made this for the first time for a dinner party for 30. It was fantastic!! I prepped all the chicken the day before and used the butcher twine as suggested. On the day of the party, I dipped the chicken in bread crumbs and browned it in a skillet and then placed in a 9x13 to finish in the oven for about 20 minutes. I used what was left in the skillet and added the other stuff for the sauce. I used Root Cabernet Sauvignon wine. It was delicious!! I highly suggest using a meat thermometer because when I cut my first chicken open I was really worried that it was pink but everyone else said it was from the ham. Delicious. I can't wait to make this again!

userID:

Display Name:
erindipity
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/177162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never had Chicken Cordon Bleu before and WOW! I am glad that I finally decided to try it.  I did however change it up a bit because of other reviews. I rolled the chicken up as directed, then rolled in flour, egg and then bread crumbs. I browned them on all sides in butter (in a pan that I could transfer to oven.) Topped with 1 more slice each of ham and Swiss cheese, poured in about 1/8 cup of chicken broth and baked in 375 degree oven for 20 minutes.   While they were finishing in the oven I took 4 tablespoons of butter and 3 tablespoons of flour and cooked the flour for 1 minute. Added 3/4 can of low sodium chicken broth, 1/4 cup of milk, a pinch of nutmeg and made gravy.  I didnt serve the chicken with the gravy on top, I let everyone do that themselves. The chicken was juicy, tender and done to perfection! Thanks SO MUCH for a great base recipe that I will use for many  years to come!!!

OMG - this is sooooooooo good.  I followed this recipe exactly and it was awesome.  So tasty, and so easy.  I purchased thin chicken filets instead of pounding the chicken - and I'm sure that made it a lot easier - so I encourage people to do that to save time and mess.  Try this - you will love it!  It reheats well too for leftovers.  I searved it with scalloped potatoes the first time, and with alfredo noodles for leftovers.

text:
These were awesome!!!  I love CCB and these were great.  The sauce was wonderful; I added fresh mushrooms halfway through cooking the chicken.  I fixed brown rice and used the sauce w/ mushrooms for it. Also - I did pound the chx breasts down to about 1/4-1/2 inch.  I rolled them instead of simply folding in half.  Also I didn't use wine because I was out - so I used chx broth.  I'm making this again tonight and using white wine - I think the sauce will be even better! (If that's even possible)  Make this recipe - you won't regret it.

text:
This was fantastic. My only change was I used 3 tablespoons butter and 3 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil.  I agree with an earlier review that this kept the butter from burning.  I found it difficult to remove the picks after cooking, maybe I'll try to tie them next time. Everything else was perfect.  I will definitely make this again.  Update - I used kitchen string to tie the rolls, and it is definately easier than trying to remove the pick. Just a little snip with the kitchen shears, and the string is easily removed.

text:
I liked this recipe quite a bit.  The key is to definitely double the sauce or there won't be enough and without the sauce, it really isn't much.  I wish I would have used a thinner slice of ham as it turned out rather chewy and at first, I thought the chicken wasn't done.  I ended up tying the chicken AND using toothpicks;  dipped in egg and breaded in Panko as others had suggested.  Fried a bit in the skillet until brown and popped into the oven (made the sauce on the stove)  The problem was finding the darned strings under the Panko and when I tried to pull them off, the breading came off with it.  Really a good recipe for something a bit different.  Thanks!

text:
I prepared this pretty much as the recipe said, but added some seasoned bread crumbs, about a tablespoon to the flour and paprika. I dredged the rolled chicken breasts in egg and then in the flour mixture.  I cooked it for the 30 minutes, perfect timing!  I then prepared the sauce as you said but just before pouring it over the chicken I added a tablespoon or so of prepared Pesto!!  Delicious!!  Oh yes, one more thing, as I took the meat out of the pan onto a warming dish, I scooped up the melted swiss cheese and drizzled it over each breast....waste not, want not!!!

Display Name:
Jonah's Mom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/11148.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made a few chicken cordon bleu recipes before, but this is my first try with a sauce.  I used a filet to butterfly my chicken breasts.  After reading reviews, I folded my swiss slices into quarters before completely encasing them in ham slices - slightly labor intensive, but not time consuming.  My hope was not to have "cheese leakage," and it worked pretty well.  I only lost a few blobs of cheese during the cooking process.  Instead of flour and paprika, I used Wondra, which I prefer the texture of.  I didn't have dry white wine on hand, but I used white cooking wine, which seemed to work okay.  I also used lite cream instead of heavy, and perhaps that is the reason I needed to add an extra tablespoon of cornstarch for it to be thickened to my liking.  My father and I loved it - my mom just thought it was "okay."  She said it was "too *something*" (I think she meant salty) but could not put her finger on it.  I will make this again (when mom isn't home :)

Made this last night... the best!  I never had chicken cordon bleu before so I didn't know what it was suppose to taste like; however, I've seen the stuff in the frozen food section.  
This does not have the thick starchy coating so it's perfect for the low carb/Atkins folks.  I didn't have ham so I used canadian bacon - fantastic! I used the Atkins baking mix instead of flour (higher fiber I guess).  Even with all the alterations - it was perfect!

text:
I made this chicken cordon bleu for my family for Valentine this year and it was a great hit!  All of our five kids and my husband loved it.  I personally like my chicken to be crispy so I cooked it in the 350 degree oven for about 35 minutes after browning both side on frying pan.  I did cut down on butter by half.  As other reviews said, I thought the sauce was a little salty, too.  So I added a little extra milk and cream at the end.  You will end up with a lot of sauce, but you can use it over pasta or something.  I will make this recipe again!

text:
I'm giving this four stars because the recipe turned out really well.  I browned the chicken bundles in an electric skillet and then put them in a 9x13 to bake for about 25 minutes.  I made the sauce w/ the drippings in the skillet and it turned out really well instead of simmering the chicken.  But I have to whine a little about having to handle and pound the chicken to get it thin enough to wrap the cheese and ham. Ewww slime-y!  The weekend after I made these I noticed that there were pre-packaged chicken breasts already sliced super thin right in the local grocery--that might be just perfect for this recipe...maybe next time.

text:
This was SOOOO good!  I eliminated the flour & cornstarch to make it low-carb, used proscuitto instead of ham, and added more wine than called for (pinot grigio).  This was a HUGE hit at my dinner party with the girls.  When the chicken breasts were fully cooked, I removed them from the pan, added some "Thicken/Thin Not Starch" stuff to thicken before adding half and half.  I will definitely be making this one again and again.

text:
Definitely a keeper! I cut the butter amount in half and used half & half instead of cream to reduce the calories and used more paprika because I love the color. I'm not adept at securing chicken with toothpicks so I pounded the breasts flat, put the ham and cheese on one side then folded the chicken over the top and secured with just 1 toothpick. I doubled the wine and cream to make extra sauce because we served this over rice. Boyfriend and I both loved this dish and made for great leftovers.

text:
My husband and I enjoyed this recipe immensely.  It's very easy to make and tastes better than those at a restaurant.
I scaled the recipe for two people and then doubled the sauce.  At the same time you add the white wine I added a teaspoon of minced garlic.  Next time I'll add a little less as it seemed a little too garlicy.  I did not have heavy whipping cream so I used half and half instead.  Was just as good!  Next time I won't make it with so much butter either, just to try and get it a little less fattening.  All in all, a great recipe!

text:
Loved it! Much easier to prepare than it looks...the hardest part is getting the edges of breasts toothpicked together..I recommend pinning along the edge sideways like a running stitch (use round toothpicks, which have a smoother surface)this will keep the toothpicks from getting in the way too much when you are browning them . Great dish!

text:
Fablous company fare.  I pounded the chicken breats to an even 1/2" to make them easier to stuff and reduce the cooking time down to 20 minutes.  I used a Black Forest no-water added ham.  After breading the chicken, I let it rest in the fridge for 1 hour.  This really helps the coating stick on.  I served the sauce on the side for those watching their fat intake and even without the sauce everyone thought it was fantastic.

None
text:
I'm a college student and it's the end of the term, and I'm trying to use up the stuff I have in the fridge. I made tons of small changes and it was still very good. I substituted chicken breast with leg, swiss cheese with pulled-apart ficello cheddar cheese, ham with small turkey+chicken+ham slices, flour with cornstarch, paprika with bbq chicken seasoning, wine with mirin (sweetened wine) and cream with low-calorie soy milk. These changes didn't affect the taste much, except for the soy milk. It had a weird nutty flavour, so if you have to substitute the cream, go with milk, NOT soy milk.

The sauce was excellent.  I sprinkled paprika on the chicken and then coated it with flour and fried it in oil in a cast iron skillet until nicely browned on both sides. text:
I've never made Chicken Cordon Bleu before so this was a first attempt.  It turned out much better than I thought it would.  The only recommendation I would make would be to add a slice of swiss cheese to the top of it after taking it out of the skillet.  To keep it warm and melt the cheese just a bit while preparing the cream, place it in a warm oven until the cream is done.

text:
A lot of work, but worth it. Absolutely one of the best chicken dishes I have made. The sauce was delicious beyond words. I recommend using high quality cold cuts. I used Boars Head Black Forrest ham. For the coating I did the flour, egg, and bread crumbs that other people recommended. One thing I would do differently the next time: I would not pound the chicken breasts so much. It made them too thin to hold the toothpicks.

None
text:
This was a crowd pleaser!  I tripled the recipe, as we had 11 folks to feed, ranging in age from 6-69.  Several requests were made for the recipe and I sent the link on earlier today.

I followed the recipe and the suggestion of others to bake the chicken rather than cook it in the wine/boullion sauce.  I also used string rather than toothpicks to hold the chicken rolls together.  Created two versions, as we had one member of the group with gluten issues.  Used breadcrumbs on one set and gluten free flour & paprika on the others.  

I will definitely make this again and will try to freeze some too!  For a quick weeknight meal.

This was my first time making this and it was Awesome.. Delicious.. I did make some adjustments. I used sandwich sliced ham ( black forest ham),  I used chicken broth instead of wine and I baked the chicken after browning it for about 10 minutes and adding the chicken broth. text:
When my boyfriend requested I make chicken cordon bleu for him, I very reluctantly agreed as I've never cared for the dish.  Oh boy am I glad I gave it a shot!  I've now made this dish over a dozen times now and IT.IS.AMAZING!  

As others have said, you'll want to double the sauce.  I use chardonnay for the wine and chicken broth in place of the bouillon granules as I think bouillon makes it a bit too salty.  I increased the Swiss to 1.5 slices and blue cheese to the center.  Try it, you won't regret it!

text:
I only made 2 chicken breasts worth and the full amount of sauce since it's just me and my husband and I love saucy stuff.  I'm glad there was extra sauce-YUM!  I don't know much about "dry white wine" so thankfully I saw in another review that said to use Sauvignon Blanc which tasted really good.  1/2 cup is barely any out of the bottle so I would suggest looking for those little individual bottles if you don't plan of drinking the rest.  I added 1 tbsp of bread crumbs and a little garlic powder to the coating and ended up using most of the coating on just the 2 so I don't think it would cover 6 very easily.  overall VERY good and I plan on making again.

text:
I made this recipe as written. I used about 3 tbsp butter and a little olive oil when I noticed the butter was starting to brown. This was soooo good. Next time, I might wrap the cheese in the ham and freeze for a half hour before I roll it into the chicken. I didn't really get a sense of the cheese because it melted too much. My husband was totally impressed. I used 2 chicken breasts which I sliced in half and then pounded to about 1/2 inch thick. I used thin sliced Black Forest Ham and some sort of baby swiss because I was afraid husband wouldn't care for Swiss. Next time I will just use Swiss. I have a feeling I will be making this often. Served with simple mashed potato and roasted string beans.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7050164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just a tip for everyone who want to save time with butterflying & pounding the chicken breast..

Make sure you are using large enough breats, 7 or 8 oz each.  Put the chicken in the freezer for about 20 - 25 minutes, so they firm up.  Cut a pretty deep slit in the fatter side of the breast - do not go from end to end, leave about 1/2" on each end uncut.

To prevent the cheese from melting out, roll the cheese inside the ham slices and stuff this into the slit in the breast.  You may want to insert 2 of these rolls into each breast.

Hope this helps & happy cooking!

userID:
12304799
Display Name:
MamiChula
isPro:

8
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1067039.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great! My husband is a diabetic, and we are all supporting his new low carb diet. I am constantly on the look out for recipes to please everyone. This was great. I used two large breasts, cut in half lengthwise to give four portions (two adults and three kids under 10). I pounded them as thin as possible, which wasnt that much. I put 2.5T flour and 1t seasoning salt in a ziplock. I put the breasts in that to coat them lightly. I seared one side in equal parts butter and EVOO. Then I placed 1t cream cheese down the middle of the breast, chopped up ham pieces, and 1T shredded cheddar. I didnt have any toothpicks so I placed them in the small pan seam side down. I sauted some sliced portabella mushrooms, added 0.5c chicken stock, and 1/3c heavy cream. I added some S&P, garlic powder, and 1t dijon mustard. Cooked it for about a minute before pouring that over the chicken. I covered w foil and baked at 350F for 20 min. I let it rest for 10 mins. It was divine. Thanks, definitely a keeper!

Used this as inspiration with a few changes: dredged in the paprika seasoned flour, then egg wash, lastly seasoned breadcrumbs before browning. Added a minced shallot to the skillet, deglazed with wine, added cream and reduced to a rich sauce, no need for cornstarch. Finished the rolls in a 350 oven. Delicious and brought back wonderful food memories. Served with rice and baby spinach leaves lightly dressed. Thanks for this!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is Heaven on a plate. I've made it a few a times now. The first time I followed the recipe to a T and it was wonderful but since then I've tweaked it to my personal preferences. The best advice I can give is to double up on the sauce, it's incredible! I've used wine and chicken broth and it's great both ways but the wine is definitely my favorite. I like to prepare the sauce separate from the chicken and finish the chicken off in the oven but yet again it's great both ways. I also use an egg wash on the chicken before rolling the chicken in flour which I add a bit of garlic and onion powder to as well as the paprika. I've tried bread crumbs but prefer it with the flour. Lastly, a bit of Dijon mustard on the chicken before adding the ham and cheese is really good! This is a great recipe and fun to make your own and it's a huge crowd pleaser!

text:
As another review suggested I sauted the chicken to brown it and baked at 350 for 20 minutes.  I made the sauce in the same pan while the chicken was baking.  I substituted olive oil for butter to cut down on the fat.  My husband is watching his calorie intake and at chicken without the sauce and found it was delicious.  The sauce is just a caloric overkill; a very delicious overkill.
Very easy and I will make this again.

text:
Well, not that this needs another glowing review, but it truly is scrumptious! And for how elegant it presents, I think it's a pretty simple and fairly quick recipe to prepare. To lighten it up a bit I do reduce the butter to 2 Tablespoons and add a bit of olive oil when browning the chicken rolls. I also use bread crumbs in place of the flour when coating, chicken broth in place of the wine and I use skim milk in place of the cream. It comes out super moist and delicious but much lighter calorie-wise.

text:
Like many others, I'm not a fan of those who rate recipes based on their OWN creations so I'm rating this as a 5-star as is BUT...as an RD, I'm adding healthful changes I made the 2nd time I made this awesome recipe that my family agrees doesn't take away from the wonderful flavors but will safe you calories, fat that aren't necessary.  (1) use shaved deli ham - no flavor change but less sodium, calories & fat and much easier to roll. (2) used 2Tbsp. whipped butter and 2 Tbsp olive oil for a blend that allows for higher heat, and less saturated fat and added the heart healthy mono fat.  (3) substituted lite coconut milk for the whipping cream saving calories, fat but with same great richness with all the same sinful goodness this dish has to offer.  thanks for sharing.

text:
Amazing. I think this has been my husband's favorite--I'm a new cook and he's a tough critic. 
I followed the directions with these modifications:
-sauteed the breasts (which i didn't hammer out but cut in halves since they were so big) in butter first--for about 15 minutes
-then stuffed breasts with cheese and ham, brushed with 2 raw eggs and bread crumbs, added sauce to dish and baked for 25 minutes
-used cream vs. whipping cream--was still great
-used almond meal instead of flour for the sauce
-*used Pinot Grigio, pretty good flavor
Will definitely put this on my cooking STAPLES list!

userID:
9734270
Display Name:
Katedutch
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing with a few adjustments. 

I lined a baking dish with tin foil for easy clean up and then combined about 1C Italian bread crumbs with 1 tbsp grapeseed oil and 1 tbsp white cooking wine. I stirred until breadcrumbs were lightly moistened and then covered bottom of baking dish. I then followed the directions for pounding chicken, laid a couple slices of ham (I used my own leftovers rather than deli meat), and used shredded swiss rather than slices (just what I had on hand). I didn't seal with toothpick as it wasn't necessary, just laid on the dish, open end down. I then lightly patted the top of chicken with more grapeseed oil and poured about 1/2C breadcrumbs over the top. I closed up the tinfoil and baked at 350 for 20 minutes. After that time, I opened the tin foil, drizzled a little more oil over the top & baked for another 10 minutes (sprinkled shredded swiss over the top for last 3 minutes).

As for the sauce, BEFORE putting chicken in oven, in a saucepan I combined 1C white cooking wine with about 2 tsp seasoned boullion granules over medium heat. I let that heat up, meanwhile combining 1 1/2 C heavy cream with 1 tbsp corn starch in a bowl. I then slowly added the cream mixture to the pot, stirring constantly with a fork. After thickened, I set aside. When meal was just about done,  I heat up again over medium and added two large dollops of sour cream, stirring until combined. It was DELICIOUS!

text:
Minority opinion: my husband and I both found this to be a little below average, especially when compared with other recipes on this site. Our main complaint was that the chicken was bland and the sauce, while okay, was not as good as other similar sauces.  In fairness, we did follow the suggestions of other reviewers as follows:  1.  we pounded the breasts to less than 1/2 inch.  2.  we wrapped the cheese inside 2 slices of ham such that the cheese did not leak out.  3.  we purposely did not use a salty ham so that was not an issue.  4.  we spread a very thin layer of Dijon inside the breast.  5.  we did flour, then egg wash, then panko which we think did improve the coating.  6.  we browned then finished baking in the oven so the chicken was tender.  7.  we added a fair amount of sauce to the taste as it was so bland as well as a pinch of garlic 8.  we doubled the sauce as we like sauce and also planned to use some of the sauce on fresh roasted asparagus.  So, while not following the original recipe exactly, we feel we gave it as fair a shot as we could for our tastes.  Perhaps we've become a little spoiled by other recipes on this site or perhaps our expectations were too high.  Still, we were quite disappointed.  We won't be making this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this meal, it is now my favorite, used to be rib eye steaks but now I prefer this dish.  I can make it so fast only 40 min start to finish.  I don't get carried away flattening and rolling the chicken, I simply butterfly the chicken breasts, bread them on one side, fry them in the butter for about 3 minutes, then take them out and place plenty of good smoked ham, and Swiss cheese inside, the open uncooked side, fold the breast back together and throw it in a 350 degree oven for 25 minutes, then add the cream sauce.  So simple, and the presentation is just fine.  I see other photos where I think other people do the same thing.  I also see many people saying the cheese is all melted out.  If you do not over cook the chicken, which I think many people do, you will only lose just a small amount onto the bottom of the pan.  Basically when you see the cheese oozing out, you know it's ready.  Enjoy!

text:
The best ever but I did make a few changes, Instead of the flour mix I brushed the outside of chicken with egg and sprinkled on Progressive Italian bread crumb then fried them with the butter, bouillon, and wine until I saw no pink, after I removed them from the juices and baked them at 350 for 15 minutes to insure theres no pink. I added fresh mushrooms to the wine mixture and drippings. Once cooked I proceeded with the whipping creme and cornstarch. I made this with pesto pasta, grilled asparagus and bread with butter. Picture 146. =)

The flavors were all there, but I actually did not enjoy this recipe as much as other baked chicken cordon bleu recipes.  The chicken wouldn't cook evenly and by the time it was cooked, the swiss managed to escape and burn in the pan, so I wasn't able to make a sauce.  If I try this recipe again, I will definitely choose to oven bake it and skip stovetop.

text:
This was fabulous and fairly easy. After reading some of the other reviews, after rolling up the chicken with ham & swiss, I dipped in flour with paprika, then egg, then bread crumbs. Then I browned in a pan with butter for about 6 minutes turning it to get all sides and baked at 350 for 15 minutes. I think it was slightly overdone, but not too bad. Next time I will bake for less. I served with red potatoes and green beans and my husband loved it! Will def make again! Sauce was yummy! Didn't have cream so used milk and butter with wine and cornstarch as another reviewer suggested.

text:
I scaled down the recipe to 3 servings. I used a little more flour than called for, added in garlic salt and black pepper. I used chicken broth instead of the wine which I doubled and didn't use the bouillon cube. The amount of butter was unnecessary and scaled that down a tad. To get a good role on the chicken the breasts must be pounded very thin. I gave it four stars because I thought the measurements and seasonings were a little off. This recipe is very easy and oh so good. Yummm....

text:
This was absolutely delicious.  We just had leftovers tonight and hubby is still raving about it.  Only thing that I did differently was to cook the chicken on the stove for 20 minutes and then put it on a cookie sheet that I covered with foil (easier clean-up), then into the oven at 400 degrees for about 10 minutes, while preparing the sauce and sides.  I also used 1/2 butter and 1/2 olive oil when preparing the chicken on the stove.  This is definitely 'company worthy' chicken!

text:
This recipe blew me away! My husband and I both enjoyed it immensely, and it has become our default "company" dish. Apparently my father-in-law couldn't stop talking about it for days, and several other friends have asked for the recipe! After reading a few other reviews, I decided to bake the chicken at 350 for 20 minutes after browning it in the skillet, adding the butter from the pan straight into the baking dish with the chicken. I make the sauce separately by combining white Zinfandel and chicken bouillon and bringing it to a simmer before adding the cornstarch/cream mixture. The chicken and sauce come out perfectly each time!

This was a great recipe, but l put my chicken in the oven after l browned it on the stove.  I made the cream sauce in a sauce pan while the chicken was in the oven.  I used UNSALTED butter and it made a huge difference in the taste of the sauce!! (bad - tasted like clam water) This sauce should Always be made with SALTED butter!!  (After adding salt & a few other seasonings it was good)

text:
All I can say is Wow. Chicken Cordon Bleu is my favorite meal and also a favorite of my husband's. I saw this recipe and thought it would be nice to try something just a tad different. I am so glad that I did. The only changes I made was that I used Panko Breadcrumbs instead of flour to make it a little more crispy and replace 1/2 cup of wine with 1/2 cup of chicken broth since my husband can't take a chance of having any alcohol in his system for work. I was told that I was not able to make this any other way than this way any more.

country:
None
text:
This deserves every bit of five stars. It's a fantastic recipe and very quick and easy to make. One suggestion: do not use toothpicks to secure the meat; they are impossible to remove after cooking. I will use string instead next time. This is a perfect casual dinner party main course.
Update: I've made this a lot since my last review. I now use kitchen string to secure the meat, and criss cross it like  you would a boxed gift. It works perfectly and keeps all of the filling in really well. This is one of my favorites. I serve it with mashed potatoes and a green vegetable.

text:
This was a very good and easy recipe.  Next time I will use cooking string instead of toothpicks.  I added  a seasoned buttermilk and egg mixture dip and dusted with flour and Panko.
Since the chicken had a crust, when I covered it for 20 minutes, the crust became moist.  But is was still good with the sauce.  And as some others suggested, I used chicken broth instead of wine.
All in all, it was a nice dish.  My daughter cut into hers and said..."Wowwww, mine has a surprise in it!!!"

text:
best cordon bleu recipe-ever! a few modifications were made - used half slice of swiss and a half slice of provolone, used virginia baked ham, didn't have paprika-just salt & pepper, i wanted extra sauce to use with side rice side dish, so i used 1 c of wine and 1 knorr chicken boul. cube in 1 c of h20, used half and half for cream and increased amount as well. served roasted asparagus as the other side. 2 adults & 3 kids loved it!

text:
Wow! Great recipe! I prepped the chicken to the recipe, except I browned in a pan, then put in oven for 30 minutes covered with foil in a greased casserole tray. I made the sauce right after, and then poured over the chicken and waited the remaining time. The wine made the sauce. I hate to repeat what everyone else is saying, but the sauce is just 100% delicious. I paired this recipe with a Garlic, Basil, Parmesan Angel Hair Pasta. I even put just a bit of the sauce when making the pasta. My girlfriend said this was the best, and her favorite meal, I've made for her. So this recipe will for sure go in the rotation (and the sauce, I will use for other dishes in the future also). The only thing I wished I would have done differently was to reduce the sauce a bit more, no biggie. Good eats!

This was my first time attempting Chicken Cordon Blue with my husbands help.  We used Chicken stock instead of White Wine thanks to another reviewer. My tip would be to make sure you have a good brand of tooth picks on hand. We used a no name brand and they kept breaking, I'm sure that's a no brainer but we wanted to use what we had on hand and found out the hard way. Loved this, I will use it again.

text:
I made this last week for my boyfriend and it turned out perfectly! I served it with a baby green salad and the meal was one of the best we've had in awhile. He told me and has kept telling people in conversation that it is no lie the best Chicken he has ever had, and that's not his "boyfriend biased opinion"-it's genuinely good! And I agree! The sauce made  at the end was perfect because the heavy whipping cream and the corn starch was mixed in the pan with all the leftover juices from cooking the chicken. It was a good combination  of flavor, and a simple way to make the sauce. Also, this recipe is healthier than some (although the heavy whipping cream ads fat) and I didn't finish the meal feeling guilty for eating it. I felt very satisfied!

This isn't the easiest thing to make, but now that I've made it more than once, things go by quicker and easier.  I put the chicken breasts into a zip-lock baggie that has the air pushed out and pound them that way to avoid showering my kitchen with chicken juices.  The sauce for this is AMAZING.  I usually serve it with steamed asparagus drizzled with the sauce. Everyone who's eaten this at my house has been truly amazed at how good it is.  In fact, a very rich relative of mine who is always eating at fancy-smancy resturants swore it was the best he's ever had.

text:
This was an amazing Cordon Bleu recipe! The wine sauce completely complements the meal. I pounded my chicken uber thin and placed grated swiss cheese long the full breast. I then placed sandwich slice thickness ham slices and cut them to the shape of the chicken. I was able to roll these fairly thick, but I loved the ratio of chicken/cheese/ham. Another suggestion -- make extra and wrap them in syran wrap tightly as is! Then all you have to do is defrost, brown and make the sauce for another meal. It freezes really well!

Review:
Rating:

helpfulCount:
2
userID:
830188
Display Name:
Simplifying Things
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
38
favoritesCount:
507
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think Julia Child would cringe at my version of this dish but technically it is what it is called.  I gave up pounding after the first breast!  Flatten the breast w/ your hand evenly on a cutting board and slice the breast (horizontally) in half.  (You might need more cheese and ham doing it this way.)  Place a slice of cheese and then ham on top (it will probably be 1/2 a slice since it's not pounded) and roll up, putting a toothpick through the middle.  Place them in a baking dish and bake at 350 for 30 min.  (Skipping the flouring and browning step.) While baking, mix the wine, bouillon, and whipping cream w/ cornstarch in a saucepan until slightly thickened.  (After reading the reviews, I automatically doubled the sauce!)  Poured some of the sauce over the chicken after baking and return to oven for another 5-10 min.  This was another yummylicious dish!    Fewer carbs, calories, and gluten free, provided that you use a gluten free bouillon, when made this way without sacrificing taste!  Bon Appetit!

Rating:
5

LOVED the recipe.  I rated it 4 stars because like other reviewers, I changed the way it was prepared.  I tied with butcher twine instead of toothpicks.  After I browned the chicken, I baked it in 350 oven for 30 min.  Before it was done cooking in a saucepan I melted butter and added wine and bouillon, then whisked in the cornstarch/cream mixture-cooked til bubbly.  I sliced the chicken,put on serving platter  and poured the sauce over and garnished with parsley.  Cooking as recommended would have indeed increased the amount of fat.

text:
Just made last night.  Absolutely delicious.  Pounded the breast to even thickness, about 1/2 inch. Filled as directed, drenched in flour, browned on both sides for 7 minutes in cast iron skillet and finished cooking the chicken in 350 degree oven in 15-20 minutes.  Removed chicken to a plate, kept warm.  Added wine and bouillon to pan. Simmered for 3 minutes, then finished with the cream and let that thicken.  Wow!  I can not encourage you enough to try this recipe.  I would feel so proud to serve this to family and company.  Thank you so much for posting!!

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super yummy! My husband and my son loved this recipe. I pounded the chicken breasts flat and placed the ham and cheese slices on the flatten breast. Then I rolled each breast up and secured with a couple of toothpicks. I dipped the chicken in a beaten egg before rolling in flour. I used margarine instead of butter to brown the chicken just because I didn't have any butter. I was a little worried the cheese would melt and all run out of the chicken roll-up, but only a tiny bit did. I used a meat thermometer to check for doneness and they were done a few minutes sooner than the recipe states. Fantastic recipe!

text:
I fried the chicken in butter for about 10 minutes until it was nicely browned, then I put it in the oven at 350 for another hour. Instead of simmering the chicken in the sauce, I whisked the cream,wine, bouillon and cornstarch in a bowl, then simmered it with the butter I used to cook chicken for about 10 min.  and spooned it over the chicken. It turned out fantastic!

text:
The addition of the wine sauce really made this an excellent recipe! Fairly easy, though it took longer than 1/2 an hour to cook. The chicken may have been too thick, I suggest taking the advice to pound it very thin. I used long metal picks to hold together while cooking, it seems small wooden ones would have gotten lost in there. Also subbed half&half for the heavy cream, the sauce was still perfect. I served it with broccoli and pasta on the side, everyone loved it!

text:
Wonderful cordon bleu. I have tried a variation on this once with veal, and this is equally as good. The only thing I did differently was remove the chicken after frying and bake it for 20 minutes at 350F as suggested by others, instead of braising it in the wine (my family isn't too fond of "wine-piquant" dishes). It was excellent. :)

text:
so, I thought that it sounded a little easy, and was a little weary of trying it because it didn't have the mushroom/wine sauce. Boy was I wrong. This recipe is awesome, I didn't change a thing, and it was phenomenal. My husband is the one who turned me on to cordon bleu, and he raved about it. I will continue to make this every time he askes for chicken cordon bleu. Just a little advice: Dont over cook the sauce, it starts to separate. And dont worry about the cheese melting out of the chicken, it adds a wonderful flavor to the amazing sauce!!!

text:
This was an exceptional recipe!  I doubled the sauce, this way there was extra to serve over angel hair.  I don't know how people could say it's okay to omit the white wine!  That would be like leaving out sugar in a cake.  The white wine is what makes this recipe!  I also added freshly chopped parsley to the sauce at the end.  Instead of bouillon granules I just added some chicken broth.  And the final change is that after I browned the chicken roll ups, I baked them at 350 for about 15 minutes. Meanwhile I made the sauce and then added the roll ups back to the pan and simmered them in the sauce for 5 or so minutes.

country:
None
text:
Spectacular recipe!  The trick to this one is using extra large chicken breasts and pounding them to an even 1/2" thickness.  This does take a little time but worth it!  If you do this and roll them tightly no toothpics are necessary to fasten and should not unroll when pan frying them.  This also allows just enough cheese to seap into the sauce and when sliced through gives a perfect spiral of cheese and ham.  Garnish with fresh basil or parsley.  Perfection!  My husband even ate this for breakfast the next day...

text:
This recipe was fabulous!  My entire family raved about it and it was extremely delicious.  I cooked it almost exactly as in the recipe.  The only change I made was to fry the chicken in the pan for a few minutes on each side to brown them and then transferred them to the oven to bake.  I then made the sauce in the pan I seared the chicken in.  That way the Atkins folks in the family could just have the chicken.  The chicken came out very tender and the taste was amazing!  The sauce was also to die for.  I was very very pleased by this recipe.

Awesome!  This will be a family favorite.  Additionally, I flattended the chicken breasts with a mallet, which makes the chicken a bit sticky and works to your advantage.  I also prepared the chicken rolls 2 hrs prior to cooking and refigerated.  This method allowed me to remove the toothpicks prior to coating with flour mixture.  I added one toothpick back to the middle and removed it during cooking.  The chicken browns beautifully and the accompanying sauce is just devine.

text:
This recipe turned out good, and was pretty easy.  I did modify it somewhat.  I cut a slit in the the chicken breasts to stuff them.  I used Prosciutto for the ham because it was super flaverful even in a thin slice.  I made the sauce seperate simmering for aprox. 10 min.  The chicken breasts were seasoned with salt and pepper, floured, egged, and breaded.  Fried till out side was crispy and then baked at 350 to finish them off.  I refregerated the chicken breasts after I fried them for a couple of hours before baking, so I got them messy process of breading/frying them done before my guests arrived and that seemed to work fine, and let me have a clean more orderly kitchen to cook it with people over.

text:
WOW.... This is delicious my only complaint is that I love the sauce so much that there was not enough for my rice :) Now when I fix this recipe I flatten & butterfly the chicken breast (the toothpick method did not work out to well for me & I like for some cheese to seep out which helps create the sauce) to remedy my craving for the sauce I use 1 cup of broth & 2 tsp of chicken granules & 2 cups of creame cook time is anywhere from 50 to 60 min give or take a few. 

***Also note that if you do not have an white wine on hand chicken broth works just as well

I made this for dinner and we really enjoyed it!.  It was easy to make.  I followed some suggestions of others and doubled the sauce.  I also used the half butter/half olive oil to fry the chicken. Wow.  This was incredible!  I didn't have toothpicks so used a  little yarn to tie up the breasts before frying.  I also used half and half and flour to get a thick sauce (I didn't have cream or corn starch) and put it in the frying pan that the chicken had just come out of so it melded really nice with the leftover juice and cheese in the pan.  OMG, it was so freakin' good!  I heated the sauce for about a total of 15 minutes, stirring every 5 minutes or so.  I've never been a big fan of chicken cordon bleu, but this has changed my mind forever!

First let me say this is absolutely delicious!  The only change I made was to use bread crumbs in place of the flour. I also have these cooking rubber band thingies that I'd picked up last Thanksgiving that I used in place of the toothpicks.  That kept the breasts together, but not so tight it was restricting in any way.  Now, this sounds like a pretty intimidating meal that I kept wanting to try but was nervous I'd mess it up but it was actually VERY simple to follow and it came out great.  I'm so proud, it was like a gourmet supper!  Thanks for a wonderful recipe that I'm sure I'll use over and over.
