text:
Fabulous recipe! I took one reviewer's advice and added olive oil to the butter to fry the chicken in- glad I did otherwise I think that the butter would've burnt a little and the chicken would have stuck to the pan. The final sauce with heavy whipping cream and cornstarch (added to the original sauce) never thickened (even with increased cornstarch) but I suspect that was due to the increased butter and olive oil I originally used. Regardless, the recipe made for a delicious meal. Thanks for sharing and bon apetit!

I used a combination of other peoples additions for my try at making this.. I used 1/2 the butter and olive oil for the other half. text:
WOW this was sooooooo good! Instead of the flour, I used bread crumbs, then browned the chicken in the butter...then i put the chicken in a separate pan into the oven (cause i thought if it cooked in the sauce it would get too soggy) meanwhile in the pan i browned the chicken in, I made the sauce and added a little bit of grated Parmesan cheese (which made it even better)....then when the chicken was done I took it out and poured the sauce over it. It was still a little crispy from the bread crumbs and the sauce was just DELICIOUS!!!! This is one of my favorites I've tried on this website. Definitely give this recipe a try you WILL NOT be disappointed. Thanks!!

text:
This recipe is excellent!  It deserves closer to 5 stars than 4, but I did make some tweaks along with other reviewers' suggestions.  I only used 3 chicken breasts because they were large (pounded thin) but didn't change the amounts of anything else.  Used no water added Black Forest ham found in the deli and used premium baby Swiss cheese. Ask the deli to taste the ham and cheese to find what you prefer. Rather than use all butter, I used half extra virgin olive oil and half real butter. Followed the cooking directions exactly, and the chicken was so moist and tender, it melted in our mouths!  I added a little garlic salt to mine once plated; just my preference. Served with fresh steamed asparagus and orzo.  he sauce was great over the orzo! Yum!  Thanks for sharing this excellent recipe!

text:
Absolutely fantastic! I recommend using half butter and half olive oil, as well as Pinot Grigio for the dry white wine. Also, I wrapped the cheese inside the ham and then rolling the breasts versus folding them and the cheese did not leak out. I used Kitchen Twine to tie the breasts, and it was very easy to cut the string before I served them.  I made this for my relatives and everyone practically licked their plate clean! This recipe is a must!

text:
I've always been intimidated by the idea of making chicken cordon bleu. But by hammering the meat so it is thinner, it makes it very easy to fill and fold. The sauce in this recipe is delicious. I am currently watching my carbs so I omitted the flour and the cornstarch and it was still spectacular. If you have never tried chicken cordon bleu, or have been too intimidated to make it, try this one.

WOW... this dish is amazing!!!  One of the best chicken dinners I have ever cooked!  The sauce is extremely RICH, so next time I'd serve this with plain sides like rice and steamed broccoli.  The sauce is so amazing!  The only difference I made was using half butter and half olive oil for frying the chicken.  This dish does take a while to make.  Preparing the chicken (pounding, rolling, toothpick-ing and coating) took me about 45 minutes, but they do cook fast in the pan if you've pounded them thin.  You have to try this!!!

text:
Nice turnout for me.  My family loved the sauce and so did I.  I pounded the chicken down to around 1/2 inch thickness to make it more manageable.  I used a dry California wine which permeated the entire house with the smell of fruits while it was cooking.  I replaced the butter with EVOO, I don't like to cook with butter ever.  With the wine I used a 1/2 cup of chicken broth instead of the granules.  I also did not roll in flour, instead I covered the  breast with egg and then rolled them in bread crumbs. I will definately be using this recipe again.

text:
This was really good.  I also dipped chicken in egg then coated w/ breadcrumbs before frying in pan with a little butter until brown.  I then transferred to oven for 20 min at 350.  I also cooked sauce separately and added 1tsp of Dijon mustard to sauce, I know that is probably not traditional but it gave the sauce a great taste and was an excellent compliment to the dish.  Also, I didn't roll the chicken I just cut the breast to create a "pocket" and stuffed w/ ham and cheese.

This recipe is amazing. I didn't cook the chicken in the sauce as the recipes calls for. Instead, I rolled the chicken, dipped in eggs, and coated with bread crumbs. Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/442663.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a fantastic meal as written. I enjoyed it thoroughly and then made changes like most cooks will do. My changes made this recipe a bit more expensive, but wow. I added a slice of prosciutto inside the chicken with the cheese and ham. I made a slit into the side of the chicken and butterflied it open, then pounded it thin with a meat pounder. To the flour/paprika mixture I added some grated Parmigiano Reggiano.  After filling the chicken and toothpicking it shut, I dipped it in egg whites and then the flour/paprika/Parm. Reg. I would not recommend changing the method of making the sauce as others have. Using wine was perfect and if you don't slowly cook the chicken in the pan that the sauce will be in, all of those wonderful chicken drippings (not to mention any melted cheese that might slip out) will be missing from the sauce. Thank you so much for this amazing recipe.

None
text:
Loved it! I have become a fan of butterflying chicken breasts and using the increased surface area to infuse whatever flavors I'm attempting into all of the meat. I applied this theory to this recipe. I butterflied the breasts and slipped a rolled up ham slice into the breast, flixed in place with the toothpick. I browned them in half butter/ half olive oil with a tbl of minced garlic. I made sure that everything got good and brown so that my sauce had great color and flavor. The ham inside the chicken really made a great recipe greater. Thanks for this. Fine cuisine is less intimidating!

This was a great recipe.  I used boneless skinless chicken thighs instead of breasts, and that worked well.  I also substituted chicken broth for the wine, since I didn't have any.  The only thing that I would change next time is to add a bit of salt and pepper to the sauce and maybe some garlic.  This is a very nice recipe to make for guests, although it took me a while to prepare.  The sauce was also great on our rice and asparagus, instead of plain butter.

text:
My husband and 6 year old son both gave this a two thumbs up--a definite keeper! I added salt & Pepper as I do with everything, used shredded swiss cheese and Hillshire farm deli Select ultra thin honey ham, which my husband said gave it a nice smokey flavor.  I also did as others suggested and used some olive oil with the butter. Used double the wine called for and double the cream, then added more butter (talk about rich!) at the end.  Next time,I might try adding some garlic and or whisking some dijon mustard to the sauce at the end to give it a little more punch.  Personally, I like more flavor in sauces, but I was outvoted.  really yummy, thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made this before Thanksgiving and we didn't really care much for the sauce.  Made this again last night with 2 slices each of prosciutto instead of ham, I seasoned my Chicken with a Chicken spice mixture, assembled, placed in a sprayed baking dish along with butter and wine.  The butter and wine with the drippings made a great juice to drizzle over the chicken and we didn't even miss not having a sauce.  I baked at 350 degrees for about 45 minutes but of course cooking time would depend on the size and thickness you pound the breast.

text:
This recipe is FABULOUS!  I served this for New Year's Eve (a formal dinner) and all 6 of us just LOVED it.  The cream sauce really made the meal.  My husband rarely goes back for second helpings but this time he did without reservation.  And, the meal was impressive to serve as well.  I accompanied the chicken with homemade garlic mashed potatoes and some fresh, seasoned green beans.  I pulled out my formal china, served the green beans in a separate dish and served the chicken on a platter surrounded by the garlic mashed potatoes.  This was a great trick because the potatoes kept the sauce on the platter, while at the same time, the potatoes absorbed some of the sauce - hhmmmmmm...YUMMY!!!  This was a hearty, yet SCRUMPTIOUS meal!  Thank you for the recipe!  This is now a family favorite!

text:
This was very good - I just wish someone could tell me the trick to getting the toothpicks out!  I served the meal with a disclaimer, that my guests needed to take small bites in case I missed one!
Here is what I altered - I browned the rolls in 1/2 butter 1/2 olive oil - to prevent the butter from burning. I used a combo of breadcrumbs and crushed butter crackers - I would have used all breadcrumbs but I had some crushed crackers leftover from something else I was doing. When rolling the breast I put the ham down first then the cheese in an effort to contain the cheese so it wouldn't ooze out (some still did, but it added to the flavor of the sauce)  I will for sure make this again, might try something other then those blasted toothpicks though!

text:
The flavour is wonderful - kinda nutty tasting. Double the sauce recipe - you'll need it. One thing I didn't do and should have is pour off the excess butter after browning the chicken and before I made the sauce. I did like someone else suggested and brushed the stuffed chicken with butter then rolled in flour mixture and let sit for about an hour - then fried. Makes a nice coating. This is by far the best cordon bleu I have ever had - even in fancy restaurants. Thank you for the recipe.

text:
Okay, Chef I am not.  This recipe gave me respect in my house!  lol.  AMAZING!  I followed some suggestions.  I coated the chicken in the morning with the butter, dredged it in flour and paprika.  I had no string so I had to use toothpicks.  The chicken set all day and when I fried it first, I removed the toothpicks.  I didnt even need them when I put it in the oven.  As everyone else says, DOUBLE the sauce recipe!  You will NOT be sorry!  The sauce is what made the meal.  I didnt have any cornstarch and just used flour to thicken it.  I used provolone cheese and tavern ham from the deli.  It was an amazing meal!  I served with plain white rice and what a hit it was!  Don't pass this recipe by....

text:
A perfect dish to serve up for company--it's beautiful and elegant too--looks like a lot more work than it is.  I rolled up the chicken in the morning and stuck it in the fridge until later (I used about a dozen toothpicks in each roll which had to be extracted with pliers after cooking--but at least none of the cheese leaked out!) I followed the recipe exactly and just have one minor change I will make next time: the sauce was just a tad rich and I'm not big on wine flavor so I think I'll cut back on the wine and use 1/2 and 1/2 as some of the other reviewers have suggested. Other than that this was just great--thanks Behr!

text:
Awesome!  I served this dish tonight to company and everyone raved! I loved the idea of folding over the pounded chicken breasts rather than rolling them...it was easier to secure with toothpicks (than rolls), and the chicken cooked more evenly.  I used lite swiss cheese, and proscuitto ham.  In the sauce, I substituted 1/2 & 1/2 (instead of whipping cream) b/c that's what I had on hand, and chose Marsala for the wine, and it was excellent.  I served this with this site's Roasted Vegetables, and Warm Spinach Salad and french bread.  Thanks to Allrecipes.com, I even impress myself lately!  This site rocks!

text:
Pretty yummy, quick & easy! I used chicken broth instead of granules & let the wine & broth simmer together in an uncovered pan to reduce the sauce for a good flavor. Takes about 15 or 20 minutes, but worth the effort in flavor. I doubled the amount of wine & 1 can (14oz.) chicken broth.  This makes plenty of sauce. Even though I made adjustments, all in all a good recipe.

None
text:
Made this tonight and it was great!  I breaded it with half flour and half panko with an egg wash because I know that's what my family likes. I recommend salting the chicken before you bread it.   I think the only change I'll make next time is to use a thicker piece of cheese.  The slices are just too thin and lose their taste.  The recipe calls for dry white wine.  Mine wasn't dry enough and the cream sauce turned out very sweet.  Next time I'll use dry or just substitute with chicken bouillon.  I took the advice of another reviewer and finished them in the oven.  My family loved it and I'll be making it again.

userID:
8422114
Display Name:
Steve Steed
isPro:
False
followersCount:
11
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
79
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2076671.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely restaurant quality. Mixed panko Italian crumbs and regular Italian crumbs after an egg wash. Pounded one large breast thin enough for two portions. Used leftover spiral sliced ham and thick sliced baby Swiss with Dijon mustard.
Tied with string before dipping and coating. Once finished I liberally sprinkled with cayenne and dried parsley.
Straight into a 350 oven for 45 minutes. No need for stovetop browning.
Sauce: melted 3 tblsp butter, bullion, 1 tblsp bacon grease with wine. Added cream and cornstarch slurry with more parsley for color.
Sliced one portion into pinwheels. Perfect for two. Had enough sauce left for another meal with the remaining portion.
Gorgeous, delicious and only 30 minutes total prep. What a winning recipe!

text:
My boys LOVED it! Even my picky eater! The sauce was so delicious, I even drizzled it over the broccoli and that was readily eaten too!  Next time I make this, I'll double up on the sauce and use the leftover as an aioli. 

Word of note: when the sauce appears to be broken you need to keep stirring/whipping it up until it is a smooth consistency. This includes reheating! It seems like it is nothing but butter, but keep whisking it and it becomes a beautiful cream sauce again!

userID:
22255872
Display Name:
newgen87

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really great recipe, but I made some changes.

First, I flattened the chicken to approx 1/2". I then seasoned both sides of the flattened chicken with salt, garlic, pepper, onion powder, and parsley. 

Secondly, I used some honey Dijon mustard on the inside with the ham and cheese. I lightly spread it around. I then rolled the chicken with the ham and cheese and used butchers twine to hold it closed. I used egg wash and coated the rolled chicken in bread crumbs.

I then heated 3 tablespoons of butter and 3 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet and fried each side until brown. I then transferred the chicken to the oven at 350 for 25 minutes.

At this time I used 3 tablespoons of butter, 1/2 cup of wine(sauvignon blanc), 1 teaspoon of chicken boullion and put them in a sauce pan. I mixed the heavy cream and cornstarch until smooth and added to the sauce pan. Cooked until boiling whisking constantly until desired thickness was reached. Remove from heat and let rest while waiting on chicken to finish. 

Sauce can be poured on top of chicken or served on the side.

Served with steamed broccoli and a poppyseed dressing spinach salad with tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers, and feta cheese. 

A new favorite and excellent presentation!

None
text:
I love this recipe. Relatively quick to prepare, not too tricky, and really tasty. I added some salt, pepper and garlic to the flour and paprika as suggested by previous reviewers. I had a little trouble rolling the chicken, ham and cheese but did okay with the help of lots of toothpicks. I browned the rolled chicken lightly as directed, using butter and olive oil, and had almost no cheese leaks. I kept the temp really low after I added the wine and again, no cheese leaks. Cooked for about 30 minutes. I made a little extra sauce because, well, sauce. Right?  I used cheap cooking wine and spiked it with a splash  of lemon juice and a dash of cayenne pepper. My company was late so I kept the meat in the oven and the sauce on the stove until we were ready to eat. Good call. It was fresh and hot when I put it on the table. Served with bread, salad and vegetables this made a really nice meal and took about an hour to prepare. Definitely a win!

text:
I've made this recipe several times and we love it.   This week I accidentally came across a secret to keeping them together without using string or toothpicks.   Due to time constraints on the day of my dinner, I put them together the night before and rolled them tightly and tightly put saran wrap on each piece.  When I browned them in the pan they kept their shape and  I didn't need to remove toothpicks or string after.   Will do this from now on if I have time the night before.

text:
FABULOUS. I read many reviews and tweaked to my tastes. I  sliced 3 large breasts down the middle. Folded Swiss into a square, folded ham around it, rolled up chicken & secured with toothpicks. Dipped in egg and rolled in panko & paprika. In a cast iron I browed for 5 minutes each side in 3 tbsp. butter & 3 olive oil. I transferred to glass dish and baked at 350 for 25 minutes. While it baked, I simmered 1 cup of chicken broth in the cast iron. I whisked in 1 cup heavy cream and 1 tbsp. cornstarch until thick. AMAZING!

text:
I made this for 20 on Christmas Day and it was fabulous. 

My tweaks: Due to the large group, I made everything up to the final cooking stage the day before. I browned the breasts/breading and then stuck everything in the fridge overnight. I cooked the prepared breasts at 350 for 30 minutes and they were perfect. 
I made the wine sauce separately;  just started with the butter, then added wine, bullion, paprika, cream w/ cornstarch and it was yummy. 
Also - added some Panko and spices to the flour breading for a much more exciting crust.

text:
This was great.  I followed a lot of the reviews, making sure I pounded the chicken breasts thinner than stated in the recipe, and it does cut cooking time down significantly.  I also added a teaspoon of poultry seasoning to the flour coating of the chicken.  The sauce turned out fantastic.  I made this just the other night and my wife is already asking me to make it again.  Also, depending on how thick cut your ham and swiss cheese is, I would also if they are both thinner add a second slice of each to each chicken breast.  Just my preference.

text:
This is AMAZING. I've made this for years (from the Good House Keeping Illustrated Cookbook). My parents always made it and it was always my choice for my birthday meal growing up. The only change I would make, would be that I pound the chicken to make it spread out and thinner, it's easier to roll the ham and cheese in. Also, in addition to the toothpicks to close it, I tie some cooking twine/string around it to keep the cheese in a little more. But other than that, this is perfect the way it is!!!

text:
This recipe is definitely a winner BUT it is also the same directions as in my own Good Housekeeping Illustrated Cookbook which I've had for over 30 years! The only alterations I made is to omit the toothpicks - they make it more difficult to handle while browning. I also pound the meat thinner than directed and have the ham and cheese in between two pieces of chicken rather than folding. A little extra wine won't hurt either - makes the flavor boosted a bit!

text:
Perfect directions, especially with the video. It tastes great and was a huge hit with my family. My biggest concern was the chicken being too thick and either unrolling on me or not being rollable. I had zero problems with it (obviously I used tooth picks). My only downside was that I didn't roll it in the flour and paprika well enough, but that's of the fun parts about cooking, learning how to do it better the next time.

text:
I used 1/2 olive oil, 1/2 butter but otherwise followed the recipe as written.  The sauce is to die for.  Seriously incredible. Next time I will use a bit more cheese or add some at the end, because most of it melted out of the chicken and into the pan. I also need to tinker with the cooking time as my chicken came out a little dry but I think that was user error relating to the size of the chicken breast I used.  The flavor was very good. Thanks for the recipe!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
1st time I've ever actually taken the time to rate a dish on this website and I've been using it for over a year! Awesome! I took some other's advice and browned chicken on all sides in pan then transferred to oven at 350 for 20 minutes, turned out perfect! I used halved chicken breasts and didn't have to thin first, also once I removed the browned chicken breast I used the same pan to make the sauce. I used 1/4 cup of water and 1/4 cup of Apple juice instead of 1/2 of white wine. I also threw in the left over flour/paprika mixture then the cream/cornstarch mixture whisked well and 1 slice of Swiss cheese at the end. The sauce was so very good, might double it next time as I only made 3 chicken breast halves instead of 6 and there still just wasn't enough of the good stuff, everyone wanted more!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is terrific as is. I found that pounding the chicken breasts thinner is a necessity to rolling them neatly as in the pictures.  I didn't have heavy whipping cream and I preferred to reduce the fat and calories, so I substituted 7/8 cup 1% milk and 1/8 cup additional butter.  This substitution is less rich than heavy whipping cream, with less than 300 calories vs nearly 900 calories  in a cup of whipping cream, and it suited our family's taste better than the heavier sauce in the recipe.

I did this and OMG!!! It was the BOMB!!! First time I have ever done this. Even the kids, 6, 10 and 13 loved it!!! I browned the chicken in 3 tbsp. of butter then threw it in the oven about 30 minutes (thicker chicken) I made the sauce in the pan I browned it in, doing the butter, wine and bouillon first then adding the cream and cornstarch(already mixed up) slowly then when it was done and off the heat I add another sliver of butter to make it velvety!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for 4 kids and 4 adults (increasing the chicken breasts to 8), and everyone cleaned their plates, even the picky eaters! I actually forgot the step of coating the chicken in flour, but it turned out fine. They still got brown. Some of the cheese melted out as the chicken cooked, but I just strained the liquid before adding the cream to get the chunks of cheese out. I don't know much about wine, but after doing a little research on what a dry white wine was, I settled on Pinot Grigio. The sauce it produced was delicious! I doubled the sauce as some previous reviewers recommended, and I'm glad I did. I served this with Chef John's rice pilaf (recipe is on this site) and grilled asparagus. I saw people also putting the sauce on their rice--it really was tasty.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used this recipe as a guideline mostly for the sauce which is amazing!  I wanted a breadcrumb outside to the chicken. Just pounded out breasts, laid slice of ham and small finger sized portion of Swiss, rolled and toothpicked closed. Dipped in egg then homemade seasoned bread crumbs. Baked 400, covered with foil for 20 min then uncovered for 20. Melted butter in cast iron skillet, added 1 teaspoon-ish each  minced garlic and bouillon paste. Added 1/2cup white wine, 1c heavy cream with the cornstarch. Cooked until thickened and added a little dried parsley. Restaurant quality. Yum!

text:
WOW!!! Glad I tried this recipe! It was the best thing I have ever made and so easy!!! Like other reviewers, I used egg and panko breadcrumbs instead of the flour. I substituted the paprika with smoked paprika. And I cut the butter in half and substituted with olive oil to make it a little healthier. The sauce was to die for!!! OMG!!!! Truly restaurant quality!!

text:
I made a few changes and I'm glad that I did. I used an egg/milk wash and double-coated with panko bread crumbs and browned on all sides followed by placing in the oven at 350 degrees for 30 minutes. Also, I used a sauvignon blanc for the sauce although I removed the burned bits of panko breading from the drippings. I happened to have a lot of leftovers so, I reheated in the oven the next day. I found that the chicken was much more flavorful then and because I had double-coated, the chicken crust was so crunchy still. The sauce is amazing so doubling that was a no-brainer. Definitely a must try!!! Thanks for sharing your recipe xoxox

Just made this for dinner tonight and it was amazing!! Even my 2.5 year old loved it, which is saying a lot. I think the only thing I did differently was to cook the chicken completely and then remove it from the pan before I added the wine and cream. Anytime I try to add wine while meat is still in the pan it becomes a disaster, but doing it that way was absolutely perfect. I will definitely be making this again!!!

userID:
11116525
Display Name:
bhamnett11
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/996005.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was SO excited to try this recipe.  Sounded like the perfect change of pace for Easter - ham, chicken, sauce, upscale presentation if cut into slices. Used the following recommendations: pounded chicken between 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick, used panko with the paprika (also made half of my recipe using seasoned breadcrumbs - did not like this b/c it overpowered the other flavors and made the recipe taste "generic"), used 3 T of butter for browning in the skillet, used a no water added thick sliced D&W ham, thick sliced good deli swiss, a decent (12 dollar)chardonnay for the sauce, finished the chicken by baking, and then made the sauce in a saucepan on the stovetop (without drippings).  We said it was 'pretty good, I guess.'  Zero wow factor, really sort of bland (chicken tasted like butter from pan frying & the sauce like creamy, buttery, wine - no dimension/depth) with the swiss & wine tasting sauce not a hit with my 4 & 12 year old (they did eat it, though they aren't really picky) & although not so difficult to make it did have quite a few steps - left me feeling like it was nowhere near worth the effort.  Still REALLY wanted this to be the perfect Easter recipe.  So, if I don't find something different to try I might give it one more shot - this time adding garlic to panko, using olive oil and a little butter for frying, replacing all or half of the ham with procuitto, & saving drippings for sauce.  I WANT to love this recipe, but so far it is a weeknight meal at best.

Very, very good. My picky husband told me it was delicious multiple times while he ate dinner! I went the oven baking route but otherwise stuck to the recipe. I baked the chicken/ham/cheese in the wine/chicken broth mix until done then removed the chicken and added the wine/broth/chicken dripping mix to the cream and cornstarch and heated on the stove till thick. I then sliced the Chicken Cordon Bleu into cutlets and drizzled the amazing sauce over the top. Delicious!

text:
I baked at 350 for 35 minutes instead of keeping them in the skillet. I added the wine before I put them in the oven, and then didn't need the bullion. This way there was a lot of sauce. I added a bit of fresh grated nutmeg and corriander as well. Yum! It takes a bit of time, though, to get the chicken flat and in the right shape, and to roll them. Also, if you use flour, then egg, then the breadcrumbs, it has a thicker crust.

text:
I made this tonight, paired it with roasted red potatoes and maple dill carrots from this site. I made it exactly as written, which is unusual for me.  I usually tweek recipes as I go, lol. It tasted really good, but Im not exactly a pro cook, so I had a couple problems.  I had a little trouble rolling the breasts around the ham and cheese, but I evenyually got 3 that looked pretty good.  The sauce was yummy, but I had to make a second batch.  The first one looked like it separated, was lumpy.  Maybe I cooked it too long?  The second batch was perfect.  I did as others suggested and finished the cooking in the oven, adding the sauce at the end. I also cut the breast into 1" rounds, then drizzled the sauce over the top, then garnished the whole thing with fresh parsley.  Ive always felt that if food looks good, it will taste good, and I think my presentation was outstanding!  I will definately make this again.  Maybe next time I will have an easier time rolling them, lol...

city:

country:

text:
I made this for a combination Valentine's Day/birthday dinner with friends.  It was delicious! I need to practice the rolling & pinning technique--the cheese did leak out but that's not the recipe's fault. I followed the recipe's cooking method and it was fine; I did use gluten-free rice flour to dredge the chicken as well as subbing proscuito for ham.  The sauce was delicious; I doubled it which made a TON.  (So I used the leftover sauce & chicken to make "chicken cordon bleu pizza" the next day. Yum again!)
I did have to laugh at myself--I used colored toothpicks in the chicken...um, not a good idea.  The color bled into the chicken!  Thankfully it's food-safe, but still--I jokingly claimed that I'd done it on purpose to make Rainbow Chicken Cordon Bleu.  Ha! Oh, well... :-)
I look forward to making this again and doing a better job--the flavor is worth it!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe as is, it was very delicious. But the second time around I made a couple mods...First I used panko bread crumbs and omitted the flour and paprika for the breading, it made the dish have a little extra crunch. Next, after breading, I browned the chicken on each side in a sautee pan using a little oil or butter whichever you choose rather than adding the bullion and the wine to the pan. (I thought if I did so it would turn out soggy and mushy) After browning the chicken, I then baked it in the oven, the time is dependent upon how thick you pound your breasts out and how long you they have been browned in the pan but 20-30 is a good starting point. (mine took a while but well worth the wait) Lastly, I used the bullion, wine, butter, cream and cornstarch for a sauce that I made entirely separately. It was fab:) One of my new favorites.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with 2 very minor changes, and it was absolutely delicious. I took another reviewer's suggestion and browned the chicken in 3 tablespoons of butter and 3 tablespoons of olive oil, rather than 6 tablespoons of butter. I also used a little more than 1/4 cup of a nice Madeira wine and finished the half cup of wine with a white wine.  The Madeira wine gave the sauce a wonderful flavor, similar to a Marsalla sauce, but a little sweeter. I used Perduce thin-sliced chicken breasts so no pounding-out was necessary. It also cut down on the cooking time. The thin-sliced breasts were perfect for this recipe. My son said this is now his favorite dish.  My husband loved it, too.  Thank you for such a simple, yet yummy, recipe!

text:
Great recipe - my husband does not like white cheeses - so I used cheddar. Also the ham I had on hand was 'smoked ham' the smokeyness really flavored the chicken a lot. One reviewer mentioned pounding the chicken thin then cooking faster - another reviewer mentioned 'butterfly' cutting the breasts. I butterflyed after not being able to pound a large breast thin. The side that was pounded cooked up best.  Next time I will butterfly AND pound any very thick breasts. Of the 'chicken' I have cooked - my husband likes this recipe the best.

country:
None
text:
Came out very well.

I didn't have swiss, so I used a combination of shredded mozzarella and cheddar.  Started it in a cast iron pan, browned both sides.  When I added the wine, I scraped the bottom of the pan under the chicken with a spatula to loosen the good bits a little, and I added most of the dredging flour along with the bits of shredded cheese that had fallen out.  Then finished in the oven.  The extra flour and cheese thickened the sauce for me, which was good since I had to sub 2% milk for the cream.

text:
This recipe was super yummy!  The only changes I made were to brown the chicken breasts in butter and olive oil then finish cooking them in the oven.  I made my sauce in the same pan I browned my chicken it.  At first I was hesitant to add the sauce to the finished chicken because it had this odd corn-starchy taste to it, but once on the chicken it was amazing.  Will definitely be doing this one again.

text:
I made this for my husband and I, I'd only had chicken cordon bleu once at a restaurant and it was delicious and the 2 times he'd tried it he said the chicken was very dry and tasted awful (not at a restaurant). but I knew I could change his mind about it! and I did! He said "You can make this anytime!" 

I followed the recipe with an exception for the butter, I used olive oil! pounding the chicken to a 1/4 thickness first really helped to wrap it up arounds itself and cuts down on the cook time! after browning it I only cooked it for 15 mins and it came out perfect!

text:
This was great. I Browned rolls in 3T butter and 3T Olive oil. Then put in the oven for 20-30 min at 350. Made sauce on stove top. Used leftover Honeybaked ham from Christmas, diced small. For cheese, I used a slice of swiss and a slice of provolone on each. All swiss may be too strong for our taste. Doubled the sauce and added a little paprika for color.  Both good ideas. Family all loved it!

I absolutely loved this recipe. 
I did use "cooking wine" because that is what I had on hand. I dipped the chicken in butter after I had rolled the cheese, ham and dijon mustard and then coated it with flour. I fried it until golden brown and then baked it at 350 for 45 minutes. I then added a couple of tablespoons of the sauce and cooked it an extra 5 minutes or so. It was delicious, I would definitely make it again... The only think I would do differently is added 2 slices of cheese instead of 1. Thanks for a great recipe!!!

The flavor was there but appearance was a little less desired. I used fresh chicken breasts and followed Chef Ramsey's instruction by using a fillet knife to make an instersion into the chicken to make a cavern. text:
Delicious! I prepared a bit differently while keeping the sauce and general idea of this recipe. For a breading, I used homemade breadcrumbs with a number of different spices on hand, but first rolled the rolled-breasts in an egg batter. Instead of cooking in the pan I baked them, keeping the sauce to the side since it's so incredibly rich. Lastly, instead of corn starch I used flour but doubled the amount. It was a great hit at a dinner party!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2010-07-14T05:49:29.913
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1833838
Display Name:
Heather Calhoun
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
49
favoritesCount:
136
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3267261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As always, I read through the most helpful reviews before starting.  I made several changes based on some of those reviews as well as my own personal taste (I didn't use toothpicks or string -- I just made sort of a casserole).  I pounded my chicken breasts, lightly seasoned both sides with seasoning salt and garlic powder, pan fried them without flour (I don't care for breading or coating) in about three tbsp. each of butter and olive oil until they were brown.  I put the chicken breasts in a casserole dish, laid a slice of deli ham, shredded parmesan cheese, a slice of swiss cheese, and shredded mixed cheese (mexican blend) on top and baked at 350 for about 30 minutes.  For the sauce I took another reviewer's suggestion and added the wine (I used cooking sherry because that is what I had on hand) and a crumbled low sodium chicken bouillon cube to the butter/olive oil mixture that was left in the pan.  I let that simmer while I mixed the cornstarch and heavy whipping cream in a separate bowl.  I poured it into the pan with the butter/olive oil, wine and bouillon mixture, and whisked it until it came to a boil and thickened.  I added paprika to the sauce, poured the sauce on top of the chicken, and put it back in the oven so the sauce would soak into the chicken.  The oven was off and I left it in there for a few minutes.  Overall, this was a good recipe and the flavors seemed to go well together.  The sauce was very good.  The chicken was extremely tender and juicy.

This was extremely juicy, wonderful chicken. I actually did not put the ham and cheese inside the chicken. I floured the chicken and fried it in the butter, then added the wine and bouillon. While the chicken was simmering, I added the ham and cheese on top. Worked out great and couldn't tell a difference in the taste. YUM!!

Very good flavor!!  Mine did not come out nearly as pretty as the picture - I don't think I pounded the chicken breast halves enough and my ham and cheese ended up leaking out. I also followed the advice of others and used 3 TBS of butter and 3 TBS of olive oil.

text:
I have made this twice now and both times received compliments. The sauce is AMAZING. The first time I used the flour coating and the second I did breadcrumbs. The breadcrumbs didn't hold well after simmering in the liquid but most of them did stay on. It just didn't look very uniform. To keep the cheese from melting out I got a block of swiss cheese and cut nice thick chunks and wrapped that well thicker slices of ham to secure it. When cutting into the chicken (even though I could not roll the chicken completly closed) the cheese was just softened perfectly and not melted away!
Review:

5

text:
I cooked this meal for last night's dinner, following the recipe exactly (except for the fact that I made 3 chicken breasts instead of 6) and it came out FANTASTIC.  Simmering made the chicken juicy and delicious, and the sauce was incredible.  I'd recommend making a side dish that can also utilize this fantastic sauce, such as rice or potatoes.  My only recommended change would be to fold the cheese within the ham (as suggested by other posters) in order to prevent the cheese from melting out.  Loved this dish.

country:
None
text:
All I can say is WOW!  This was sooo good.  My husband especially liked the sauce and he doesn't usually care for it.  After reading the reviews, I did the following:  I used 3T butter amd 3T olive oil.  Put the ham and swiss on the chicken and rolled up, coated in egg wash and rolled in Panko bread crumbs.  Fried lightly for 3 mins. each side and placed in a baking dish.  With the oven at 350, I placed the chicken in the oven to bake for 25 mins. While the chicken was baking, I mixed the wine, chicken bouillon, heavy cream/cornstarch in the pan with some dried basil (that's all I had on hand), and sauteed until thick, appx. 10 mins.  Will definitely make this again many times.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Before I cooked this, my hubby warned me several times that he is not a fan of cordon bleu. But guess what he chanted while eating this? "KEEPER!" :-) Scaled the recipe to yield 2 and did the ff: (1) pounded 2 pcs whole (vs halved) chicken breasts (2) spreaded Dijon mustard over the chicken  (3) placed 2 slices of Swiss cheese between 2 thin slices of ham for each chicken breast (4) added 1/4 tsp garlic powder & 1/8 tsp each of iodized salt & ground black pepper for the flour mixture (5) secured the rolled chicken with thread (cross- & length-wise) & toothpicks (at the ends and middle part) (6) Fried the dregded chicken for about 4mins per side and placed in the oven at 350F for 30mins (7) For the sauce, simmered wine, bouillon granules, cornstarch, and cream until thickened. Good that I doubled the sauce! I served this with steamed broccoli on the side, jasmine rice, and "Delicious Ham & Potato Soup". Definitely a keeper! :-) Thanks for this recipe and thanks for the great/helpful reviews!

text:
So, I made chicken cordon bleu based on this recipe, but because I did not follow the recipe as stated, I gave it a lower rating. I knew that a chicken breast with a flour coating and no bread crumbs was not the kind of cordon bleu I was looking for, so I coated my chicken breast in beaten eggs and seasoned bread crumbs after butterflying it and stuffing it. Rather than cook it in the sauce, I pan seared the breasts, and finished them in the oven at 350 degrees. I also added the juice of one lemon and double the amount of wine in the sauce because I thought it would compliment the chicken breast better. Thanks for the great jumping off point!

this was fantastic. i followed the recipe exactly and it turned out fine. i might try the breadcrumbs next time, but the flour/paprika was excellent. a small amount of the cheese did melt out during the cooking process (per other reviewers) despite my wrapping the cheese in the ham slices (per other reviewers), but not so much that there wasn't any left inside, and it really just added to the sauce! i am definitely making this again! None
text:
This dish turned out to be much easier than I expected.  I tied the rolls fast with kitchen twine rather than using toothpicks.  The twine is much more secure, doesn't get in the way when turning the chicken for browing, and is also helpful when you're trying to move them around the pan.  I added some fresh chopped rosemary to the sause which we felt really rounded out the flavor just right.

!cindyjo!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I finally made this evening after putting it off since Monday. It was much easier than I expected and the taste was simply wonderful! I only made 4 chicken breasts, used  egg wash with added paprika and garlic powder then dredged them in flour which I also added garlic powder and paprika to. I then browned them on the stovetop before baking for 20 mins at 350 degrees. For the wine sauce, a I combined the wine, bullion and butter. Once that started to simmer, I added an extra slice of swiss cheese. I had read many reviews from folks who made the sauce along with the chicken and I really wanted that "melted cheese" flavor and this worked. One last note, I did cut back on fat content by using low fat ham slices, reduced fat swiss cheese, fat free half and half and part real butter/part "I can't believe it's not butter". My husband couldn't tell the difference and it tastes delicious. I will make it the same way again (likely soon!!)

DaniDee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7454441.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this recipe and it "rocked" as my husband exclaimed when he finally pushed himself away from the table.  I actually used leftover spiral honey ham from Christmas dinner and a lower fat swiss cheese (melted just the same).  One thing that I did that I may do different next time is that I didn't use heavy cream.  To save fat I used fat free half and half.  It looked gross (curdled) but tasted awesome.  It just kind of screwed up the presentation a bit.  If that is not an issue for you and you want to save on calories then I would try this lower fat version.  I also used the Uncle Ben's 90 second rice to save on time.  I'll use two packages next time as it barely fed both my husband and I.  Also, you can buy the Purdue thin cuts (which I used) instead of having to pound the cutlets.  I will use two packages of those next time instead of one because the cutlets are somewhat small.  Overall, it rocked!

This was simply OUTSTANDING.  I actually used white grape juice instead of wine and I used 1 cup instead of 1/2 cup.  Because I used more of the "wine", I doubled the bouillon.  I changed nothing else.  I used colored toothpicks and the color bled onto the chicken.  Oops!  Next time I think I'll try tying it like someone else recommended!  HUGE hit with our guests!

text:
I have been looking for a recipe similar to this for a long time.  We had a little mom & pop restaurant down the road that had the best Chicken Cordon Bleu, they closed down and boy did I miss the chicken.  I could never find the right recipe to make the "sauce" that was pored over the chicken, and this sauce is extremely close if not a little better.  I did the chicken, ham & cheese like they used to do at the restaurant.  Deep fried Chicken with a piece of cheese & ham (i used smoked) on top covered with the sauce.  I made the sauce separate and used chicken broth instead of the wine and it turned out great.  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
Due to dietary restrictions I had to modify the fat content.  Instead of the butter, I 'fried' the chicken until lightly browned using butter flavored spray, then baked the chiken for 20 minutes.  I used a 50/50 mix of fat free cheddar & mozarella cheeses.  For the sauce, I used fat free half & half and a TBS of parsely.  Then poured the sauce on the chicken and baked 5 minutes.  It was fabulous!  Even my chicken hater loved it.  Agree with other ratings....MAKE MORE SAUCE.

This was fantastic. I pounded the chicken, rolled swiss and ham in them, floured them, egged them, and dipped them in breadcrumbs. I then pan fried them in veg. oil before baking them at 350 for 30 min.  I made the sauce on the stove separately and drizzled it over the chicken before serving. I used half and half instead of whipping cream and it still turned out great!

text:
This was very good.  Lots of compliments.  I used thin sliced chicken breasts, and wrapped the cheese in the ham which kept the cheese from leaking all over.  I followed the recipe exactly except I seasoned the chicken with salt, pepper and garlic powder.  If I use thin sliced chicken again I'll cut down on the cooking time.  A few people mentioned how the cream separated.  After taking the chicken out of the pan, I poured about half of the liquid out before adding the cream & corn starch and had no problem with the cream separating.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2009-09-28T12:38:34.227
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3767535
Display Name:
shangriluck
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
87
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/390797.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best. Recipe. Ever. I can't even handle how delicious this is. I've done it a few different ways; once with thick breasts that I pounded down (so much work), once with thin cut breasts that I placed one on top of the other with the filling between the two (works just as well) and once with boneless breast steaks that were huge and thin and easily folded over. I added a little honey mustard on the inside last time which was awesome, and tonight I'm going to try using havarti instead of swiss. Love that rich flavor. I also added some cooking wine to the sauce, which adds more of that wine flavor and salts it just enough. I've also used flour, egg, then panko crumbs a couple of times for a more crispy and flavorful crust. Really no matter how you tweak this recipe, if you follow the basic ingredients it's going to be fantastic. I have chicken soaking in buttermilk right now, just waiting to be cooked!
EDIT: I did these again last night, and this time I had breasts that were so huge I didn't even want to think about pounding them down. Instead, I cut along one side of the breast as deep as i could without cutting straight through it, forming a pocket. I took the ham and swiss and tucked it into the pocket, pinned it shut with a toothpick for the browning process, then stuck them in the oven for 45 minutes (they were huge). So tender and so good, worked just as well as before and actually easier than any of my other methods. Also, serve the sauce on steamed broccoli! Nomnomnom.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made the recipe according to how it was written and from the suggestion of another reviewer. Gotta say that changing the recipe was much better. I did, however, cut the chicken breasts and place the ham and swiss in. Then rub the breasts with egg and cover with bread crumbs. Fry them in a pan with butter until golden on both sides. Place them in the oven for 25 minutes. While it's in the oven, mix together the cream, cornstarch, bouillon, and wine. If you like the strong taste of wine, use the measurements provided. Otherwise, reduce the wine 1/3 cup. Simmer for 10 minutes. Pour over chicken and serve!

text:
Amazing recipe!! I have made this a couple of times now.  The sauce is a perfect compliment to the chicken without being too rich.  I suggest a high quality smoked ham for the best flavor.  I made this for a dinner party and changed a few things up because I couldn't fit the amount of breast I need into one stove top pan.  After browning the breast I placed them in a glass pan and poured the wine/bouillon mixture on the chicken.  I baked it at 350 degrees for 20 minutes and it came out great.  I have made it with both ways of cooking it and they both taste great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I registered with allrecipes.com just to review this recipe! This was the best dish I have ever ate let alone made. I customized it by putting all reviewer suggestions together. I only did 3 servings. I pounded the chicken probally 1/4" thick and put about 1tbs of dijon mustard in each. I used 1 slice of thick ham wrapped around 2 pieces of provolone. I tied it with cooking string and fried it in 3tbs of butter and 3tbs of extra vigin olive oil on med high 5 mins each side. Baked at 350 for 20 mins. I poured 1/4 of the butter/oil in a saucepan on med along w/ 1c chicken broth and 2ts of bouillon for about 9 mins with a lid then added a slice of provolone for 1 min. Then i added 2c of whipping cream(regular) and 2tbs of cornstarch and simmer for 5 mins and boil for 5mins until thick and poured it all in the pan with the chicken. It was AMAZING!!!

text:
I love creamy dishes and especially cooking with wine. This was good except the chicken was not cooked inside. I would recommend baking the chicken after the browning. I also found the cornstarch to lump in the whipping cream. I'd dilute the cornstarch with a bit of water before mixing it in with the whipping cream. The sauce needs a dash of salt.

This is EXCELLENT! Really!  I made just a few minor changes based on suggestions of other reviewers. (Thanks!) I used chicken broth instead of white wine; I dipped the rolled chicken into an egg wash (with a little salt/pepper), then in flour, and back into the egg wash again before placing it into the skillet; and sprinkled a bit of basil in the sauce just before serving.  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. Delicious!  Thanks for sharing, Behr!

text:
My husband said this is in his "top ten". Modifications I used include: flour mixture for dusting: reduce paprika to 3/4 tsp and added dash of rosemary leaves (fresh would be best). Liquid for simmering chicken: Used cooking Sherry and increased it to 3/4 cup, added 1/2 cup water and increased granular boullion to 2 tsp. After chicken simmered, removed to baking dish and placed in 375 oven for 10-15 min to improve appearance. Added sauted mushrooms to gravy (used can, would prefer fresh). Served with quartered sm. red potatoes with snow peas and red peppers in rosemary butter sauce and crescent rolls.

text:
Unbelievable! This is definitely one of my  fave dishes. I used chicken cutlets (3 to equal one chicken breast), then cut up slices of deli ham and cheese into 3's. This way, you can use as appetizer or main dish. For heavy cream, I used 2/3 c. milk and 1/3 c. melted butter. I use smart balance spread instead of butter for health benefits. Otherwise, followed exactly. Dish was absolutely fabulous, unbelievable flavor and super moist chicken. I doubled the sauce to have extra, and microwaved some peas to throw in there. Great! Will make again.

I made a few mistakes when making this (I'm a beginner, ok?!), such as purchasing chicken tenders instead of breasts and somehow totally screwing up the sauce (it was thin and I was stirring it over low heat, then suddenly it became a big gloppy mess!), but it still ended up tasting delicious, if somewhat not as visually appealing! I did add a bit of dijon mustard to the chicken before putting on the ham and cheese, as well as adding a slice of cheese to the sauce as others had recommended.  Will definitely attempt this again, hopefully with fewer errors!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4584574.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish is simple, yet elegant. The taste was fantastic, and worthy of its name! I did make a few modfications though. I substituted chicken soup base (powder) and 35% cooking cream for the chicken bouillon granules and heavy whipping cream. I also used thick slices of salami instead of ham. I used processed Swiss cheese slices (though the real thing would have made it way better, next time!) and bacon slices to hold the breasts together. I used a moderately priced white wine (about $15 CAD). I used margarine instead of butter, about three heaping tablespoons. Next time I'll do the butter/olive oil combination for more flavour. I also melted an extra slice of the cheese while the sauce was cooking. I served this with some boiled veggies... blah. The sauce would greatly compliment some asparagus or spinach quite nicely, next time I'll use those instead. A definite keeper!

text:
This recipe for Cordon Bleu is delicious! I made it last night and served it over "Dreamfields" low-carb linguine and steamed broccoli. It came out great. I used the half butter half olive oil recommendation from "chefsingledad" and added a buit more dry wine then called for. I think it made a big difference in flavor. Also I found that toothpicks nor string were necessary if you make sure to pound the meat to at least a 1/2" in thickness.  Enjoy!

text:
My picky family really enjoyed this meal.  I made a few modifications however.  After dipping the chicken in the flour mixture, I dipped it in melted butter and then in seasoned bread crumbs and baked it in the oven.  This made it neccesary to change the sauce recipe, using only a shot of red wine, since I had no white, and using milk and sour cream instead of heavy cream. The sauce was not a great success so sticking to the recipe in that area would be safer.  I do think extra seasoning on the chicken and thicker ham and cheese slices would have made this a 5 star recipe for me.

text:
Turned out good! I doubled the sauce, as many recommended. Great sauce! I also browned the chicken first then baked it while I cooked my sauce separately. I used provalone cheese instead of swiss and used smoked ham from the deli. First I covered in flour, then egg and then Italian bread crumbs. My boyfriend would have preferred my bread crumbs.  I've never had Chicken Cordon Bleu. I'd probably make it again.

Edit: I'm about to make this meal for the 5th time but for my parents this time! I now only cook this meal as the original person created it and I double the sauce and serve with mashed potatoes. This is and excellent recipe!

text:
WOW that was fun!  Just served this to a dinner party and everyone raved about it. And if you're wondering if you can make this ahead of time, it works out fine.  Just stop at the point where you've cooked the chicken in the wine. Cool then refrigerate.  About 15 minutes before you serve: reheat chicken/wine sauce, then remove chicken and make the sauce.

text:
I prepared this dish for my husband and friends and they and I were very impressed :) I made a few changes:  I used twine (no toothpicks), 1/2 olive oil and 1/2 butter versus (vs. all butter), breadcrumbs (no flour), 1/2 heavy cream and 1/2 half & half (vs. all HC), after browning in skillet, I baked chicken in oven at 350 for 20 mins, and I added fresh chopped basil right before serving and it really was just icing on the cake! I served chicken over white rice and broccolli (next time I will do asparagus instead).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so delicious - I made it for my husband for Valentine's Day and we loved it.  I did add extra breading to my chicken rolls (flour, egg wash, then bread crumbs), then I browned the rolls in a pan with the butter and removed them from the pan to a baking stone and baked them for 20 minutes at 350 degrees.  I then made the sauce in the pan I added the chicken bouillon granules and the cooking wine I had in my pantry and let that simmer for about 5-10 minutes then I added the cream mixture and stirred in until it thickened and let it simmer until the chicken was cooked.  I couldn't believe that I had cooked this dish, it tasted better than the chicken cordon bleu I have had in a restaurant.  I served it with fresh bread, mushroom rice pilaf from this site, and steamed asparagus.  I can't wait for another opportunity to make this again.

My family was so impressed with me, made me look like a real chef, lol!! I did follow suggestions of others, like 3tbl spoons butter and 3tbl spoons evoo, doubled the sauce, which was amazing!!I did use a three part breading for the chicken, first flour,paprika, second egg, third bread crumbs, then I browned the chicken and baked it like the others suggested. I made the sauce in the same pan I browned the chicken and when the chicken was done I poured the sauce over it!! Yummmmm...sooooo good!!!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-01-23T05:05:59.297
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
237963
Display Name:
Bev Miller Johnstone
isPro:
False
followersCount:
15
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
176
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6080877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is absolutely awesome.  I made a couple changes.  I added bread crumbs and a little dried thyme to the flour/paprika mixture.  I melted butter in a baking pan in the oven.  Then, I just coated the chicken rolls with the melted butter, and rolled them in the bread crumb/flour mixture.  Then, I baked them in the pan I used to melt the butter.  I baked them at 350 degrees for about 45 minutes.  When they were done, I made the sauce in a saucepan on the stove, using a Pinot Grigio because that's what I happened to have on hand.  I mixed together the wine, heavy cream, a little cornstarch, and the chicken boullion.  I cooked it over a medium low heat until it thickened. After I poured the sauce over the chicken, I thought it looked a little pale, so I sprinkled on just a little more paprika and some dried parsley for color.  I had never made cordon bleu before, but I will be making this often from now on.  It's a great company dish.  The sauce was just delicious, however, next time I think I'll only use about half of the cornstarch called for. Mine turned out just a bit thicker than I would have liked.  Great recipe!!

text:
WOW this was great!!! I was skeptical about making Chx Cordon Blue on the stove top but it was fab! One suggestion is to cut down the cooking time after you add the wine. Chicken is safe to eat at 170 degrees - I would take the chicken off then to save some of the cheese in the middle (overcooking it will melt all of the cheese out of the roll) and to ensure it doesn't get to dry.

text:
I have made this several times, it is has ALWAYS gotten rave reviews.  It is so amazingly good.  The one thing I change is that in addition to the swiss cheese, I also add a slice of meunster.   What stays inside of the chicken adds richness (yes, even more) and what doesn't melts into the sauce making it even creamier.  If it weren't for the calories and fat, I would make this weekly!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/20.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was superb! Easy to do with all of the ingredients on hand, but I think would be expensive otherwise.  My husband wants me to cook this for any company we have in the future. I served it with wheat buns, salad, peas and asparagus (we have picky eaters when it comes to green food).

As for modifications:
I used my leftover spiral ham from New Years for the middle. I pounded my chicken down to 1/2" thickness. I folded the chicken over in half over the ham and cheese, and it worked fine.   I baked it in the oven in a 13x9 glass pan @ 350' for 30 min. I then added the wine mixture and covered it with foil for 20 min. I then transferred the chicken to a plate, added the cream mixture and thickened on the stove top. BIG HIT!

country:
None
text:
This is very flavorful and delicious. However, I followed the recipe and left the chicken in the pan to simmer. During that process most of the cheese melted out of the chicken and into the sauce. This would have been fine except that it added a whole bunch of fat to the sauce you make at the end. The fat separated out and ruined the look of the sauce. Next time I'll try another reviewer's suggestion and make the sauce completely separate from the chicken. I also cooked the chicken for 30 minutes, which was much too long. Bottom line, good flavor and pretty presentation once you learn proper preparation.

text:
Good recipe, but I would tweak a couple of things for a healthier meal.  Leave out the flour bit and simply season the chicken with salt, pepper, and paprika and brown in pan.  Leave out the bouillon cube, add a little bit more wine, then substitute the heavy cream with chicken stock and you have yourself a simple, lean, yummy dish!

This sounds like the recipe I use. I haven't tried this recipe yet but have a suggestion. Instead of using toothpicks, I find that cotton or cooking thread works better. Just roll or fold over the chicken and tie it like you would a package. This way your guests aren't digging around in the chicken for the toothpicks but can rather untie and the string will come right off.

Display Name:
powcook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good, but everyone around me thought it was great. My dad especially raved about it. I put the cheese in between two slices of ham so that it wouldn't melt into the sauce. But I didnt want to use thinly sliced deli ham because its too salty and doesnt have the same great taste, so I used good quality thickly sliced ham. But instead of using two thickly sliced pieces of ham in between cheese which would be too "hammy", I used one good quality piece of ham and added a thin sliced piece of deli ham on top of it and that was enough to hold the cheese in. It came out great and it didnt affect the taste at all. And since most of the cheese is held in the chicken, I melted one more slice of cheese into the sauce mixture. Also, I didnt have white wine so I highly suggest using half white wine vinegar and half water. Cant taste the difference. Delicious.

country:
None
text:
This was just SUPER DUPER. I used italian seasoned panko crumbs in addition to the flour/paprika mix, and I coated the entire chicken breast before rolling them up. I used half olive oil, half butter, and added a little chopped garlic. I didn't have problems with the toothpicks, but I couldn't get them to roll up, so it was more like "folding" them and sticking in the t-picks to close up the ends. I accidentally started cooking the chicken in a pan that didn't have a lid to fit over everything, so after browning, I transferred the chicken to my little Oster oven and baked for about 15 min at 250 F to make sure it cooked all the way through. The last few minutes while baking, I cooked some asparagus in the wine/butter/olive oil and removed them before adding the cream/corn starch to the pan to finish the sauce. I had doubts about the sauce, but wow... it was so good.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So, I made this again today for the second time.................................... ..........................................This time I used pancetta(Italian bacon) in place of Ham. I think it is much better with pancetta. I used 2 thinly sliced pieces of pancetta and 1 piece of swiss cheese(DO NOT use the American singles swiss cheese....use the REAL swiss cheese) for each half piece of chicken breast.....................................................................................................................I  used 1/2 cup WATER instead of wine, and I added 2 teaspoons of the chicken bullion granules..........................................................................To increase the volume of suace,I added 2 cups(16 oz) of heavy whipping cream with 1 1/2 tablespoons corn starch and I added 1 teaspoon finely chopped garlic.....................................................................................................................Two minutes before remove the sauce from the heat I added 1/4 teaspoon ground NUTMEG and 1 added the chicken pieces to the sauce.............................................................................The garlic and NUTMEG adds amazing flavour to this great dish
..........................................................................................REMOVING THE TOOTHPICKS..use the Kitchen Scissors to pull them out. They come out much more easily.

text:
Yum!!!  I added salt and pepper to the chicken before the flour.  I wanted to double the sauce so I made the following changes.  I browned the chicken using 3 tablespoons of butter and 3 olive oil.  I used 1/2 cup of white wine and 1/2 cup chicken broth.  I slowly whisked in 1 and 1/2 cups of heavy cream with 2 tablespoons of cornstarch.  The sauce was delicious.  My family loved this meal.  Thanks for the recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe, we didn't have swiss so we used Provolone cheese, it was sooo yummy. For the wine we used Pinot Grigio and it was fabulous! Even my 3 year old liked this one. We served this meal with white Jasmine rice that I cooked with 1 cup water and 1/2 cup of wine (pinot grigio) and 1 tsp of chicken boullion seasoning, and served with Green beans. This was fabulous! Don't pound the chicken too hard or too thin, it will fall apart. Also, big WARNING HERE -- DO NOT USE COLORED TOOTHPICKS OR THE CHICKEN WILL ABSORB THE COLOR FROM THE TOOTHPICKS. OUR CHICKEN TURNED GREEN FROM THE GREEN TOOTHPICKS.

Thanks for this recipe, it will be a regular weekly meal in our home from now on.

text:
I did not have any toothpicks either but just rolled it tightly and baked the open side of the chicken down on the skillet first. For 2 of the chickens, I had some silver needle looking things (have no idea what they are called) that came with my turkey basting set and used those like toothpicks. I noticed my sauce looked different than the posted pics. I added the cornstarch and the whole milk (sub for cream) into the skillet with the remaining paprika/flour mix to make the gravy that is poured on top of the chicken. I would make this again, although it is more rich than I am use to  with Chicken Cordon Bleu recipes.

text:
Amazing!  I made this on Thursday and I plan to make it again on Sunday!  I seasoned the flour a bit with salt, pepper, and garlic powder.  I also butterflied the chicken, layed the ham and cheese on the chicken, and then just rolled it.  Stuck 2 toothpics in and was done. Yes, some cheese came out, but it mixes in with the sauce.  Instead of pouring the sauce over the chicken, I dumped pasta into it and did it that way.  Next time, I won't use whipping cream, I will use table cream or milk.  I am sure I can find a recipe for a wine sauce that isn't SOOOO bad for me.  I can't wait to eat this again!  THANK YOU!!

userID:
921635
Display Name:
foodiemomof5
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
148
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/20.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe was fantastic, but I needed to make some procedural changes.  First I pounded the chicken breasts and breaded them, without the ham or cheese.  I then browned just the pounded, breaded breasts.  I didn't have a skillet large enough to cook all of them at the same time, so I put the browned chicken breasts into a large glass pan.  I poured  the liquid (I used chicken broth) into the pan with the chicken, then placed the  ham and cheese on top of the chicken and covered it with foil.  It then went into a 350* oven for 30 minutes.  When cooked through, I just poured the remaining liquid and bits back into the sauce pan to make the sauce.  All of the goodness without messing with toothpicks, slippery chicken and problems with small frying pans.
Review:
Rating:
5

I wasn't confident that it would look good at the end, but after browning and serving with the sauce, it looked great. My pan was large, so I doubled the wine and bouillon. The gravy makes this recipe wonderful.

text:
This recipe is excellent.  I have made it twice now and it is clearly one of my husband and I's favorites. One tip that I found was helpful was instead of using toothpicks I used the picks that come with a functional nutcracker set.  This really helps keep the chicken stay wrapped around the ham much more efficiently while maneuvering it.  I also substituted American cheese, instead of Swiss, and found it to come as even better.  I know I will be making this recipe for many years to come.

text:
Excellent recipe. I cooked for New Years Eve dinner. Set them on a bed of Mashed Potatoes and a side of steamed butter garlic broccoli.  I did make some changes. I marinated my chicken breasts in Italian dressing over night. I also sandwiched a piece of swiss cheese between two slices of ham instead of one. I browned them on the stove and then placed them in the oven with skillet juices to bake when they were almost done I layered each chicken roll with one slice of ham and a strip of cheese. The chicken was amazingly tender and I loved the sauce so I doubled up on the cream. Will make again!!!!

I was brave enough to try this recipe for Christmas dinner because so MANY people raved about it. It was true, it was terrific. Every plate was clean! I had to make at least 20 cutlets, so I had the butcher trim the fat and cut them very thin. This helped me out a lot, timewise. text:
YUM - this was very tasty.  I liked the combination of the Swiss cheese and the wine sauce.  My 2 1/2 year old kept going "yum yum yum" as he ate it and my hubby said it was comfort food with a gourmet touch.  I used homo milk with extra cornstarch as I did not have whipping cream and it was still delish.  The only suggestions I have would be to strain the sauce before serving as there were bits of cheese and fried breading that made it lumpy and to use tongs or tweezers to help get the toothpicks out.  It was easier to prepare than I had thought...the instructions were very detailed which helped in the ease.

text:
This is seriously one of the best things I've ever eaten. Double the sauce, though, because it's GOOD!  I also add sliced baby portobello mushrooms into the sauce about 15 minutes after the wine, and everyone has loved this much more.  This is my most requested dish, and both my boyfriend and my daughter ask for it every time when I say "I'll make whatever you want".  I've also found you don't even really NEED the toothpicks to hold everything together.  They can be kind of a pain.  The middle will still stay inside, and no need to go searching for the dang things afterward.  Served with pasta, and the sauce is amazing over the noodles.  Just an incredible recipe...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was fairly easy to follow although with the toothpicks holding it together it started browning a LOT quicker than I wanted. If I could start over again I'd minus the toothpicks and just slice basically a pocket into the chicken, then I would insert the Swiss wrapped with the ham first, makes it a lot easier to cook, I discovered it on the last breast to do that and that one was perfect. I used too much butter and so it was very greasy but that was my fault because I didn't want the chicken to burn but it was hard to cook them with the toothpicks. Took longer than I thought but all in all it was fairly easy to work with the recipe. I did the recipe exactly as it is except for the extra butter while cooking the chicken. Also my friend asked if I added "salt" and I said no and I'm guessing its from the Ham so maybe try a salt free ham or light or something to omit the salt taste.

My husband raved about this dish. It was a winner!  He asked me to be sure to make it again. I didn't bother with toothpicks, instead i just folded over the breasts.  This worked fine for me. I also added a tablespoon of evoo to the butter in the pan. Also, per the other review, I made my chicken breasts about 1/2" or thinner so I could get them done in about 15 minutes cook time rather than 30.

Awesome recipe! This is the first time I've ever made chicken cordon bleu and I was so impressed with the ease of this recipe! text:
Yum,Yum!! This is a excellent recipe!! The sauce is what makes this recipe different from others. I did add a little pepper and parsley to the sauce once it was completed, and before pouring over the chicken. My sauce didn't seperate as others had mentioned. I used 4" bamboo skewers to hold my chicken together. I also cut the chicken in half,(width wise),instead of pounding. This way made it easier to wrap the chicken. This is going in my recipe box!! My husband loved it! Thanks for a great, easy, quick recipe!

text:
I made this for my neighbors and they said it was good.  I did not try it because I don't eat meat, but it smelled delicious. I substituted half & half. I have to say that 6 tablespoons of butter was too much, the chicken seemed to be poaching in butter and the sauce was extremely oily looking when it was prepared. I should have poured off most of the grease, but I didn't, so I ended up trying to blot the big greasy areas with paper towels.  Smelled wonderful, tasted "good" to my neighbors and looked very greasy that's why I gave it 4 stars.

text:
This recipe is awesome! I was very surprised! I made it thinking I would hate it. Then I saw all the reviews and thought wow this many people liked it. I probably will too. 
 Key to sauce is blending in the cornstarch with the whipping cream before pouring it in to the pan so you have no lumps. You may consider adding a little pepper to the sauce maybe a dash of salt. Try before adding as everyones tastes are different.
In fact it was so good I had the left over for breakfast.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The sauce was absolutely delicious, and went amazingly well with steamed asparagus and green beans sauteed in butter and garlic. I baked the chicken instead of frying it, only because my boyfriend insisted, and it turned out a little dry - but that was definitely my mistake; I won't make it next time. I also substituted chick broth for white wine, as I had none on hand and we're not drinkers. 

The sauce I just threw together in a saucepan while the chicken was baking - the butter, chicken broth, chicken bouillon, cream, and corn starch - and some flour to help with the thickening.

All in all, this was the first fancy meal I ever prepared by myself; usually, my boyfriend cooks! I made it for my family, and there were compliments all around - especially, as I said, the sauce. This recipe is definitely a keeper. :)

text:
This was a welcome change from regular old chicken cordon bleu (which mine always seems to turn out dry).  I was eager to try the sauce and that's what made this recip!  I did have to change a few things to fit what I had on hand in my kitchen.  I substituted milk for the whipping cream (and I probably wouldn't have used the cream if I'd had it, to cut the fat, milk worked fine) and I didn't have any chicken bouillon, so I added a bit a seasoned salt, pepper and garlic/herb seasoning to taste.  Also did not use all of the milk/cornstarch mixture, it dulled the taste down adding too much and I had to add more wine and seasonings.  So, I'd reccommend adding that just to taste.  Very good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at a Chicken Cordon Bleu recipe and my fiance declared it the best meal I've ever made (and that's saying a lot as he generally loves my cooking!). I followed other reviewer's suggestions and prepared the chicken ahead of time so that it could chill.  Once I was ready to begin cooking, I breaded the chicken a second time as it came out with a really great crispy crust.  One alteration--instead of transferring the chicken onto a warm platter, I put it in a non-stick skillet with some butter-flavored Pam to crisp the chicken back up as it gets a little
soggy cooking with the wine sauce.  Also, I only made 2 chicken breast and we had just enough sauce for the 2 breast and little to go with our steamed asparagus.  I would suggest doubling or tripling the sauce recipe if making the full 6 chicken breasts as indicated in the recipe.  Thanks Behr for a great recipe!  Due to the high fat content, we'll probably only make this for special occassions but it was great! Thanks again!

text:
This is very good but it's the sauce that's the star of the show and there is not enough of it for six servings.  I will definitely double the sauce next time.  You certainly don't have to make these into rolls (mine never turn out good and I lose a lot of cheese).  Instead, cook pounded chicken breasts  and when the sauce is done, return the chicken to the pan, top it with ham and swiss and put the cover on until melted.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason I didn't give this recipe a 5 star (I would have given 4 1/2!) was because it was a little more involved than I expected.  That said, I followed the recommendations of others and started on the stovetop browing for about 10 minutes and put in the oven at 350 for 20 minutes, unvocered.  I doubled the sauce,  blended the wine, about 3 tblsp butter and chicken bullion on the stove, then added the cream and cornstarch mixture.  When I took the chicken out of the oven, I put the pan back on the stove, brought the drippings to a simmer and added the cream mixture.  I let that simmer for about 5 minutes, stirring constantly.  I served with rice.  Very good -- just a little time consuming for a week-night meal!!  Thanks!
