city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my Christmas Eve dinner.  We had 12 quests coming so I did a trial run a few days before the 24th.  Thank Goodness for the trial run.  We thought the chicken was excellent, but the sauce very poor. It was more like a very thick gravy that didn't have the right taste to compliment the chicken.  I  doubled (because we were having a homemade pasta as well) and substituted the following for the sauce: 1/2 cup real butter,1 1/2 cups very dry white wine, 4 chicken bouillon cubes, 2 large pks of cream cheese, 2 1/2 cups of whole cream, 1 tsp. paprika, and 1/2 tsp white pepper.  It was a very good sauce...my guests were raving about it.

text:
I give this recipe 4 stars only because I modified it with another recipe from this site.  I changed the sauce slightly and then baked in the oven.  After the chicken was browned in the pan, I transferred it to a 9x13 pan and mixed the wine, bouillan and heavy cream with a can of cream of mushroom soup, warmed it and poured it over the top of the chicken and baked for 30 minutes.  It turned out really well!!!!  Will make this again soon!!!

Great Recipe!  I double the wine, bouillon, whipping cream and cornstarch (actually I even add a little extra bouillon for more taste) and use it on bow tie pasta. Just be careful to get all the toothpicks out of the chicken before you serve :-)

text:
Excellent! I made this for a small gathering of family and friends. It was easy to make and tasted fantastic! The compliments continued long after dinner was over! I followed the recipe for the most part exactly, except forgot to roll the chicken in the flour, so to catch myself up, I sprinkled the chicken while it was browning with paprika and it was fine. I didn't have any plain toothpicks and had to use colored ones, and some of the dye came out on the meat! I will definitely NOT do that again! I also added about triple the amount of cornstarch (3T) to thicken the sauce a little more. But overall, this was wonderful!!! 5++++ stars!

userID:
864635
Display Name:
Joan
isPro:

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm on a low-carb diet, so I tried this one out with minor modifications. I'm also not a very good cook, so the low rating may be my own fault. First, I cooked only 2 breasts, cutting the recipe to 1/3. I did not use flour, instead sprinkling the chicken lightly with paprika and sauteed it in a frying pan before baking at 350 for 20 minutes. I stirred all sauce ingredients together and cooked that separately (very easy and quick) in the same pan as I browned the chicken so some paprika mixed in. I added the cheese and ham on the top of the chicken the last 2 minutes of baking which worked out fine and was much simpler (for those of us not skilled in the wrapping, tying, etc.). In any case, I found the sauce to be much too rich -- way too much greasy. I think if I tried it again, I'd use almost no butter, and maybe milk or half-and-half for the base instead of heavy whipping cream. My boyfriend passed on the sauce entirely, saying that it was "too buttery." It's only fair to say that I grew up on very bland, low-fat foods, so my taste buds may not be evolved enough for such decadence. Thanks for the recipe anyway.
Review:

5

text:
I like the flavor, but the execution is off. First, the wine is too much and had to be drained afterwards. Secondly, I would swap half the butter with olive oil to keep it from burning like someone else suggested. It wasn't crispy enough, so I'd suggest upping the flour amount until you can actually coat and dredge and pan fry it. You really do need a very very long chicken breast as it's somewhat hard to fold over and complete. Thank god for the toothpicks. It'll do, but the recipe needs some work.

text:
I made this for my wife and I for the first time last night, and could not have been happier. Chicken came out wonderful and still tender, and the sauce that this makes is phenomenal. My wife and I agreed that this was the best new recipe we have made in a long time.

I followed the recipe very closely. The only additions I made was a bit of salt and pepper both on the chicken prior to assembling them, and a bit more in the flour/paprika mixture. I also only had light cream (recipe calls for heavy), but the sauce was still wonderfully rich. Will absolutely make this again.

text:
Delicious.  Made a few changes...nothing big.  Fried the chicken in the butter as directed but only for 10 minutes and then added the wine and a teaspoon of Better then Bouillon and cooked 5 minutes more.  Then transferred them to a 9x13 and cooked in the oven at 300 for 30 minutes.  When you make the sauce, try 2 tablespoons of Wondra instead of  cornstarch.  It works the same but will never be lumpy.  Super tasty recipe!

userID:
24070061
Display Name:
Aileen Lisette
isPro:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an amazing recipe, but I did change it after reading several reviews. First off, it took forever to pound 6 thick chicken breasts, so next time I will use chicken cutlets. After laying the ham and a slice of swiss (cut in half)on the breast and securing with a toothpick, I rolled chicken breasts in 1 whisked egg and then bread crumbs. I fried the breasts in 3 tbl of butter and 3 tbl of olive oil. After they were browned on all sides, I put the pan in a 350 degree oven for 40 minutes. While the chicken was in the oven, I made the sauce. In a sauce pan,  I mixed 1 c. of white wine, about 2 tsp of chicken bullion, a dash of black pepper and paprika and 2 tbl of butter. In a separate bowl,  I then mixed 2 cups of cream with 3 tbl of cornstarch. I whisked it into the sauce pan until thickened. I poured the sauce over the chicken when it was time for dinner. Next time, I will follow the recipe exactly and see which one tastes better.

SZYQ1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe for Chicken Cordon Bleu! The sauce is delicious with the chicken. It's a 5 star recipe, but Chicken Cordon Bleu always has breadcrumbs, hence the 4 star rating from me. This recipe was easy to substitute for my dietary restrictions (lactose intolerant, gluten free, and egg free). My substitutes if anyone with the same issues needs it and have been avoiding this recipe were GF AP flour, earth balance butter, GF vegetable bouillon (I was out of chicken), unsweetened coconut creamer (next time Id just use coconut or almond milk). I did use GF and egg free breadcrumbs and to apply the breadcrumbs, I dredged in flour as directed and brushed on a little coconut creamer. As I can tolerate some hard cheeses, I tried using an imported gruyere that contained 0gm sugar and was actually labeled lactose free. It worked perfectly and was delicious. Despite these changes for my needs, I followed all measurements exactly and have no doubt this recipe works very well as written and tastes even better if you can handle the ingredients. Served with grilled asparagus and really enjoyed this chicken cordon bleu! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Being pretty new to cooking I decided to challenge myself with this dish. After researching several recipes and sauces, I decided to tweak a few things while cooking. The sauce could have used twice the amount of cornstarch in order to really thicken itthis could be due to the amount of wine/butter mixture left over from the pan. I also added in a few other ingredients to the sauce to kick the flavor up a notch: pepper, minced garlic, Dijon mustard, and bit of shaved onion! I also could have saved myself 20+ minutes of slicing by simply buying chicken cutlets instead of the breasts itself hahaha :) Was slightly disappointed I didnt think to add bread crumbs to the outsidenext time Ill give that a try. Overall received raving reviews on this one, I just wish I had breaded it!!

userID:
10509020
Display Name:
toosxz4me
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3

20
favoritesCount:
303
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1024407.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG!!! So delicious!!! I do agree with one rater that the directions should stay the same, but at the same time, it's a matter of taste! I coated the chicken (5 pieces) with 1 egg and some seasoning. I added honey turkey to 3 and honey ham to 2 of them along with the swiss cheese, making sure to put the cheese in the middle and not on top. Then I rolled it in bread crumbs. Then I simmered it in half butter half olive oil, but I DID NOT add the wine or boullion at that point. After cooking it for about 15 min browning it on all sides, I removed it from skillet, placed in a pan lined with foil, poured the sauce from the pan on top of it and baked it for 20 min. I just prefer baking as opposed to all skillet cooking. While it was baking, I made the sauce. I tripled the sauce because of other reviews, and I'm glad I did. I poured 3 cups of Heavy Cream, 1 1/2 cups of white wine, 3 tbsp of cornstarch and 2 bullion cubes with a sprinkle of paprika for color. After whisking it for about 3 min, I added it to a pot and cooked it on med high for about 5 min. I let it sit for about 5 min until it thickened. Then I added some sauce to the chicken and kept the remaining sauce for the white Basmati rice and asparagus! It was a sensation!!! The family said it was the best  they ever had. Thank you so much for your recipe. It is a dish that will hit home every single month from now on.

Churchlady

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall this was a hit at my dinner party. I made this exactly as the recipe said. It was very good and the chicken stayed moist but it was bland. Either salting the chicken or putting salt in the flour/ paprika mix with other spices such as pepper, oregano, thyme, etc  might help. I thought the bouillon and wine would give it enough salt and flavor but I didnt think it did.  Also I bought chicken breasts from Costco which were very thick. It was hard to pound them to a 1/4 inch and roll. I would suggest getting thin cutlets to start and pound them even thinner. Finally the sauce was easy to make. I worry about it thickening enough and not being runny but with heavy cream it thickens just by heating and stirring. Again I didnt think it had enough flavor except richness. I would try again to add a shredded cheese like a sharp white cheddar to give it some more flavor.
Review:

5

text:
I made this and almost followed the recipe exactly. Instead of keeping the chicken in the pan for the 30 minutes to cook, I transferred it into the oven for 18 minutes at 350 after I browned the sides . I pounded the chicken very flat and also split each breast into two pieces versus one. I really loved the rich and creamy sauce and was amazed at how great the chicken tasted. I paired this recipe with broccoli and rice. I double the sauce so I could use it to drizzle over the rice as well. Delicious recipe, would definitely make it again. My son and husband absolutely adored it!

text:
stuck to the recipe. Rolling pounded out chicken with cheese and ham was a bit more challenging than it appeared on the video. Kept to the pan no oven baking. But the sauce was really good. Probably heavy handed the wine a smidgen. Served with sauteed mushrooms in garlic butter, steamed broccoli florets and jasmine rice. As Guy Fieri likes to say, "I'd put that sauce on a flip flop and eat it". 
I'll pound the chicken thinner and keep the pieces smaller next time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so easy and relatively quick to make, certainly quick to prepare.  We did make a few mostly minor changes. We pounded the chicken to about a 1/2 inch thick. I used 2 slices of honey ham (all we had) and 3 slices of Swiss per breast, then tied up with butcher string and dipped in paparika+flour as directed. I seared in an oven safe skillet with butter and oil, then stuck in the oven til temp read 165*. 
For the sauce, I was lazy and also didn't have any wine on hand. I did cream, about a half teaspoon of chicken bullion and dijon to taste. Let the sauce simmer a bit and it thickens just fine.  I didn't even need to add any additional salt to this dish. I will use black forest or something besides honey ham next time as well, but will make again!

country:
None
text:
Such a good dish!! The measurements are spot on, and the video helps a ton. Just have one tip, however: when making the sauce, make sure theres no burnt pieces of chicken or melted cheese leftover. If there is, not a big deal. The sauce is meant to be the mixture of white wine, butter, corn starch and whipping cream so the burnt pieces and cheese wont make it as rich and creamy. Other than that, this is a great dish for so many occasions. Love it.

text:
love this recipe!! I've made this several times now and I make it as stated every time. Tips for storing leftovers- STORE SAUCE SEPARATELY from chicken and warm sauce on the stovetop prior to serving.  Do not use the microwave.  I can't explain it, it's just not as good. 
I recommend ensuring you use thicker slices of ham rather than a thin slice.  Can hardly taste the ham when using thinner slices.  I go straight to the deli and ask them for medium to thick cuts of ham (worth it!)

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This tasted great, using some suggestions by other reviewers. (Spread some spicey brown mustard on the chicken before laying down the ham and cheese,  adding smoked paprika to flour coating, also then dipped in beaten egg wash, rolling in Panko crumbs  with chopped parsley,  lightly browning the rolls...mine were like blobs...in canola oil, and making the sauce separately while the rest baked in the oven 30 minutes. All the guests loved it.
It was not easy to assemble, handling slippery wet raw chicken and wrestling with the rolling up and tying string process was messy and difficult.  The Swiss cheese slices I had were too thick to roll easily.  Still, it was a very satisfying main dish for a family gathering together.  (Also had to tell everyone to be aware of string pieces as I couldnt remove the  completely.)

text:
This recipe was over-the-top awesome! I did make a few changes though. I used 4 chicken breasts since there were only four people and I used 2 tablespoons of butter and two tablespoons of olive oil. I slit the chicken in half and salted them to absorb the moisture and patted them dry. Then placed the cheese and ham on them and rolled them up and dipped them in egg wash and breadcrumbs with salt and pepper. I finished them in the oven and made the sauce without the chicken bouillon and added salt and pepper and they turned out awesome. My family loved it sooo much that they wanted me to make it again. This will definitely be one of my go-to recipes for sure. Thank you for the recipe.

text:
I can not describe how thrilled I was with this recipe!  While it sounds and tastes like an incredible complex meal, it was surprisingly quick and easy.  My red meat loving husband rolled his eyes when I said I was making chicken for dinner...then proceeded to eat 3 servings and request 2 more for lunch the next day!  The only changes I made were using an egg dredge with ground pork rinds instead of flour or breadcrumbs since my husband eats a primarily keto diet.  I also did the stovetop browning for 10 mins + oven baking (350 at 25-30 mins) method and it came out perfect.  We served with a side of riced cauliflower and broccoli topped with that incredible sauce.  This will absolutely be finding its way to our table again soon!!!

text:
Simple, easy, and wonderful, especially if youbtweak it a bit.  

Be sure to pound the breasts to a consistent 1/4 inch. Go easy on the boullion or it will be very salty - peobably best to substitute real chicken broth. And, if youre like me, add a tablespoon of vermouth or white cooking wine to the sauce AFTER you take it off the stove and it will be amazing.

text:
The fianc and I both loved this dish!  It was awesome.  I browned the chicken in the pan first and finished in the oven.  I added prosciutto, and that added an extra level of flavor.  I may have messed up the sauce, I added the wine to the pan I used to brown chicken with butter and then it deglazed, I then added the cream and cornstarch, it came out more like a gravy.  After we had gotten done and I was cleaning up, I realized I left out the bouillon granules, but it was still an excellent dish.  Will definitely make again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6823763.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! We loved it! I took advice from 2 other cooks but the changes would not change the outcome or taste of the recipe. I pounded the chicken breast to about 1/4 inch thick This helped aid in rolling the ham & cheese up in the chicken which I secured with a toothpick or two. I browned the chicken in a skillet on all sides except for the ends. Once browned I placed in covered baking pan and finished them off in a 350 oven for 15 - 20 minutes. In the mean time I made sauce using wine and rest of sauce ingredients combining with drippings in the skillet. I made 1/2 again as much sauce, as I always like extra. Only change was I used fat free half n half in place of the heavy whipping cream. I served it with wild rice and we poured sauce over all. Even the leftovers heated up nicely and did not dry out. The chicken was very juicy and the flavor was wonderful! While definitely be making this many times in the future.

text:
So, the reason Im giving this recipe 5 stars is, I didnt have any ham so I substituted turkey lunchmeat. I had no heavy cream so I used organic skim milk. Instead of chicken bullion I had beef. Also, I had no dry white wine and used cooking sherry instead. Just for kicks I threw in some capers. 
Although I tried really hard to screw up this recipe it turned out really well!! Therefore 5 stars!

Made this last night for our crew of 5 adults / 2 kids 9 & 4.  Only change I made was placing chicken breasts in a baking dish after searing/browning off in the skillet.  Put them in the oven with the wine/bouillon mixture and covered tightly with foil.  350 @ 20-25 mins ( these were huge breasts)  Made wine/mushroom risotto and added a side of steamed green beans.  E V E R Y O N E loved it  The kids wanted more - everyone wanted more.  Will most definitely make again but next time I will use butchers twine instead of toothpicks.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this recipe quite a few times now. Always comes out very delicious and my family loves it. This will remain my go to Cordon Bleu recipe! :)

This last time I didn't have any heavy whipping cream, so I mixed half a cup of Greek yogurt (Fage) and half a cup of whole milk, strained it after a good mixing, and used that instead. Came out just as good! 

I also have used both the regular Paprika (smokey) and Hungarian Paprika (sweet) in this recipe. I prefer the Hungarian Paprika, as it gives it a very nice balance of flavor and gets rid of some of the tartness of the wine and cream (you can find it in European markets, if not at your regular grocers, if you'd like to try). 

For those saying that their sauce curdled, the general rule of thumb is to temper the cream and cornstarch mixture before adding it to the hot liquids. You can do this by adding one teaspoon at a time, hot to cold, to bring the temperature up before adding to the pan.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love the sauce for this. I pound chicken breasts but use mozzarella slices instead of Swiss .  I add some paprika to flour and after rolling cheese and ham and securing the chicken breasts, dip in flour mixture then beaten eggs and then coat in bread crumbs. I lightly cook in a frying pan with butter until all sides of the chicken are browned. I remove the breasts and put them in a casserole dish and put them uncovered in the oven on 350 for about 30 to 40 minutes. Last 10 minutes I use the same pan with drippings and make the sauce. I pour the sauce over the cooked breast to serve. Amazing on mashed potatoes as well!

I made it with a slight Kiev variation. Instead of just the flour, I add an egg wash and light bread crumbs. I then browned them in the pan and moved to a 9x11 baking dish where I added the white wine mixture and baked for 25 minutes at 400. I used the pan that I browned them in to make the heavy cream mixture with another splash of Sauvignon Blanc!  Tasty

text:
First attempt, surely 5 stars.  A bit of work.  Used Panko breadcrumbs instead of flower.  Double sauce.  Started in skillet, when brown switch to baking dish and cook in oven 350 until done (20-30min).   Used skillet to make sauce, did add S&P and a little nutmeg.  It will be repeated.  Note:  if you do six (I did 3) you might want to triple the sauce.   Also I did all prep, including rolling,  well in advance.  Pan to table less than an hour.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I adapted this recipe quite a bit. I did do the flour but added salt and pepper. After the flour I put it in egg then in panko. I browned it in the pan, then removed and dis the butter, wine and dissolved the bullion. I put the chicken in a baking dish and poured the butter wine sauce over. Cooked for about 40 minutes. When I pulled it out I put the chicken on a platter to rest and put the drippings in a skillet. I added some extra wine, cream, Parmesan, and corn starch and let it reduce down. Then served it over the chicken, and had enough extra to do a drizzle over the roasted asparagus and potatoes. It was great! I give the recipe 3 stars because I adapted it but the results were 5!

country:
None
text:
Fantastic!  OK, I tried to stay true to the original recipe, but I did make some changes based on personal preferences.  The flavors in this are SO good.  

Took a few tips from other reviewers and baked the chicken after I pounded the chicken breasts and browned the rolled up breasts.  I cooked the sauce separately.  I did use red rind Gouda cheese as I don't like Swiss.  For the sauce, I made a roux with 2 tablespoons butter, 2 tablespoons flour, 2 chicken bouillon cubes, 1/2 C white wine and 2 C heavy cream.  I never have much luck with cornstarch.  The sauce was extremely tasty!  This got RAVE reviews from the family and I am positive I will make this again and again.  Thank you,  Behr!!

text:
I made this for the first time last night. I've only had chicken cordon Bleu once when I was in high school and remembered it was good.  I figured I'd try my hand at making this fancy dish. Pounding the chicken took a while, I used a wooden rolling pin. I just used some deli baked ham and some generic swiss,  and it did come out really well. My husband (who is very picky) and his friend both really liked it. In fact,  my husband's plate was quite clean when he finished which is unusual,  he usually leaves bits on his plate. I used a sweet reisling wine instead of dry sherry  but I think that was the only major difference to the recipe that I did.  I paired it with garlic mashed red potatoes and corn/green beans in butter and salt/pepper.  

Very glad I tried this recipe. Even amateur home cooks can make delicious "fancy" meals like this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Beyond AWESOME !!!  ... That Sauce... MIND BLOWN !!
Did a Google image search for Chicken Cordon Bleu..  Hadn't made it for awhile, and I like to check out new recipes.... liked the picture...  clicked, then was intrigued by the Sauce...  Original plan was to scale down to  2 servings, but breasts were so thick i butterflied them into 4 servings.. after the flour dredge, I did an egg dip, then Panko... Have had too many problems with toothpicks .  So now I use a Singer heavy duty canvas/leather sewing needle  and cotton cord/cooking twine..  and sew em closed.. ..   Works amazing..  just be sure it's all cotton, no synthetics/coating.. after the 30 minutes, pulled out chicken..  and any black bits of panko..  added the whipping cream, stirred, scraping up as much of the fond  off the bottom of my stainless pan as i could with my silicone coated whisk......  ground some salt and black pepper into it.....   Gotta say..  That sauce Blew my Freakin Mind...  so much so, I could care less that it's 40% FAT..  I WILL BE making this again..  and again... and again.. It is now a Permanent Printed Recipe in my kitchen..  to make every couple months..

text:
Made this fabulous recipe as written EXCEPT....I made a pocket in the chicken breasts (thickest part) and angled it down so that once "stuffed" and cooked the cheese wouldn't run out.  Braised them on the cooktop until browned then finished in the oven with another splash of wine.  Just terrific.  Oh and I also wrapped the ham around the cheese to give me the best chance to keep the cheese inside the breasts and just placed it into the pouch. Easy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4113941.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish is very tasty but I made a couple modifications- 
I used 3 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil and 1 tablespoon of butter instead of the recommended 6 tablespoons of butter. 
I did an egg wash with almond milk prior to tossing the chicken breasts in the flour and paprika.
I added garlic and onion powder to the flour and paprika mix.
I added a bit of pepper to the stuffing (ham and swiss).
I added some smoked sea salt and ground pepper to the whipping cream. 
Lastly, I added a bit more ham and cheese then recommended.  Cheese usually flows out as it's being cooked so by adding a bit more cheese, it really made a difference.
It turned out great and I will for sure make this dish again!

5

text:
I cook a recipe roughly as directed (unless I happen to spot a concern).  With the exception of adding a few glugs of olive oil with the butter, I left this recipe unchanged.   If you don't use the oil, you won't realize a proper medium high to high heat sear on the chicken which adds flavor and appearance.

text:
WOW! Make this for company as it will definitely impress!   I had every intention of seasoning the chicken breasts with salt, pepper and garlic powder because I thought they would turn out bland, but I ended up forgetting and you know what? They surprisingly came out bursting with flavor! The sauce is absolutely delicious. I followed the recipe to a T and wouldn't change a thing except maybe the cook time.   I seared mine about 4 mins each side, then simmered for about 20 mins total. They came out super juicy.  I had pounded the breasts down to about 1/2".   This is going in my regular rotation!

text:
So easy and yet so yummy. I had to adjust recipe according to what I had on hand and what my kids would eat.  So after banging up two chicken breasts, I folded up ham slices with cheese and salami (as I didn't have smoked ham on hand).  I drenched all sides and inside the chicken with chicken broth mixed with a little bit of onion powder before heating on stove top for 10 minutes.  Next time I'm going to put the chicken in the oven for 30-35 minutes.  And next time I'm going to cut a slit in the chicken breast before pounding it :)

text:
Fantastic recipe! I will make this again. Everyone loved it. I followed the ingredients exactly as the recipe states. The sauce is to die for! The one minor thing I did differently was I made the sauce in a small pot and let simmer for about 5 minutes first. I cooked the chicken for about 10 min in the pan, placed them in a casserole dish, put the sauce on top and finished them off in the oven @ 375 for 20 min. They were cooked perfectly. Not overdone. Mine were quite thick. About 4" high so I was afraid they would be undercooked in the frying pan. This was turned out perfect.

favoritesCount:
1028
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this!  So easy to make!  After reading a few reviews I changed the process a bit. I pounded my breast halves thinner, use prosciutto instead of ham (made rolling a breeze), and tied it with kite string (so much easier than using toothpicks), and used breadcrumbs.  I also started this on the stove halving oil to butter, transferred to a casserole dish and finished in the oven at 350 for 30 min. PERFECT!  I then finished the sauce in the pan so it could pick up the flavor from browning the chicken. Oh and I added the paprika to the sauce not the bread crumbs. Kids were skeptical but raved over it.  It would have been delicious as it's written this process just felt easier for me. Served with asparagus and spaghetti squash. Outstanding!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-04-02T23:04:27.09

I made enough for 15 adults who RAVED about my cordon bleu. Some were kosher, so, following other sites, I opted for smoked turkey. I used the one-minute Hollandaise Sauce (amazing - and quick!!) for a little drizzle on this and the asparagus. Perfect for my "French Cuisine" Night of Romance!! With the left overs, I chopped all up and put in a deep casserole dish, added a bunch of spinach and added stuffing to the leftover broth mixture, put ontop and added the leftover hollandaise to that. Sooooo good!!

text:
I will most definitely be making this again. I read where some people were concerned about the cheese melting out.  What does melt out incorporated nicely into the sauce.  For the sauce, I used white cooking wine.  The only thing I did which varied from the instructions was that I butterflied 2 large chicken breasts and cut them in half, making 4 pieces.  They were easy to pound out that way and manageable in size. Both my husband and I were thrilled with the taste, and we're appreciative of good quality, tasty and easy recipes!

My Family Loved this so much they made extra trips to my room that night to knock on the door just to tell me how amazing this was! One thing  I did that maybe others might want to watch out for as well. Make sure you slice the ham VERY thin if you choose to slice it yourself. I used turkey ham and made it far too thick and had trouble closing them. Took several tooth pics and a lot of ingenuity! I also added some extra wine and butter when it seemed a little too dry while browning.

I have made this twice. We love it! It's actually not that hard. Even made it on a work night. The first time I made it as is and it was so good. The flavors all meld together. text:
This is a great recipe! You HAVE to cook to your own tastes though. For me, the amount of cream was too much. I liked a much stronger wine flavor, more better than bouillion, and i like to saute a bit of garlic before i deglaze the pan with a chardonnay. Also, instead of rolling, i cut a slit in the side of the chicken and tuck a big ole hunk of swiss wrapped in ham. With a few toothpicks to seal it up, the leaky cheese problem is fixed. I brown at med/high heat and then transfer to the oven- 350 for about 20 minutes.

text:
I made only very minor changes to the recipe. I gave it a test run about a week ahead and had some trouble rolling the chicken after I pounded it. I use a gallon ziplock bag cut down the side, as it holds up well to pounding. I would like to say a huge 'Thank you!' to the reviewer who suggested rolling the chicken rolls into plastic wrap and twisting the ends shut, like Tootsie Rolls, then refrigerating them. (sorry, I couldn't find the review again) When I removed the roll from the wrapping it was easy to handle as I rolled it in flour, paprika, salt and pepper. I used butter and olive oil to brown the chicken, then transferred to a casserole to finish cooking through while I made the sauce.  Delicious! My guests agree.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay I have made this recipe at the very least twice a month for the past 2 years. This is my kids (7 and 8) favorite meal. They beg me to make it every week. As with most people I do tweak it to suit our tastes. The changes I make are as follows. 1. I like to use smoked provolone instead of swiss it is amazing!  2. Instead of just flouring the outside of the chicken I do a more traditional breading of flour, egg, panko bread crumbs. 3. After I have browned all sides of the chicken I move it to a 350 degree oven to finish cooking . It normally times out perfectly to be cooked just right by the time I have made the sauce. The 4th and final change I make is I ALWAYS double the sauce. There has never been a time when we didn't eat every bit of the sauce. We always eat this with white rice, it's a hit every time!

userID:
5303136
Display Name:
Natalie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/461202.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious - very easy.  I used a package of 3 large skinless, boneless breasts.  Sliced breasts in half, put between plastic wrap and pounded each until about a half inch thickness give or take.  Did not have to use toothpicks.  Rolled swiss and ham with chicken, rolled in seasoned flour, then egg with a little chicken broth added, then rolled in panko holding bundle together throughout.  Placed individually in plastic wrap and put into fridge until ready to cook.  Did not use wine, all chicken broth instead, no granules.  Used half and half, and browned chicken in half butter half olive oil.  Ended up with 6 bundles, plenty of sauce.  Four of us, had two bundles left over.  Will definitely be making again!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-11-09T19:15:06.32
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
6450652
Display Name:
veganmama
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I did make some changes though. My biggest complaint with any cheese stuffed chicken dish is seepage so, first I butterflied the chicken and continued to slice completely in half. I gently pounded my pieces of chicken until they were as thin as I could get them without tearing... about 1/4" or even less. Then I sprinkled with fresh ground salt and pepper. When adding the cheese and ham, I left a good 1 1/2" on both sides allowing me to fold in the sides before rolling, making sure that everything was tucked in.  After they were all rolled up, I tightly rolled them up in saran wrap twisting the ends like a tootsie roll and I placed them in the freezer for 30 min. After removing the saran wrap, I had a nice tight roll with no exposed cheese or ham. I then rolled them in flour, egg and breadcrumbs. To cut down on the fat, I browned them in a mixture of butter and olive oil. After browning them on all sides, I baked them for 25 min. There was no cheese seepage and they turned out perfect! The sauce was amazing as well! I added torn basil at the end. I'll be making this again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

The only thing I can say is, OH MY GOSH! This is delicious! I surprised my husband with a nice dinner at home last night and he was extremely happy! He just kept going on and on about it. I used Sauvignon Blanc as well. Also, I didn't have whipping cream and used half and half. The only other change I made was to mix about 1/4 cup panko crumbs and 1/2 t garlic salt in with the flour mixture. Then instead of finishing it on the stove, I just covered the iron skillet I started cooking them in and baked it in the oven at 350 for 30 minutes. I will make this again and again!

text:
This is a great base recipe.  So simple.  I used 1/2c chicken broth with a splash of white wine.  I also used skim milk instead of cream and it was healthier and delicious.   I added 1 tsp of salt to the sauce at the end with some dried basil.  I simmered the chicken in the broth for 15 minutes and then placed the chicken in a dish of steamed broccoli, poured the sauce over the top and baked for 20 minutes.  Served over rice.  My family loved it!

text:
This is delicious! I used much less paprika in the flour coating (like, 1/4 a teaspoon) because I didn't want it to be too spicy. Also, I ran out of toothpicks so I used cooking twine; it worked well. Mine only took about 20 minutes to cook but maybe that's because all I could find in the store was chicken cutlets. The sauce is amazing! I served it with roasted potatoes and radishes. Will definitely be making this again! Thanks for the great recipe!! :)

Display Name:
Angel Sowatskey

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2917308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed some things because my chicken breast pieces were organic free-range and very small.  Instead of stuffing the chicken, I flattened it, breaded it and cooked it with the butter, wine and bouillon, then transferred the pieces to a casserole dish, covered them with crumbled bacon and layered baby Swiss on top.  I put the aluminum foil covered dish in the oven at 350 for about ten minutes while I prepared the cream sauce.  (I added a few extras to the cream as well for flavor.). After the cheese was fully melted I removed the chicken and poured the cream sauce over it and served it.  It was delicious and I think I'd rather do it this way only because I'm not great at stuffing things.

Good base recipe. I cut 3 rather thick breasts in 1/2 length wise and flattened them some. They were all right at a 1/2" precooked thickness. I used a Pinot Grigio and added a splash more than what was called for and let them go the whole 30 minutes covered on low ... they came out just a touch dry. The sauce came out great.

Just to switch it up some, I'll use an egg dip and maybe some Panko bread crumbs the next time.

text:
I've made this a couple times before.  However I too,  baked it instead of pan cooking.  350 for 30 mins.  Still moist,  but the next time I'll do 25 mins. Made 6 by halving 3 breasts and used bread crumbs with the paprika.  I used a smoky hot paprika.  Like I said,  I've made this a couple times  prior,  and I just can't get sold on the sauce like most.....I just find it meh and a little too salty.  This time I added some dijon and thyme....still just meh :( maybe next time I give it a little tarragon.  I'm always looking forward to this yummy sauce and I've yet to love it.  I like it,  but love is a bit strong emotion,  at least for me.  But the dish itself is great!  Also,  I make a little "burrito" with the cheese using the ham as my wrapper, then roll it up in the chicken.  Definitely  keeps the cheese from oozing out.

This recipe tastes fantastic but it costs too much to make. Next time, I'm going to use chewy bacon instead of ham to make it a little cheaper. Also, I felt like 30 minutes  on low was too long to cook them even though they were still tasty and tender. Maybe 20 to 25 minutes.

Display Name:
CURTISLEE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/169789.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it, as did my son Eric. I had eight chicken breasts, so I spread them out into two separate frying pans, then when reserving the chicken, I consolidated both pans into one to make the sauce. With more chicken than in the recipe, I doubled the sauce.  When the directions say, "Pound the chicken breasts if they are too thick," that's too vague.  "Pound the chicken breasts to 1/4 (or 1/2) inch would have been more instructive. It would have also been helpful to know the recommended thickness of the ham. Mine was a bit too thick, which made it hard to fold into the chicken. I may use string next time. Using tooth picks can be dangerous if one is missed and they really don't hold the chicken together as well as cooking twine would. My son was on a tight schedule, so I sped up the cooking time by increasing the burner temperature slightly. My 1/2 inch chicken breasts were done in 15 to 20 minutes. Despite these minor complaints, the recipe is top shelf, one of the best I've found at allrecipes and to date, I've prepared nearly 600 different ones since becoming a member many years ago.
Review:

5

text:
This was very good with changes per other reviewers. I brown the stuffed breast in the butter on the stove top and then finished them off in the oven at 350 degrees for approx. 20 minutes. I did need to use a little extra flour and paprika mixture for coating.  I also doubled the sauce and made it in the pan with the drippings using the 4 sauce ingredients & extra butter.  I served this with rice pilaf and steamed broccoli so the extra sauce went mixed in well with those side dishes. I have to mention that it was a pain trying to close the stuffed breasts with the toothpicks in the past so i used twine to close the chicken breasts instead.

text:
I took one skinless, boneless chicken breast and cut it evenly as filleting fish. With my left hand pressing on the chicken breast and right hand with a sharp knife cut each chicken breast horizonally in half. Then placed ham, then swiss cheese on top. Then carefully starting at one end, roll like you would a cresent roll. Secure with two toothpicks. Then follow the rest of instructions.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this with a few minor changes. We don't use alcohol in our cooking, so I substituted chicken broth for the wine and it worked out great (1 chicken bouillon cube with 1/2 cup water). The broth was salty and added nice flavor to the chicken and then to the cream sauce. I also fried the chicken in olive oil mixed with a couple tablespoons of melted butter which lets the chicken brown nicely without the extra fat. Since I love bread crumbs, I also sprinkled 2 teaspoons of that on top of the finished product before serving. These were fantastic and I'll definitely be making them again!

Yummy! I'm not sure if I wrapped the cheese and ham properly but most the cheese stayed in the chicken, and the cheese that melted out actually made the sauce taste even better. I flattened out the chicken and used 2 pieces of cheese and ham per breast. Since there is only 2 of us I halved the recipe but because of other reviewers raving about the sauce kept that the same and glad I did! It was great to pour over the chicken and the stuffing I made as a side. 

Next time may try getting smaller breasts and having more cheese than ham.

text:
This is a lovely, easy dish, that I've made dozens of times, with my own tweaks.  I do season the breading with a bit of garlic powder, and after browning the chicken, I put the pan in the oven to finish, making the sauce in the pan after removing the chicken to a warm platter.  I double the sauce.  My other trick is to use uncooked spaghetti noodles as my toothpick.   The pasta cooks into the meat and there is no string or toothpick to remove.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe is the "Chicken A La Suisse" recipe in the Good Housekeeping Cookbook from 1972 - with a few minor word changes but no changes to ingredients or amounts.  I have been making it for  over 40 years for Christmas Eve dinner and it's a family favorite and absolutely delicious!  Just be sure not to cook the sauce too long because it will break.  Enjoy!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the easiest & best dinner's I've ever made.  I cut a chunk of swiss cheese, wrapped it in a piece of pit ham (folding the ends in as I rolled) and then rolled the flattened chicken breast halve around it & secured with 2 toothpicks each.  The 3 T of flour worked out well, but I only used 3 chicken pieces for it so if I were to do 6, I would increase the flour & paprika.  I used Sauvignon Blanc for the wine & it all turned out beautifully.  We had a ton of sauce, but who doesn't love sauce on their meat?   I served with Asparagus with Balsamic Vinegar Butter sauce & baked potatoes.  Perfect meal for my Veteran on Veteran's day.  Thanks for sharing!!!!

userID:
11004433
Display Name:
Larissa Davis
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2740806.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for my husbands birthday dinner. This is what he wanted for dinner. I didn't think I'd like it, but I believe it turned out great. I did do a few changes. I used vegetable oil in a skillet on medium heat and I browned the chicken on all sides. Then I transferred it to a baking dish coated with nonstick spray. I baked it in the oven for 35 minutes at 350 F. While the chicken was baking I cleaned the skillet out and put in 1/4 cup of butter (1/2 a stick) and 1/4 cup of Olive Oil. This cuts down some of the fat. I added 2 chicken bouillon cubes and the wine. I let this cook on medium heat until the bouillon cubes dissolved. Then I whisked in the cream and cornstarch mixture to the wine sauce. I did put a pinch of salt and pepper and a little bit of garlic powder (not much, that stuff is potent!) I served this dish with green bean casserole and mashed potatoes. It was very good and I will be making this again!

5

userID:
2132613
Display Name:
Annie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
30
favoritesCount:
552
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5997770.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I purchased thin sliced chicken breasts which saved me the time of flattening chicken which was great! Rolled up cheese inside thin sliced deli black forest ham and secured with toothpick. Dipped in egg and then rolled in panko crumbs (about 2 cups) with paprika and pepper.  Put directly into a pyrex with buttered bottom and stuck in the fridge for a couple of hours while I got other parts of the meal ready. Baked at 375 (because I was also doing diced potatoes in oven that needed that temp). Baked for an hour covered with foil to keep in moisture. (I like my chicken tender enough to cut with fork and this was. Less cooking time would require to cut with knife). Made the sauce as written on the stovetop but took others advice and made 1.5 times amount. Because I was serving a crowd, took chicken from oven, sliced into 1-2 inch round slices, placed in a pretty serving dish and drizzled 1/2 - 3/4 of the sauce on top. Stuck back in oven (because we were waiting for some to arrive) and kept the rest of the sauce warm on stovetop. Normally I could have served at this point without putting back in oven. At serving time I put remainder of sauce in a gravy boat. People loved it. I served with garlic rosemary diced red potatoes and steamed broccoli. Delicious! Thank You!

Rating:
5

text:
Wow! This is a great recipe! One of the best I have ever made! 
I followed the recipe as close as I could. I decided to use almond flour with the paprika to coat the chicken. I did not have bullion cubes or the white wine so I used chicken stock in the pan when simmering. I also did not have corn starch so I used a little bit of flour instead. 
We had ours over cauliflower rice and it was absolutely fantastic! Low carb, not too high in calories and very tasty! Definitely will make again soon!

Display Name:
poshlynne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This made me look like I knew what I was doing, thanks to RHCULLEN's review.  I used 2 large chicken breasts.  I coated in egg and then a bread crumb mixture that included the paprika and some garlic powder.  I browned them on all sides in 3 tablespoons of butter in my cast iron skillet and then transferred the skillet to a 350 degree oven for 20 minutes.  I made half the sauce recipe by melting the remaining butter (which was half of 3 tablespoons), wine and bouillon in a small pan and then adding the cornstarch/cream mixture and simmering until thickened.  I sliced the chicken into 1 inch rounds and served with the sauce on top.  Yummy!

country:
None
text:
My sister in law and I made this for my brother and it turned out pretty well. We forgot to pound the chicken until the very end and it definitely makes a difference so try to remember to do that. I also didn't follow the recipe, I used a suggestion from a review. We rolled the chicken then used toothpicks to keep them together and dipped them in egg wash. We coated them with Panko and fried them until golden brown on every corner. We immediately put them in the oven for about 30 minutes. While the chicken was baking I made the sauce in the same pan with the drippings that I used to fry the chicken with. I'm not a big ham person so the taste got to me a little but everything else was perfect. you will want to double the ingredients of the sauce it's great!

text:
Pound the chicken breast to less than 1/2 inch thickness.  Roll lengthwise and tie with cooking string (makes it easier to roll around in the pan when browning).  Mix olive oil and butter as suggested, brown, then bake in the oven at 350 degrees for at least 20 minutes or until the chicken is no longer pink.  In the meantime heat the wine and 1/2 chicken cube with mushrooms if available, mix the heavy whipping cream with the cornstarch and add to the wine mixture, stir over medium low heat until thickened. Can add any fresh herbs available at this point. The servings are large, you will have left-overs, or can count on serving 2/3 breast/person by cutting into medallions.

text:
Amazing!  Absolutely amazing!  I followed the recipe exactly, with the following minor changes: I added a thin layer of Dijon mustard on the chicken, before layering on the ham and Swiss cheese (another user recommended this as a more authentic way of making the dish); I dredged the chicken in egg before coating with the flour and paprika mixture; I used about 1/3 cup of chicken broth instead of bouillon; and I used 2 tbs of corn starch to balance out the increased liquid from using the broth which increased the amount of sauce in the final product, which was definitely a great thing.  I will definitely be making this again!

I will definitely make again.

Display Name:
TaraB

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/954446.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since chicken is sold by the pound, not the # of breasts, I purchased 2.25 pounds.  I couldn't find the right poundage in breasts, so I bought thinly-sliced breasts instead.  They ended up being smaller and I had a lot more bundles, but I think eaters preferred the smaller size.  I ended up having more ham & Swiss per inch of chicken, which was also a good thing.  I did have some trouble sealing the bundles, though.  Some of them ended up being cups with toothpicks sticking out of the top like a porcupine.  Obviously, I wasn't able to sear the top of those bundles, but they cooked just fine.  No trouble with the sauce.

Display Name:
Angel7705

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe, and with some creativity, it can be made several ways. I don't coat the chicken with flour. It adds too many carbs to the meal and the fat content is already too high. I use half olive oil, half butter to cut some of the fat. I fry it quickly, just enough to brown the breasts, then remove and place in a baking pan. Instead of white wine, I use chicken broth mixed with the bouillon granules, and put it in the bottom of the baking pan. I also add a whole bunch of fresh garlic to this recipe. It makes it absolutely incredible, if you're a garlic fan! I slice cloves and roll them up with the chicken/ham/cheese. I add garlic slices to the chicken broth. And I also add minced garlic to the sauce. It's really, really good and a big hit every time I make it.

text:
Great!  I added a bit more chicken bouillon granules and a pinch of salt to the sauce. I also breaded the chicken instead of flour, and spiced up the breading with some onion and garlic powder and some basil.  I also follow some other recommendations and didn't simmer the chicken in the sauce, but made the sauce separate and poured it over the chicken after.  It came out delicious!

text:
I loved it and my boyfriend was so impressed. I took the advice of two reviews and mixed them together.  I used an egg before covering with flour mixture.  After browning on all sides I put it in a pan instead of leaving on the stove and added ingredients except substituted chicken broth for wine. Then baked at 350. It's easier to bake things with my son around the kitchen. I simmered the sauce by itself and added basil. I did make a mistake and bought mozzarella sliced cheese instead of swiss and loved it. This went well with the  allrecipe  for baked asparagus and parmesan  couscous (I used a box recipe)

text:
Huge hit at my dinner party! Said they felt like they were eating at a 5 Star restaurant!  My adaptations ~ used 1/2 butter and 1/2 olive oil for browning, added an egg wash between flour dips for extra crispy version, doubled the sauce portions, placed the cooked chicken in the oven at 350 degrees while preparing the sauce (kept them hot) and side dishes - this is served great with Salad, Spaetzle and fresh Haricots Verts French beans. What a keeper!

text:
This is one of our favorite recipes and is always a big win with company! The only thing I change up is that I butterfly chicken breast, and stuff them with two slices of cheese and ham. Secure them with tooth picks as well as possible so I don't loose the stuffing. Everything else is the same, however I would most definitely double the sauce and try not to cook the sauce for much longer then directed or you loose a lot of the wine flavor!

text:
Great recipe! I used Better Than Bouillon instead, basically the same thing. Be sure to use chicken cutlets or pound out your breasts thin to make rolling easier. When I make this I usually double the "sauce" by doubling wine, corn starch, whipping cream, & bouillon- the extra sauce goes well with diced boiled potatoes on the side, a great gravy! I usually use quite a few toothpicks to hold it all together, tricky to remove until it cools a bit. Impressive meal!

text:
This recipe was a hit last night for guests.  I did change some of the ingredients based on what I had on hand, but it still turned out really yummy.  Maybe some of these options will encourage you to try the recipe even if you don't have everything listed.
no wine: water worked for me (I did have oddly enough a little white wine vinegar and splashed some in...)
no swiss: mozzarella worked for me
no whipping cream: whole milk worked for me
I also seasoned each piece of meat with salt and pepper before rolling them up.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe.  I butterflied and then marinated the chicken breast for 24 hrs prior to cooking.  I marinated in a soy/ginger low fat dressing.  I also sliced up some fresh ginger for the marinade.  I know this sounds a bit off, but it added a great flavor.  Instead of frying the chicken for the entire time, I braised the chicken/ham/cheese in a skillet with the above ingredients before moving to the oven (cover) and cooking for about 20 mins.  I used the juices/droppings in the pan to make the wine sauce.  

My wife and son loved it and were already asking when would I be making it again.

text:
This recipe was just fantastic. I pretty much did exactly what I was told to do except for a few minor changes. I added Progresso bread crumbs to each side of the breasts, then the ham and finally the cheese. Afterwards, I sprinkled them still with the flour concoction up above. Then cooked them as suggested. When they were all done, I removed the chicken breasts, and began making the sauce. I used the grease that was in the pan to aid to the taste as well as putting a chicken bullion cube in it too!! It was scrumptious! They were gone that day and it was only two of us. Thanks so kindly.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The actual chicken cordon bleu was really tasty. I used fresh deli ham and Gruyere Swiss cheese from the deli. The flavors worked very well together and instead of flour I coated the chicken in egg and used seasoned bread crumbs. However, I did not like the amount of butter that was used to cook the chicken it was overpowering and some of it burned while it was cooking for a half hour. I also did not like the texture of the sauce. It basically tasted like thick butter and the consistency was weird. Next time I will use a reviewer's advice and use 3 TBS butter and 3 TBS EVOO, brown for 10 minutes in the skillet and finish cooking the oven at 350 while making the sauce separately.

text:
Delicious! You HAVE to make this. 
I love this recipe! It is AMAZING. I used Pinot Grigio for the dry white wine. 

Chicken: I baked it instead of pan fry and simmer. Used Italian bread crumbs with a teaspoon of the paprika instead of flour and paprika. Also, I put spinach leaves in the middle with the Swiss cheese and ham as shown in the picture. 

Sauce: Since I baked the chicken I just let the white wine and butter simmer for probably 15 minutes before adding the rest of the sauce ingredients.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved the flavor. I didn't make any changes since it was the first time. Next time I will try it with broth instead of wine. Unless you have a very large saucepan-like skillet with lid, or you really roll the chicken tight, you're only going to get 4 maybe 5 in a pan. I had to use two pans, and the second pan wasn't up to the task. You're frying with butter, so temperature control is paramount in not burning the butter; you need the right kind of saucepan-like skillet with lid to do this right. It was a tale of two batches for me. The one in the right skillet, cooked at the right temperature was perfect. Luckily, I was able to make the sauce with that non-scorched pan of butter and stock. I think the next time I make it, I will only make 4 servings, and it will be totally awesome. I'm a tough critic, and through it all, I got nothing but rave reviews from the family. Did I mention NOT burning the butter?

None
text:
I like this a lot, but it was missing "something."  Next time, I'll season the chicken with more than just paprika, and add a tiny spread of Dijon mustard to the roll up.  I bought thin-cut chicken breasts, and they still weren't quite thin enough.  The stated recipe should make this a mandatory step - the chicken breasts should be pounded to a quarter-inch thickness.   

Just remember, the quality of the sauce is dependent on the quality of the wine.  I used a good, oaked Chardonnay, and the sauce was definitely the best part of this dish.  Delicious!

text:
This is my husband's favorite dish, hands down. He tells me I should make extra sauce and bottle it, so he can put it on everything non-Cordon Bleu. :) I use Sauvignon Blanc and thick-sliced lunch meat ham. Cut the ham and Swiss cheese in 1/2 lengthwise, then stack on top of each other to prevent so much cheese oozing out the sides. Comes out perfect every time!

text:
Great base recipe. It's hard to rate a recipe when you do not follow it exactly but, come on, many of us change things in most recipes we find. I love this site because I always check reviews and find what people did different and I usually go by the majority. As many others did I doubled the sauce and I used an flour then egg then panko bread crumbs to coat the stuffed chicken. After browning I finished in the oven for about 25 minutes at 350 while I made the sauce. The sauce was spooned over at the end.  The next day I had two servings left but had to make more sauce. This time, my fianc made the sauce and he added some garlic powder and it was even better.  Enjoy!

text:
I love this recipe! Made as is all the way until the sauce then I added some salt and basil it made it perfect. When I heated the pan I also put half butter half olive oil. 
 Most people this is a given already, but for some I feel they do not know when you make the sauce DON'T clean out the pan before adding the starch and whipping cream.

Also the wine I used was rare find  vintage 2010 California Chardonnay . It made the whole thing come together.

country:
None
text:
I will admit, part of my problem with this recipe is a personal preference.  Not many tasks in the kitchen bother me, but pounding chicken flat is one that drives me crazy.  I tend to avoid recipes that require it.  That aside, once I got done doing that and stuffing the chicken, I realized that getting the chicken nicely coated with the flour mixture was going to be difficult and that once I would try to pan fry all the filling would ooze out.  So I decided to cook it in the oven instead.  The chicken was ok this way, but having to cook in the oven made it tougher to thicken the sauce.  Bottom line, this recipe is way too troublesome for the final results.

region:

country:
None
text:
This was excellent; however, I did things a little differently.  I did not dredge the chicken in flour, instead, I mixed the paprika with Seasoned bread crumbs.  I sprayed a 9x13 glass baking dish with butter Pam, placed the chicken in the dish and sprayed the chicken with the Pam to wet the breadcrumbs.  I baked the chicken at 350 for about 25 minutes.  Then I added about 3TBS of butter to the sauce ingredients, which I cooked in a sauce pan on the stove top.  I served the sauce separately so each person could use it to personal taste.   Super easy and quick!  Will definitely make it again!

text:
Yum, yum! Changed up a few things that made it easier to make and (in my opinion) more delicious. . . Butterflied the chicken breasts, so that I didn't have to make a mess pounding them and waste some plastic wrap. I stuffed the chicken with sliced spiral ham--healthier and heartier than the deli stuff and did NOT include the cheese. I followed the directions for browning and cooking on the stovetop, but instead of adding heavy cream, I added milk and stirred in about two cups of shredded Swiss cheese, and made a cheese sauce! I always hate how the cheese leaks out of the stuffed chicken, so I just thought: What the heck? I'm making a sauce instead! It was so delicious altogether. I'm sticking to my way from now on. :) Great recipe!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good. I tweaked it by preparing the chicken, ham and cheese in the rolls, placed them in a baking dish, sprayed with olive oil cooking spray and sprinkling with paprika. Then I mixed the 1/2 cup of wine and bullion, poured it in the baking dish and baked them for about an hour. I prepared the sauce separately on top of the stove (using the butter, 1 tbsp flour, wine and bullion again and all the rest of the ingredients) and just poured it over the chicken right before serving it. Baking the chicken vs. preparing it on top of the stove is just less messy and predictable for me. My guests and my husband LOVED it! Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
What makes this recipe incredibly good is the white wine sauce. We make our chicken cordon bleu the way we always have - breaded cutlets with the ham and swiss (or gruyere if we have a few extra $) place on top, into a 300 degree oven for 15-20 minutes so the cheese can melt. Now while that's in the oven I make the sauce and it totally makes the dish. Because it's so rich and fattening, this is a treat for special occassions.

Display Name:
aprilmacnamee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times and it is quite simple but fantastic. It is a very rich meal so I only make it on special occasions. A trick I use is to cut the chicken breasts lengthwise in half while they are still somewhat frozen. Very little pounding is necessary when I do this and if still frozen they cut easily.. Plus, I only need three breasts and it makes plenty for a family of 5.  I always coat the chicken in egg/milk mixture and roll them in seasoned bread crumbs as other reviewers suggest. I add paprika to the bread crumbs as well. When I'm browning the chicken, I make sure to get the ends real good because it somewhat sears the chicken edges and keeps the Swiss from escaping! After browning them, I bake them in the oven for about 20 minutes on 350, while I make the sauce separately. I use the same saucepan and keep the pan leavings right in and just add the wine and heavy cream and corn starch and let it cook while the chicken does. I do suggest doubling the sauce!

text:
This is excellent! Used thin chix cutlets/strips and pounded to make a little wider. added the cheese and ham and rolled up.  They were small which shortened the cooking time.  I dipped in egg wash and then rolled in Panko bread crumbs.  Browned for 8-10 minutes then put in a dish and baked for about 15 minutes or so. On the stove I whipped up 1/2 cup butter and 3/4 c milk (was out of cream~ but it worked fine) and then added the wine, chix broth and the corn starch (per recipe).  I let simmer on stove top for about 10 minutes. Whisk as needed and allow to thicken. I drizzled sauce on the chix rolls after they were placed on the plate.  ( I knew the kids wouldn't do the sauce).  It was a HIT!!  This would make a lovely plate to take to a party, get together, etc.  Was easy and DELICIOUS!!!

text:
Very yummy dish, even the leftovers heated up nicely.  I borrowed some suggestions and used an egg wash and garlic and herb breadcrumbs.  After I pounded the chicken out, I sprinkled them with salt, pepper and paprika.  The sauce is simple and very flavorful.  I used a Sauvignon Blanc like Cintron suggested and it worked very well.  I served it with wild rice and brussels sprouts.  One chicken breast would have been good to split; it seemed to make a lot of food.  I highly recommend this recipe, even for novices like myself.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Warning: Made some changes for our tastes, but kept the general integrity of the dish. After pounding out the chicken, I sprinkled onion and garlic powder, parsley, and a little cajun seasoning under the cheese and ham. Then rolled in italian seasoned breadcrumbs and baked them. 

I made the sauce all at once instead of simmering the chicken. Couldn't find boullion granules, so I used a little poultry seasoning in cooking wine and added the above seasonings and a little salt to the sauce, tasting it as I went. (I read on another dish to mix the cornstarch and some of the liquid separately first and get the rest of the sauce boiling, and then add the starch in. It thickened so much faster.) Hubby asked me to please make it again.

userID:
4315505
Display Name:
r-me_grl
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

31

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe twice now; once as written & once with a few changes. As written, this recipe is good, not great. It was a bit bland for our taste and while it wasn't bad; my family preferred my other version of codon bleu. I decided to revisit this recipe one more time to see if we could bring it up to a 5, and I'm happy to say, it went above and beyond.  As suggested, I pounded the breast to about 1/4" thick.  I then used a 1/4 cup mixture of sorghum, buckwheat & brown rice flours with 1/4 cup corn meal and added some garlic powder (everything needs garlic) with a sprinkle of seasoning salt. I used 1/2 olive oil and unsalted butter, basically to keep the butter from burning. As others suggest, I browned the rolls in the sauce pan, then cooked them in the oven @ 350 for 20 min, then covered with sauce and baked them for another 5-10.  For the sauce, I was just shy of a 1/2 cup of white wine, so I used some sherry with a splash or so extra.  I had forgotten about the sauce becoming too think last time with 1 TBS cornstarch, next time, I will cut it 1/4 - 1/2.  I then added some dijon to the sauce, as it was still a bit bland; it was amazing. Unfortunately, I don't know how much I added, 1-2 tsp., maybe.  The combination of the sauce with the chicken was amazing..

5

text:
Wonderful recipe.  Made it for company.  Received rave reviews.  I did coat with seasoned bread crumbs along with the flour/paprika.  I doubled the sauce per the suggestion of other reviewers.  I used only half of the one called for due to personal preference and used chicken stock for the rest.  I did use whole milk instead of heavy cream because it's what I had.  It didn't seem to affect the outcome.  I did add about 1 t. of Italian seasoning and 1/2 t of garlic powder to the sauce just to give it some more flavor.  Excellent!  Served it with garlic smashed potatoes and sauteed spinach.

I have made this recipe for years. It is my son's pick for his Birthday dinner every year since I started making it. Display Name:
Stefani

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is delicious.  I've made it according to the recipe before, but have decided to make it an open faced dish instead.  It spreads the ingredients equally so there's a piece of ham, cheese and sauce in every bite. I used the recipe measurements as is listed just changed up the way it's put together.  All I did, was pound the chicken, salt and pepper it.  Then coat it in the flour/paprika mixture.  Fry till both sides are golden, remove and put in a single row in a baking dish.  Top each piece with ham and swiss then de-glaze the pan with the wine and chicken granules. Simmered it for about 5 minutes and then added in the flour and heavy cream mixture. Poured that over the chicken and baked in the 325 degree  oven for 15 minutes.  It was perfect.

text:
Wow this is a great recipe!  It's the 2nd time I've made it. Reading the other reviews really helped.  I had to make this gluten free b/c of my brother's food allergies and it was still delicious!  I substituted with soy flour.  I used cooking string instead of tooth picks and used 1/2 olive oil, 1/2 butter for the frying.  Then I put it in a pan and baked it, as suggested by other reviewers.  It was perfect b/c I did that in the a.m. and then put in the oven when my guest (12 people) came.  I also made the sauce in a sauce pot, as suggested.  Came out fabulous!  Everyone thought it was the best!  Thanks to the other reviewers for their great ideas.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The family really enjoyed this.  I did prepare it a little different based on reviews and my family's preferences.  Once I rolled up the chicken, I dipped it in an egg wash and rolled it in breadcrumbs seasoned with paprika, black pepper, and garlic.  I baked the chicken at 350 for about 40 minutes and made the sauce in a saucepan and served it tableside.  I think next time I'll add some dijon mustard to the sauce to add another dimension.  It took almost 45 minutes to prep (clean/trim chicken, pound chicken, assemble the chicken/ham/swiss, egg wash, and bread).  That being said, the recipe is worth the effort.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this out and was surprised it tasted good. But i didnt follow the recipe per se but did my own revisions. First i dipped the chicken with ham and cheese inside in egg then breadcrumbs with paprika. Panfried it in butter for 5-10 minutes. while panfrying i made the sauce, mix cream, cornstarch, wine, and chicken granules (2tsps) cook in pan for a few minutes. the panfried chicken put in a casserole together with the butter from the pan and bake 350degrees for 30minutes. after 30 minutes pour in the creamy wine sauce and bake again for 20 minutes. put chopped basil leaves on top then serve.

text:
Truly a 5 star recipe... I marinate my chicken in a salt water brine for 1 hour before cooking to increase flavor and moistness.  In addition, I usually only make 2 chicken breast halves; but still make the same about of sauce.  The sauce is so good and great served over rice.  For those not aware: dry wine is not sweet.  Choose a good chardonnay... that's what I always use. Yum!

None
text:
After making it with and without the wine, I can say that that the wine makes a difference!  Even if it's just the cheap stuff.  Yes, you can substitute chicken broth, but the flavor is simply not as good, even with homemade boiled down broth.  To make up for it I tossed in a piece of ham for flavor, some better-than-bouillon beef flavor and  a little cream cheese (basically whatever I had on hand).  We don't drink, but I normally keep a little cooking wine on hand and by the time you've boiled it for 30min the alcohol will be completely gone leaving a delicious flavor behind. Yum!

text:
This was amazing, and tasted even better the next day! I used kitchen twine instead of toothpicks, they were easy to cut off and held the chicken together nicely! Making the chicken 1/2 inch in thickness is a must, and make sure all of your rolled up chicken pieces are about the same size, so the insides cook at the same rate, will definitely double the sauce next time, and will add non-fat milk instead of more heavy cream as it was too rich for my taste buds.

OMG this was phenomenal! I made it exactly as the recipe stated except I used 3 tbsp. butter & then enough olive oil to coat the pan. I also used half & half instead of the heavy whipping cream because I accidentally bought that instead, it was still amazing! This is one of the few dishes I've made that look & taste like restaurant quality! I've never had chicken cordon bleu before & let me tell you it was awesome!! I am really looking forward to having the leftovers for lunch today! It was so easy too, guests would think you spent hours slaving in the kitchen!! I made this for my husband & I's anniversary & managed to whip this up with a side of rice while still having time to care for my 3 week old son! He thought I slaved all day making it!!! Absolutely delish! Thanks for the wonderful recipe :)

text:
I thought the chicken was outstanding. I used string to hold the chicken together, but i will have to say it was a little bit of a challenge finding the string again (to cut) before serving. But I don't think I did the sauce right.  I removed the chicken after 30 minutes of cooking in wine, butter, etc. but then I heated the cream and cornstarch in a cleaned pan, then heated it until it was thick. It did not seem right but I thought I was following directions. Apparently, you need to add the corn starch and cream mixture to the existing oils, butter, etc. I just didn't do it initially b/c I thought the pan scrapings, chicken fat, etc. was too dark. Oh well, next time I know...

text:
There were a few things I found odd about this recipe...and will do differently next time.  First, I'd brown the chicken in the skillet, then bake it in the oven. Leaving it in the skillet for another 30 minutes just did not work for me. The chicken was nearly burnt to a crisp on several sides (granted, my burners run a bit hotter than normal and I forgot that).   Also, why hold the chicken together with toothpicks? The picture seems to show that it was rolled...that makes much more sense than toothpicks.   The flour & paprika was nice, however. Just needs a few changes and I'd give it 5 stars.

text:
I absolutely loved this recipe!! It has been a VERY long time since I have enjoyed my own cooking...but when I made this...I was the one ranting and raving!!!  Instead of wine, I used chicken broth.I didn't add the chicken granules. I doubled the sauce. With this I made stuffed baked potatoes...bake the potaotes..6 of them. Then I scooped out the potato from the skin. I put in my KA mixer and added 1 cup sour cream, 1/2 cup butter, 2 cups tex-mex cheese, 1/4 cup real bacon bits, and chopped up some green onions. Scoop back into the skins, bake for 20 minutes at 400 and the turn up oven to broil and broil till nice brown and crispy. Awesome with the sauce on top!! Thanks for the great recipe!!!!

text:
Spectacular. Not only is this recipe delicious, it's fun to make and smells amazing while you cook it.   I've had to split the breasts up into two different pans due to lack of space. I did put more than half of the other ingredients (butter, wine, granules, etc.) in each pan. This allowed for equal cooking, more white sauce, and more creativity. Bottomline: the quantities in this recipe are very flexible.  I tried to make one of these with Pepper Jack cheese....not recommended. All of the cheese melted out of the chicken and ended up in the sauce. Good for the sauce, not for the chicken. The sauce is also really good the next morning on breakfast ham. Enjoy!

This is a great recipe, easier than I anticipated.  I did add Pankow to the flour mix. Poured about half of the sauce on top of chicken while it was in the oven, reserved the rest and served as  gravy.  I did add two more Tbs. butter and a little more wine than then the recipe called for so I was sure to have extra.  Will make this again!

text:
This is the first recipe that I've spent the time to write a review for, but this one was worth it.  Because of both the ease and of course the ultimate end product, this was a winner.  I personally like a bit more flavor, so instead of regular ham I did use Prosciutto and I did add extra cheese, but that's a personal preference.  I do recommend pounding out the chicken breasts as another reviewer recommended, not only does it shorten cooking times somewhat, but it will make them consistent.  Enjoy this recipe, I know that my family and I did and that includes two picky youngsters (5 and 6).

text:
I needed to use up some left over Christmas ham and this was an excellent option. I didnt have swiss cheese, so substituted cheddar. I pan fried it in an oven safe pan, added the wine/stock mixture, then as my biscuits baked at 350*F for 20 minutes, I finished cooking the chicken as well. They were pounded out fairly thin, so that amount of time worked well. I just finished off the cream sauce on the stove. Family loved it- very rich, but a great overall recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my god, this was sooo good, I am so happy that I can finally make a meal that would be worthy of the fanciest of restaurants :) Making this dish was kind of a spur of the moment thing, so I had to substitute some of the ingredients, but it turned out so great that I think I will make it with these alterations the next time too, and BELIEVE ME, there will be a next time! I didn't have any heavy cream, or even milk, so I used sour cream and a little water, worked great! Used strips of bacon instead of ham, I wrapped it around the cheese, I think this helped prevent the cheese from escaping from my chicken during cooking :) I also added garlic powder, onion powder and some salt and pepper to the flour mixture, and I used 3Ts butter and 3Ts olive oil as a lot of other people suggested. Didn't use tooth picks or string or anything, but my chicken held together just fine. And finally, if you make this dish, be sure to double the amount of sauce, it's out of this world!
