text:
This was very tasty and moist.  The cream sauce was superb!  I followed a lot of the suggestions and it was a hit.  I was concerned it would not have enough flavor since the only seasoning is Paprika so I lightly seasoned the inside of the chicken breasts with season salt.  I also used bread crumbs as suggested and I lightly seasoned the crumbs with season salt, onion powder, and paprika.  I browned them in a skillet for 10 minutes then finished up in the oven for 20 mins on 350 degrees.  I prepared the wine sauce separately. I will definitely prepare this again!

Display Name:
Shannon Perry

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1868571.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this was really yummy. i gave it a 4 only because i changed it some. some things i did differently, cooked chicken breasts with bone and skin in crock pot until done(skipped the flouring and browning step).  remove the bone and skin, wrap the large pieces of chicken(or several small pieces) with swiss, then ham.  melt the butter in the skillet, add a bullion cube and i used the broth from the crockpot instead of wine, simmer for a minute, then add the cornstarch/cream and whisk until it thickens.  i poured some sauce in a baking dish to cover the bottom, put the chicken/ham pieces in, then poured the rest of the sauce over the top.  sprinkled a little parmesean on top, baked at 350 (covered)for 10 minutes until bubbling. and voila! was super delicious! picky boyfriend even loved it!

text:
One of the best on allrecipes.com.  What I did was copied pasted this recipe in a Word document then copied and pasted the three most helpful reviews on the bottom (shrunk the font a little so it ends up on one page).  Then I took a highlighter and highlighted the best suggestions, or what I thought was good advice.  The highlighting helps because my eyes only focus on the good stuff so I'm not reading all the other stuff that I'm not doing.  Much better than rewriting then not being about to read my handwriting.  Also put this in a clear plastic sheet protector because I'm a really messy cook!  I obviously make this a lot!  Enjoy!

text:
SO GOOD! I scaled it down to 2 servings. Due to some of the reviews of the chicken itself being a bit bland, I marinated it for about 4 hrs in apx. 1Tb Goulden's Spicy Brown Mustard, 1Tb Apricot preserves, 1/2c half and half, 1ts corriander, mixed well, coated pounded chicken. Rolled a Havarti slice in a Black Forest Ham, proceeded with recipe as written. Since they were quite big, I just served it with a green salad and crusty baguette. I actually got up from the table and returned with the pan so we could sop up the sauce with our bread! This one's gonna be a regular around here for sure.

text:
Really delish...after reading reviews complaining about leaking swiss cheese, I decided to prepare a bit differently.  After dredging pounded chicken in flour/paprika/garlic salt/pepper mixture, I pan "fried" both sides in butter and then placed chicken covered with ham slice and swiss cheese in baking dish for about 20 minutes.  During this cooking time, I prepared sauce as described and then poured over chicken once served on plates.  Really yummy!

We LOVED this recipe! I made this for my Mum's birthday and it was perfect. Thank you for the recipe. I did make a few changes, though (it never fails XP). I did use breadcrumbs in place of the flour. I browned the chicken in the pan and then baked it for about 40 mins (I used whole breasts instead of halves) at 350. For the sauce I used chicken stock instead of white wine and I also added some dijon mustard and it turned out great! Thank you for the wonderful recipe, we will definitely be making this again!

text:
Excellent recipe!  However, to make it healthier and even better, substitute evaporated skim milk (same quantity) for the cream.  I know in some recipes cream makes the recipe, but for this one the wine sauce interacts with the evaporated skim milk perfectly.  Try this substitution - you will be amazed at how good it is!

text:
This was soooo good!!!!! I spread dijon mustard on the chicken before the ham.  I also rolled the swiss cheese inside 2 slices of ham and the cheese did not ooze out when cooking. I fried in a pan on all sides and then popped in the over for 30 min at 350.  While chicken was in the oven I doubled the sauce and the poured on top of chicken and covered for another 10 minutes.  I made a loaf of French bread in the bread machine and it was perfect for dipping into the wonderful sauce.  It was a friends 50th Birthday dinner and this was a perfect meal to serve, everyone loved it!!  THANK YOU FOR THIS RECIPE!!!!!

1687165
Display Name:
cmay80

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!  My husband wanted to know what I bought & how much I spent since I only ever make fancy dinners when I come home from spending too much shopping.  He loved it & did not believe me when I said it was nothing fancy to make.  I have a problem following directions & tend to cook by personal taste & this a great recipe for that, you do not have to go by exact measurements.  It is also nice because it is a one-pot-meal, less is cleaning always nice.  Defiantly check out the other comments for helpful tips.  The best ideas are to cook in the oven @ 350 for 20 min after browning on the stove top & to add a slice of cheese to the sauce.  Cooking in the oven frees up the stove to make your sides.  I also doubled the sauce after I removed the chicken & used it all.  The tooth picks were tricky & I couldnt really seal the chicken around the filling so I just folded it in half & placed the cheese on both sides of the ham inside (that way the cheese sticks to the chicken instead of sliding off the ham).  I used thick-cut deli meat & cheese slices and half&half instead of cream.  This will defiantly become a dinner staple & not just when I feel guilty for that pair of shoes I just had to have ;)

text:
This was a big hit at our house!  I browned my chicken in half butter/half olive oil to help keep the butter from burning, as well as for the health benefits.  I don't really care for the taste of wine so I just substituted chicken broth instead.  I also did not have any heavy cream at the time, so I just substituted milk.  This helped make it a bit healthier as well.  I will definitely make this again.  It was an instant favorite with our five kids!

AMAZING! I usually make this like the recipe with boneless chicken breast but the only fresh chicken breast they had in Whitehorse at the time was bone-in. So I rolled up the chesse in the ham and then used a toothpick and stuck it to the top of the meat. It turned out awesome, very moist and no cheese leaked out. When I make it again, i will use the same chicken breast, we loved it that way and it saves a lot of time too. I had extra cheese so I melted it in the sauce. Delicious!!! Thanks so much for this recipe

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had never had Cordon Bleu or made it before tonight.  It was terrific!!!  I do have a few suggestions... I find that toothpicks are a bit tricky, so I use these great cooking rubber bands!  (They withstand temperatures up to 600F and can be used with virtually any cooking technique.)  They are so easy to use and make rolling the chicken fast and easy.  I used two rubber bands per breast (they come in a pack of 24).  The bands keep the chicken in a perfect roll and even make it easy to slice afterwards! I used Carlo Rossi Chablis for my white wine.  It is great for cooking and BevMo has it at a great price!   Lastly, I cranked up the heat at the end to thicken the sauce.  It thickened perfectly! This was a terrific recipe!  Thanks for sharing :-)!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/169104.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am sure this recipe is good as is but since i follow a severely restricted low carbohydrate diet i change a few things. The result was delicious. Replace the flour with about 3/4 cup of crushed pork rinds, yes pork rinds. Try it. they make a remarkable breading and have practically no carb content. I dipped the prepared chicken lightly in cream before rolling them in the crushed pork rinds. I also omitted the corn starch and found the sauce quite thick enough without it.  I garnished the completed dish with a little torn basis.  My guests loved it and commented on how beautifully browned the breading was. A Keeper

text:
Breaded with Panko breadcrumbs instead of flour, used olive oil instead of butter, and fat-free plain yogurt instead of cream (thickened with corn starch).  It was delicious, and my family has already requested it again.

I also rolled the chicken TIGHTLY (like prosciutto in an antipasto) instead of folding.

Quick, easy, and delicious!

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty, but tricky for rookies like me!  It's really tough to roll ham and cheese into a neat little chicken bundle-I used plenty of toothpicks, and that made it hard to brown them on all sides.  I took a few of the reviewer suggestions: I used light cream instead of heavy cream, gravy flour instead of cornstarch, and a mixture of olive oil and butter rather than just plain butter.  I also cooked the chicken with the bouillon and wine in an oven at 350 instead of in the pan.  I brushed the chicken with a mixture of melted butter and dijon mustard before I put the ham and cheese on and rolled them.  After the chicken was done, I strained the melted cheese out of the wine/boullion and simmered it, adding the cream/gravy flour mixture slowly. It didn't get as thick as I thought it should be, but I was also a little impatient, so maybe it just needed a little more time.  It was really good, and my guests loved it...but it sure seemed like a lot of work! I think next time I'll manage it a little better.
Review:
Rating:
5

This recipe is SOOOOOOOOO good! This is my first time ever eating cordon bleu and I am very happy with the outcome. I tried to follow the recipe word from word but somehow I forgot to bread the chicken before placing it into the butter. As a result I let the chicken simmer in the wine for 10 min. then placed it in another pan to broil the top in the oven. Even though it took me a little longer because of my mistake it was worth it. You could not go wrong with this recipe.

text:
This recipe is extremely good. Being a beginner, it proved to be a little messy for me but it was well worth the effort. To cut down on the grease, I made the sauce in a separate pan instead of all the greasy butter from cooking the chicken. I just added a little extra virgin olive oil to it instead. And the toothpicks were a pain but I didn't bother taking them out; I just told my husband to be careful when he cut and ate the chicken. I would use larger toothpicks or even skewers next time so that they are more easily removed.  Great recipe, though!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We ended up baking the chicken right after browning them b/c the chicken was too thick. We baked the chicken at 350F for 30 mins, but wrapped & sealed them in foil to keep them moist. Then I opened foil & drained the juice back into the skillet, to add the wine, chicken bouillon, whipping cream & corn starch(+cold water) to finish off the sauce. I kept  the sauce heating for a while & stirring which was my mistake of not serving it once it was ready. My guests really enjoyed this dish & how moist the chicken was.

text:
This recipe was delicious and easy to make.  I used chicken broth in place of the white wine and bouillon (thats what I had at home and it worked great).  To reduce the fat I used 1 tblspn butter and 2 tblspn olive oil for browning, and 1/4 cup heavy cream w/ 1/4 cup chicken stock w/ the cornstarch for the sauce.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After all the good ratings I was really prepared for serving something special for dinner. I did make some changes though. I used breadcrumbs as the others suggested and transferred the breasts into a separate pan and baked them in the oven. I was afraid that the breading would become too mushy if cooked in the sauce. I made the sauce and served it on the side. Well, neither my husband, nor I were impressed. It was good, edible, but nothing special. Maybe I did something wrong...I usually make cordon bleu in a little bit different way. After dipping the rolled-up breasts in flour, egg and then breadcrumbs I fry them in oil. Maybe not that healthy, but certainly very tasty with mashed potatoes and pickled cucumbers.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3566572.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a quick and relatively easy chicken cordon bleu recipe that my boyfriend gobbled down (even though he said he wasn't a big fan of cordon bleu to begin with).  I followed the recipe ver batim except that I only used two chicken breasts (and had a lot of extra sauce).  Like others said, the gravy is the best part, so the extra wasn't a burden.  I served this over rice, but my boyfriend and I are thinking the gravy would be fantastic over potatoes.  We only had Chardonnay in the house - it was a touch too floral.  I will try to get my hands on some Pinot next time.  Five stars from me - this is good eatin'!

UPDATE:  I've found Barefoot Pinot to be a cheap and tasty wine to use.  I prefer to use egg wash/bread crumbs over flour.  I also had to last-minute substitute 2% milk for heavy cream, and it turned out fine. Sure, some of the richness is gone, but it's still very, very good.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A bit complicated recipe but worth the time. This was my first Chicken Cordon Bleu effort and I loved it! I used Half butter, half olive oil to brown the chicken. In my opinion you should definitely use the wine. Substituting with broth just will not achieve the maximum flavor. Also I tied my rolled chicken with twine and forgot about the toothpicks, they're too complicated to dig out afterwards. If you're not a huge fan of Swiss, use baby swiss. Its much milder while packing the same punch. And last but not least, this dish needs citrus. Serve with some fresh lemon slices on the side. Yum!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This was easy to make and a great meal to make for a bunch of people!!!  Would definitely recommend this!!!  The only thing I did differently was instead of using cornstarch to thicken the sauce, I melted 3 TBS of butter and whisked in 3 TBS flour to make a roux and then added that to the sauce to thicken it.

text:
This recipe is excellent and simple. I used 2 chicken buillon cubes with one cup of white wine.Simmered the chicken until it was done and then removed from pan. Added the heavy cream mixed with corn starch. Served the sauce on the side with stuffing. Delicious over everything. Used the remainder of the sauce the next day with some cubed up cooked chicken breast. Almost reminds me of chicken marsala. Don't be afraid to try this! Used a pinot grigio off the clearance rack for 3.99

region:

country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. I made a few small changes in the preperation of the chicken. I rolled the cheese in ham, and then rolled the chicken around them. I breaded the breasts in both flour and then bread crumbs (using an egg wash). I fried them for about 5 minutes in oil until they were brown, and then baked them for about 30mins in the oven. They looked and tasted excellent!  My sauce wasn't the best (accidently used some corn SYRUP instead of starch at first... i'm a beginner!) though it ended up tasting quite good. I ended up putting a fair amount of parsley in the sauce, but otherwise I followed the recipe. Served it all with wild rice, salad, mashed carrots/parsnips, and asparagus. It all disappeared!

My fellow wanted this for his birthday supper. My guests loved it and I thought it was pretty easy, though removing the toothpicks was a pain in the butt.  I didn't use wine, and substituted soy milk for heavy cream, in an attempt to make this a little more compatible to my dairy-free, alcohol-free requirements.  Kept a cheese-free piece of chicken specially marked for myself.  I've had the real thing before I developed food allergies, and this alternative is not as decadent but is still really good. It's why I can't give it 5 stars, though.

text:
Absolutely wonderful, and very easy to make.  I actually used chicken tenders instead of chiken breasts, since that's what I had on hand.  So, I pounded them out, and ended up making a bunch of "mini" Chicken Cordon Bleus.  It worked just as well, and cooked in a lot less time (simmered about 10-15 min).  I also used baking wine (sherry), which still gave it a great flavor.  Other than that, I followed the directions as they're written.  Wonderful, thanks for the recipe. I will certainly make it again!

This was an excellent recipe. I cooked it for my families Labor Day cookoff. Yes it was a winner. I made a few changes, we are a family that love flavor, so I marinated thin chicken fillets for about 3 hours in the refrigerator with garlic salt and black pepper on one side and the other with season all. Then I followed the directions except for butter, I'm not a big fan of real butter so I used margarine instead. This dish was a real WINNER!!!

text:
This was easy and delicious!  I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and after coating the rolled chicken with flour, I dipped it in melted butter and rolled in bread crumbs.  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly.  Next time though, I will probably omit the bread crumbs because it left crumbs in the sauce, and I had to transfer the liquid (minus the crumbs) to another pan to finish the sauce.  The sauce was incredibly good!  Thank you very much for sharing this recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/86136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy....made a few adjustments. I egged, breaded(in italian flavored crumbs) and fried my chicken cutlets first. I place them in a baking pan and layered the ham and swiss on top...covered with foil and heated until the cheese was melted. I made the wine sauce on top on the stove (also used fat free 1/2 and 1/2 instead of heavy cream)and halved it..we poured some of the wine sauce over the cutlet cordon bleu. It was delicious! Sometimes when I make a cordon bleu the rolled way....the cheese totally runs out as it is cooking.....same concept here....just easier to prepare....same great taste!! Thanks for a great recipe!

None
text:
Excellent dish, especially for company, because it looks so fancy.  The chicken came out this wonderfully even golden color, beautiful.  I didn't have bouillon, so I used a little chicken broth instead, but will try to use bouillon in the future -- the sauce, though great, needed just a tad more flavor to it to be "wow".  I followed the directions exactly and it came out great.  Only change was using xantham gum instead of cornstarch to thicken (less carbs) and cutting the butter down to 4 tbls.
